source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can’t you see I’m eating?
target: Thou dost see I eat.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What are you going to do?
target: What wilt thou do?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Father, go ahead.
target: Father, in.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He won’t have a chance.
target: Then he shall have no odds.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s say goodbye to him.
target: Let’s take leave of him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Cleopatra— How could I have ever thought that you would be faithful and true, even though your vows of love shook the heavens themselves—you, who were unfaithful to Fulvia?
target: Cleopatra— Why should I think you can be mine, and true— Though you in swearing shake the thronèd gods— Who have been false to Fulvia?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Only my free will—nothing else.
target: Oh, this is the poison of deep grief.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Back when I was a schoolboy, if I lost an arrow I would try to find it by shooting another arrow in the same direction, watching the second arrow more carefully than I had the first.
target: In my school days, when I had lost one shaft, I shot his fellow of the selfsame flight The selfsame way with more advisèd watch To find the other forth—and by adventuring both, I oft found both.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hope sores cover your tongue for a wish like that!
target: Blistered be thy tongue For such a wish!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He who chooses me will get what many men want.” What many men want—that “many” could mean that most people are fools and choose by whatever is flashy.
target: What many men desire”—that “many” may be meant By the fool multitude that choose by show, Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach; Which pries not to th' interior, but like the martlet Builds in the weather on the outward wall, Even in the force and road of casualty.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think of as many things as he does, but I just thank heaven and don’t show off about it.
target: I think of as many matters as he, but I give heaven thanks and make no boast of them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Be a careful mother, madam, and think about your son, the young prince.
target: Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother, Of the young prince your son.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s the same kind of guy who got you upset and made you suspect I’d cheated on you with the Moor.
target: Some such squire he was That turned your wit the seamy side without And made you to suspect me with the Moor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But why couldn’t I say “Amen”?
target: But wherefore could not I pronounce “Amen”?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let it stay in your inventory until it bankrupts you.
target: Lie they upon thy hand And be undone by ’em!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Just remember who you’ve got on board with you, good man.
target: Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who do you obey here?
target: Do you perceive in all this noble company Where most you owe obedience?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, wake up, wake up, wake up!
target: Come, stir, stir, stir!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He has epilepsy, a disease where you fall down.
target: He hath the falling sickness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I won’t sleep until I see her, Hortensio.
target: I will not sleep, Hortensio, till I see her, And therefore let me be thus bold with you To give you over at this first encounter, Unless you will accompany me thither.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We achieve things with our intelligence, not by magic, and intelligent planning takes time.
target: Thou know’st we work by wit and not by witchcraft, And wit depends on dilatory time.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But don’t be easily won over.
target: And be not easily won to our requests.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m glad you’re insane enough to admit it in front of me.
target: I am glad to see you mad.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t miss our feast.
target: Fail not our feast.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Isn’t it possible to imagine that the noble ashes of Alexander the Great could end up plugging a hole in a barrel?
target: Why may not imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander till he find it stopping a bunghole?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But for the whole world?
target: But for the whole world?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We respected the beat of the song, sir.
target: We did keep time, sir, in our catches.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, then he must be alive.
target: Why then, he is alive.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s too bad.
target: Tell thou the tale!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And what would that accomplish?
target: To what end?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I were my father, cousin, would I do this?
target: Were I my father, coz, would I do this?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Block up my house’s ears—I mean the windows.
target: By Jacob’s staff, I swear, I have no mind of feasting forth tonight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’s nothing to fear in him.
target: There is no fear in him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s get dressed quickly and then meet in the hall.
target: Let’s briefly put on manly readiness, And meet i' th' hall together.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, you evil woman!
target: O most pernicious woman!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They drink Danes under the table, and it takes them no effort at all to out-drink Germans.
target: Why, he drinks you with facility your Dane dead drunk; he sweats not to overthrow your Almain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Drown yourself?
target: Drown thyself?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why didn’t they just kill us that night?
target: Wherefore did they not That hour destroy us?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No one’s heard from him.
target: He cannot be heard of.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You notorious whore!
target: O notable strumpet!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What time is it?
target: How’s the day?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My child, my reason for living, wake up, look up, or I’ll die with you!
target: My child, my only life, Revive, look up, or I will die with thee!— Help, help!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lady Olivia told her servant Malvolio to kick you out of the house.
target: If my lady have not called up her steward Malvolio and bid him turn you out of doors, never trust me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re making a terrible racket out here!
target: What a caterwauling do you keep here!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So it’s nearly the time when the ghost likes to appear.
target: It then draws near the season Wherein the spirit held his wont to walk.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go to my room and put on something of mine.
target: Go to my chamber, put on clothes of mine.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No stony tower, no brass walls, no airless dungeon, no iron chains can contain a strong mind.
target: Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass, Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron Can be retentive to the strength of spirit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I assure you, my man is as true as steel.
target: Warrant thee, my man’s as true as steel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’ll go away.
target: Why that’s with watching, ’twill away again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Me neither, my lord.
target: Nor I, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So prepare to die.
target: Therefore prepare to die.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir John Falstaff.
target: Sir John Falstaff.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is Clarence dead?
target: Is Clarence dead?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re right.
target: Tis spoken well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But when our vices become habits—Oh, the sadness of it!—the wise gods blind us, shade our better judgment, make us love our mistakes, and laugh as we strut to our ruin.
target: But when we in our viciousness grow hard— Oh, misery on ’t!—the wise gods seel our eyes, In our own filth drop our clear judgments, make us Adore our errors, laugh at ’s while we strut To our confusion.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s been killed.
target: He is slain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We can’t think that way about what we did.
target: These deeds must not be thought After these ways.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Caesar’s better qualities exist in Brutus, and we will crown him.
target: Caesar’s better parts Shall be crowned in Brutus!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are those my tents on fire?
target: Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She doesn’t have anything going for her so far.
target: There’s nothing in her yet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye, good Mr. Love.
target: Farewell, good Signior Love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me tell
target: These fellows have some soul,

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If not, he’s got truth on his side!
target: If not, he’s plain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tonight I received a letter from my sister telling me all about them—and warning me not be at home in case they come to stay at my house.
target: I have this present evening from my sister Been well informed of them—and with such cautions That if they come to sojourn at my house I’ll not be there.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Small but brave in his surroundings, he’s trying to stand up against the wind and rain blowing back and forth.
target: Strives in his little world of man to outscorn The to-and-fro–conflicting wind and rain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hurt him in eleven different places.
target: Hurt him in eleven places.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Follow”?
target: Follow”?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I didn’t find him at the Elephant.
target: I could not find him at the Elephant.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That really is an illegitimate hope.
target: That were a kind of bastard hope indeed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: With that, I hope God is with him!
target: And so, God be with him!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He left to fetch a necklace and he promised to bring it to the Porcupine, where I was dining with Balthasar.
target: That goldsmith there, were he not packed with her, Could witness it, for he was with me then, Who parted with me to go fetch a chain, Promising to bring it to the Porpentine, Where Balthasar and I did dine together.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Friends, Romans, countrymen, give me your attention.
target: Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Calphurnia, my wife, is keeping me at home.
target: Calphurnia here, my wife, stays me at home.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll run away from you and hide in the bushes, and leave you to the mercy of wild animals.
target: I’ll run from thee and hide me in the brakes, And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t worry about that.
target: Never fear that.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’re in God’s hands, brother, not in theirs.
target: We are in God’s hand, brother, not in theirs.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What didn’t you like?
target: What didst not like?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here’s a postscript!.
target: Here is yet a postscript.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, I’m the man you’re speaking of.
target: I am he that is so love-shaked.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When I send for you, come out wearing masks.
target: Well, daughter, and you gentlewomen all, Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves, And when I send for you, come hither masked.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Indeed, I would have such an exploit for you, Ligarius, if you were healthy enough to hear it.
target: Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius, Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This was the basket.
target: This was his basket.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A worthy fool!
target: A worthy fool!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There are rats and thieves and pirates—not to mention storms, winds, and rocks.
target: There be land rats and water rats, water thieves and land thieves—I mean pirates—and then there is the peril of waters, winds, and rocks.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s a deal.
target: There’s a bargain made.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I held the sword and he ran on it.
target: I held the sword and he did run on it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That will kill our lovers.
target: Why, then, we kill all our women.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I want to speak with Clarence, and I came here on my legs.
target: I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve changed my mind about that.
target: I am changed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Show us the way.
target: Lead the way.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And then?
target: What then?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s the matter?
target: What’s the matter?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Both fencers are bleeding—how do you feel, my lord?
target: They bleed on both sides.—How is it, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Edward Plantagenet, why are you dead?
target: Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But you didn’t, even though you had every reason.
target: You have some cause; they have not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good-bye, sir.
target: Farewell, dear mother.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take up the sword again, or take me up.
target: Take up the sword again, or take up me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And so, good-bye.
target: And so, adieu.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tybalt was my nephew!
target: Tybalt, my cousin!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good sir, stay close to me.
target: Good sir, draw near to me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you there?
target: Yea, art thou there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She confessed.
target: She confesses it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They ought to be whipped for being so stupid.
target: Whip me such honest knaves.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I must and will have Katherine for my wife.
target: I must and will have Katherine to my wife.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I answered that Lepidus had become too brutal and abused his position.
target: I have told him, Lepidus was grown too cruel, That he his high authority abused And did deserve his change.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A greater gift?
target: A greater gift?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give my regards to Hastings, Catesby.
target: Commend me to Lord William.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, oh, Edmund, I don’t like this monstrous business.
target: Alack, alack, Edmund, I like not this unnatural dealing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll say you’re not feeling well.
target: I will forestall their repair hither and say you are not fit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If God will be revenged for this deed, he will do it publicly.
target: If God will be avengèd for this deed, O, know you yet He doth it publicly!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I didn’t want to be free like this.
target: Yet would not so have been, Durst I have done my will.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Isn’t it past two o'clock?
target: Is it not past two o'clock?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All the worse that she stooped this low, then.
target: She’s the worse for all this.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good night then, Casca.
target: Good night then, Casca.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And even if they don’t, at least Hero’s supposed death will stop the rumors of her infidelity.
target: But if all aim but this be leveled false, The supposition of the lady’s death Will quench the wonder of her infamy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Just being thanked is more than enough for me, madam.
target: To be acknowledged, madam, is o'erpaid.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll have celebration feasts for each other before we go our separate ways.
target: We’ll feast each other ere we part, and let’s Draw lots who shall begin.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Some are born great—”
target: Some are born great—”

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll win yet.
target: We will yet do well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She weeps for Edward and so do I, while she does not weep for Clarence, though I do.
target: She for an Edward weeps, and so do I; I for a Clarence weep; so doth not she.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Isn’t my name Hero?
target: Is it not Hero?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come, explain.
target: Come, instance.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Gentleness is the only way to go—gently, gently.
target: No way but gentleness, gently, gently.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In this wicked world, criminals often take the money they stole and use it to buy off the law, shoving justice aside.
target: In the corrupted currents of this world Offense’s gilded hand may shove by justice, And oft ’tis seen the wicked prize itself Buys out the law.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All the spirits hate him as much as I do.
target: They all do hate him As rootedly as I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ve made up your mind, then?
target: You are resolute, then?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stop, brave lady, stop!
target: Hold, worthy lady, hold!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen, in books they say that true love always faces obstacles.
target: For aught that I could ever read, Could ever hear by tale or history, The course of true love never did run smooth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How does she claim to own you?
target: What claim lays she to thee?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Which one of them should I pick?
target: Which of them shall I take?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: These things are beyond anything we’ve seen before, and I’m afraid.
target: These things are beyond all use, And I do fear them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But step aside, fairy!
target: But, room, fairy!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me to run, and I’ll run.
target: I will run.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’s no point in looking for him if he doesn’t want to be found.
target: Go, then, for ’tis in vain To seek him here that means not to be found.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But don’t delay.
target: Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Maybe the king is sending you to the Tower to have you renamed.
target: O, belike his majesty hath some intent That you shall be new christened in the Tower.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The nine Muses mourning the death of learning and scholarship.” That’s some sharp, critical satire, and it’s not appropriate for a wedding.
target: The thrice three Muses mourning for the death  Of learning, late deceased in beggary.” That is some satire, keen and critical, Not sorting with a nuptial ceremony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thank you.
target: I thank you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Call up your courage.
target: Put color in thy cheek.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I beg you, daughter, don’t make me crazy.
target: Now, I prithee, daughter, do not make me mad.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Just because I act familiar with you sometimes and let you fool around and joke with me, you try to take advantage of my affection.
target: Because that I familiarly sometimes Do use you for my fool and chat with you, Your sauciness will jest upon my love And make a common of my serious hours.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Some startling news has just arrived, sir.
target: There’s strange news come, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lady, did you sleep in her room last night?
target: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s good we’re doing this.
target: Tis good we do so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Which ring did you give away, my lord?
target: What ring gave you my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So, by Christ, I’ll cut off your head.
target: So Chrish save me, I will cut off your head.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The partygoers have arrived.
target: The revelers are entering, brother.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The Prince and Claudio are hurrying this way.
target: Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re wise!
target: Oh, thou art wise!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look with your ears.
target: Look with thine ears.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s a lot like you.
target: Of your complexion.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you planning to go out?
target: Think you to walk forth?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll die like a swan.
target: I will play the swan.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Cousins, you all have work to do.—Oh, I beg your pardon.
target: Cousins, you know what you have to do.—O, I cry you mercy, friend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, as short as a woman’s love.
target: As woman’s love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I see you’re troubled.
target: But I do see you’re moved.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Regan, is that what you said?
target: Said you so?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He made my heart leap for you.
target: He started one poor heart of mine in thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why are you hiding that letter?
target: Why so earnestly seek you to put up that letter?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But where have you been?
target: But where hast thou been, then?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll talk more about this later.—Egeus, I’m overriding your wishes.
target: Of this discourse we more will hear anon.— Egeus, I will overbear your will.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If we’d fought like this before, we’d have driven them home with bandaged heads.
target: Had we done so at first, we had droven them home With clouts about their heads.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good Lord!
target: Good Lord!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I say he shall go to prison.
target: I say he shall go to prison.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Old Montague is here, and he’s waving his sword around just to make me mad.
target: Old Montague is come, And flourishes his blade in spite of me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wouldn’t have dared!
target: I durst not!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Keep your word.
target: Keep thy word.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: These are frightening odds.
target: Tis a fearful odds.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you really mean that?
target: Sayest thou so?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is the plague of important men—our wives betray us more than those of poor men.
target: Yet ’tis the plague to great ones, Prerogatived are they less than the base.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then certain ones.
target: Certain ones, then.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes.
target: Ay.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: By my count, I was already your mother at just about your age, while you remain a virgin.
target: By my count, I was your mother much upon these years That you are now a maid.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Octavia has a pious, chaste, meek disposition.
target: Octavia is of a holy, cold, and still conversation.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If he seems game to our plan, encourage him to join us and explain all our reasons.
target: If thou dost find him tractable to us, Encourage him and show him all our reasons.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you sitting around in this humiliation to amuse yourself?
target: Makest thou this shame thy pastime?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You don’t need eyes to see how the world works.
target: A man may see how this world goes with no eyes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We all must die, Messala.
target: We must die, Messala.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll bury you in a magnificent grave.
target: I’ll bury thee in a triumphant grave.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Gregory, remember how to slash.
target: You know not what you do.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He will if he lives long enough to become a man.
target: He will, an if he live to be a man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ah, you’re here?—Come on, gentlemen, let’s go!
target: What, art thou come?—On, gentlemen, away!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How can you test them like that?
target: How canst thou try them so?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell her to come to me.
target: Call her forth to me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’d better understand that I won’t wait till I’m chained up in your master’s court, and I won’t let myself be scolded even once by dull Octavia.
target: Know, sir, that I Will not wait pinioned at your master’s court, Nor once be chastised with the sober eye Of dull Octavia.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My trusty servant, Ariel!
target: My industrious servant, Ariel!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He couldn’t be a lion if the Romans weren’t such easy prey.
target: He were no lion were not Romans hinds.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m afraid he will.
target: I fear he will.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I ordered that the sleeves be cut out and sewed up again, and I’ll prove it in combat even if your little finger is armed with your thimble.
target: I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and sewed up again, and that I’ll prove upon thee, though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This wicked son of mine confirms the prediction —son against father.
target: This villain of mine comes under the prediction—there’s son against father.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A gentleman.
target: A gentleman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you can love me for this, take me.
target: If thou canst love me for this, take me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Those who smile at it will soon be dead themselves.
target: They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I don’t get it—what’s the joke?
target: But what’s your jest?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It was just two days ago that I tripped you and beat you up in front of the king.
target: Is it two days ago since I tripped up thy heels and beat thee before the king?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good Mr. Peaseblossom, I’d like to get to know you better too.—And you, may I ask what your name is, sir?
target: Good Master Peaseblossom, I shall desire you of more acquaintance too.— Your name, I beseech you, sir?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t run away.
target: I cannot fly, But, bearlike, I must fight the course.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t say anything bad about wine anymore.
target: Exclaim no more against it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you close the doors on a woman’s wit, it’ll fly out the window.
target: Make the doors upon a woman’s wit, and it will out at the casement.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, girl, you’re weeping not for his death as much as for the fact that the villain who killed him is still alive.
target: Well, girl, thou weep’st not so much for his death, As that the villain lives which slaughtered him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s up, daughter and niece?
target: How now, daughter and cousin?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A fair woman!
target: A fair woman!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: From soldiers.
target: In the wars.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If there are any, speak, for it is he whom I have offended.
target: If any, speak—for him have I offended.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s better to act virtuously rather than vengefully.
target: The rarer action is In virtue than in vengeance.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The laws of Venice state that if a foreign resident directly or indirectly attempts to kill any citizen, the person he tried to kill will receive one half of the foreigner’s goods.
target: It is enacted in the laws of Venice, If it be proved against an alien That by direct or indirect attempts He seek the life of any citizen, The party 'gainst the which he doth contrive Shall seize one half his goods.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wait, sweet Beatrice.
target: Tarry, sweet Beatrice.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When she cries, all the little flowers cry too.
target: And when she weeps, weeps every little flower, Lamenting some enforcèd chastity.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Speak, my fair one, and speak fairly, I beg you.
target: Speak, my fair, and fairly, I pray thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What did he say?
target: To what effect?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Excellently, excellently.
target: Rarely, rarely.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Among the ten thousand the French have lost only sixteen hundred are mercenaries.
target: So that in these ten thousand they have lost, There are but sixteen hundred mercenaries.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where is he, in his bed?
target: Where is he, in his bed?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get to the point, since we already know the truth.
target: Be simple-answered, for we know the truth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The sister of my wife, this lady here, is married to your son.
target: The sister to my wife, this gentlewoman, Thy son by this hath married.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen to this.
target: Mark me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The street is narrow here.
target: Here the street is narrow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His messengers are waiting here to take me to him immediately, on pressing state business.
target: How may the Duke be therewith satisfied, Whose messengers are here about my side Upon some present business of the state To bring me to him?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All right, but first let the ambassadors speak.
target: Give first admittance to th' ambassadors.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My dear friends, thanks for your patience.
target: Sweet friends, your patience for my long abode.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, my lord.
target: Good my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I’m sure you don’t dislike him so much as to wish he were here alone, even though you say this to find out how the rest of us feel.
target: I dare say you love him not so ill to wish him here alone, howsoever you speak this to feel other men’s minds.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Of course he is, and so are you.
target: Yes, sooth, and so do you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But when you are with him, your angel is weakened and easily frightened.
target: But near him thy angel Becomes afeard, as being o’erpowered.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve looked at many ladies with pleasure, and been
target: Full many a lady I have eyed with best regard and many a time

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh my!
target: O me!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve got something for you.
target: I have a thing for you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He liked to call me a loan shark; let him think about his debt to me.
target: He was wont to call me usurer; let him look to his bond.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s hear someone play the triangle and the sticks.
target: Let’s have the tongs and the bones.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I told him what I thought.
target: I told him what I thought, and told no more Than what he found himself was apt and true.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Her curses have made my hair stand on end.
target: My hair doth stand an end to hear her curses.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can put him in the right mood, and I’ll bring him to the Capitol.
target: For I can give his humor the true bent, And I will bring him to the Capitol.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have to leave right away.
target: I must with haste from hence.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is it gone?
target: Is ’t gone?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You hear the charges.
target: You hear the suit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Down with the Montagues!
target: Down with the Montagues!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, I won’t stay a second longer.
target: No, faith, I’ll not stay a jot longer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m game.
target: I embrace it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It has been done already, and the messenger is on his way.
target: Tis done already, and the messenger gone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Today he fought as though he were a god who hated mankind.
target: He hath fought today As if a god, in hate of mankind, had Destroyed in such a shape.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Keep listening.
target: Hark further.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Anything I did to you, I did it because Sir Toby made me.
target: Od’s lifelings, here he is!—You broke my head for nothing, and that that I did, I was set on to do ’t by Sir Toby.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, thank God I’m cured!
target: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But if I am myself, then I know for sure that your weeping sister is not my wife.
target: But if that I am I, then well I know Your weeping sister is no wife of mine, Nor to her bed no homage do I owe.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s full of wise sayings and up-to-the-minute anecdotes: that’s the way he plays his part.
target: And then the justice, In fair round belly with good capon lined, With eyes severe and beard of formal cut, Full of wise saws and modern instances; And so he plays his part.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The rest of the king’s guests are already inside.
target: Then ’tis he: the rest That are within the note of expectation Already are i' th' court.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If not, then I have no powers of observation.
target: Or I have no observance.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you all crazy?
target: My masters, are you mad?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You killed my child.
target: Thou hast killed my child.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go back with her?
target: Return to her, and fifty men dismissed?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s subhuman, like an animal.
target: A hornèd man’s a monster and a beast.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, sir.
target: Ay, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our handwriting gives away our hearts.
target: Here’s our own hands against our hearts.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How tall is she?
target: What stature is she of?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You didn’t do anything else to earn this punishment?
target: Made you no more offense but what you speak of?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But if a man becomes weary of these obstacles, he can always kill himself.
target: But life, being weary of these worldly bars, Never lacks power to dismiss itself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: By next week, I’ll be able to pay you.
target: Come the next sabbath, and I will content you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Laertes, I want you to hear what they say.
target: Laertes, I must commune with your grief, Or you deny me right.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your eyes look threatening.
target: Your eyes do menace me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen.
target: Hark.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve made my choice.
target: I choose her for myself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s why it’s better for wise men to trumpet their own virtues, like I do.
target: Therefore is it most expedient for the wise, if Don Worm, his conscience, find no impediment to the contrary, to be the trumpet of his own virtues, as I am to myself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen but don’t speak to it.
target: Listen but speak not to ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now we wear the wreaths of victory on our heads.
target: Now is the winter of our discontent Made glorious summer by this son of York, And all the clouds that loured upon our house In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Transform your grief into anger.
target: Let grief Convert to anger.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please spare my innocent wife and children!—Kind warden, please stay with me for a while.
target: O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!— Keeper, I prithee sit by me awhile.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No wonder she’s waiting to get married.
target: No marvel though she pause; They can be meek that have no other cause.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The lack of time and the risk I’m under will have to keep us from bonding and catching up on each other’s news the way we usually would after not seeing each other for so long.
target: The leisure and the fearful time Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love And ample interchange of sweet discourse, Which so-long-sundered friends should dwell upon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Two of them are completely honorable, and if they have been tricked in this, we must blame John the Bastard, who lives to create conflict.
target: Two of them have the very bent of honor, And if their wisdoms be misled in this, The practice of it lives in John the Bastard, Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s conducting some business with my lady, and sooner or later he’ll leave.
target: He is now in some commerce with my lady and will by and by depart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Just a bit of my dry humor, sir.
target: A dry jest, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And so you do.
target: They know your Grace hath cause and means and might; So hath your Highness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He meant he did nothing right for me—which is true, unfortunately.
target: He meant he did me none; the more my spite.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Only children are afraid of scary pictures.
target: The sleeping and the dead Are but as pictures.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where’s America and the West Indies?
target: Where America, the Indies?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is beyond weird.
target: This is above all strangeness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who are you?
target: Wherefore art thou Romeo?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d hate to see you drowned in honey, sir.
target: I would be loath to have you overflown with a honey bag, signor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I took the kingdom from your sons, I’ll give it to your daughter to make up for it.
target: If I did take the kingdom from your sons, To make amends I’ll give it to your daughter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is the final discussion I will grant.
target: This is the latest parle we will admit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go relax now.
target: Go to your rest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Everyone can see that, and even blind men can smell the stench of his misery now.
target: All that follow their noses are led by their eyes but blind men, and there’s not a nose among twenty but can smell him that’s stinking.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m ready and waiting.—Give me your hand, Bassanio.
target: I am armed and well prepared.— Give me your hand, Bassanio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, Sir Andrew.
target: Approach, Sir Andrew.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stop, even if only to kill me.
target: Stay, though thou kill me, sweet Demetrius.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me go, gentlemen.
target: Still am I called.—Unhand me, gentlemen.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This play isn’t right for you.
target: It is not for you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, the leader of the team; the one that gets you if you can’t pay a debt; the one who assumes people are always going to bed and says to them, “Have arrest.” Well, sir, stop your joking there.
target: Ay, sir, the sergeant of the band; he that brings any man to answer it that breaks his band; one that thinks a man always going to bed and says “God give you good rest.”  Well, sir, there rest in your foolery.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I’ll linger.
target: But I will tarry.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Farewell, kind master.
target: Farewell, kind master.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If he says anything against me, I’ll humble him, even if he were stronger than he is—and twenty punks like him.
target: An he speak any thing against me, I’ll take him down, an he were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Everything about this is unnatural!
target: Thriftless ambition, that will raven up Thine own lives' means!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Many people have told me so.
target: I have been told so of many.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look!
target: Hark!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t believe it.
target: I’ll not believe ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Today shall always be remembered as a holy day.
target: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Excuse me, young man, how do I get to the Jew’s residence?
target: Master young man, you, I pray you, which is the way to Master Jew’s?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll go now to find out the date of the wedding.
target: I will presently go learn their day of marriage.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll drink it if I like.
target: I pray you, pardon me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good-bye!
target: Adieu, Lest our old robes sit easier than our new!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, madam, twenty different messengers.
target: Ay, madam, twenty several messengers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I look forward to getting to know you better, Mr. Mustardseed.
target: I desire you of more acquaintance, good Master Mustardseed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I want this to provoke confrontations, so I can give him a piece of my mind.
target: I would breed from hence occasions, and I shall, That I may speak.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Any news from Genoa?
target: What news from Genoa?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then it must be Banquo’s.
target: Tis Banquo’s then.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’re in.
target: We are resolved, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If there are any, speak, for it is he whom I’ve offended.
target: If any, speak—for him have I offended.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh friendly friar!
target: O comfortable Friar!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If this letter doesn’t make him fight, I don’t know what will.
target: If this letter move him not, his legs cannot.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Didn’t he come home last night?
target: Came he not home tonight?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But let it rain; I’ll survive.
target: Pour on, I will endure.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I would give all my glory for a mug of ale and safety.
target: I would give all my fame for a pot of ale, and safety.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And pay attention to what Caesar does and which men are close to him.
target: And take good note What Caesar doth, what suitors press to him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And even if you throw everything you possess to the two of them, they’ll battle each other to the death to have it all.
target: Then, world, thou hast a pair of chaps, no more, And throw between them all the food thou hast, They’ll grind the one the other.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish I were Sleep and Peace, so I could spend the night with you.
target: Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Everything’s fine.
target: Everything is well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can’t trust them.
target: There’s no composition in this news That gives them credit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll fight at sea.
target: I’ll fight at sea.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, my boy?
target: Why, my boy?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Because my name is George.
target: Because my name is George.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did you call me, my lord?
target: Called you, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Should we go see the sights in the town?
target: Shall we go see the relics of this town?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m not like you.
target: I am not of your element.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s the prize?
target: The wager?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, none that you’re smart enough to make.
target: No, none that thou hast wit enough to make.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s a common  What?
target: It is a common thing— Ha?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, such a life with such a wife is unlikely!
target: O sir, such a life with such a wife were strange!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re making fun of me.
target: You mock me, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You must all keep up this united front.
target: You peers, continue this united league.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We have to strike while the iron’s hot.
target: We must do something, and i' th' heat.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My strength is all gone, as if in a dream.
target: My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t let the Danish king’s bed be a nest of incest.
target: Let not the royal bed of Denmark be A couch for luxury and damnèd incest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The crowd that follows Caesar at his heels—senators, justices, common petitioners—will suffocate a feeble man almost to death.
target: The throng that follows Caesar at the heels, Of senators, of praetors, common suitors, Will crowd a feeble man almost to death.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They’ve eaten themselves sick.
target: The oats have eaten the horses.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, no, with God’s help, his son will be king.
target: No, no, by God’s good grace, his son shall reign.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What victory does he bring home?
target: What conquest brings he home?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thoughts work so quickly that even now you can imagine him on Blackheath, where his lords suggest that he should carry his battle-scarred sword and helmet on a procession through the city.
target: So swift a pace hath thought that even now You may imagine him upon Blackheath, Where that his lords desire him to have borne His bruisèd helmet and his bended sword Before him through the city.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our action will seem too bloody if we cut off Caesar’s head and then hack at his arms and legs too, Caius Cassius—because Mark Antony is merely one of Caesar’s arms.
target: Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius, To cut the head off and then hack the limbs, Like wrath in death and envy afterwards, For Antony is but a limb of Caesar.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And, moreover, God saw Benedick when he was hid in the garden.
target: And, moreover, God saw him when he was hid in the garden.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t want to dance.
target: I am not for this ambling.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If God had been willing, I wish we had died in the same hour too!
target: If the heavens had been pleased, would we had so ended!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Really?
target: Indeed?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh Margaret, Margaret, your heavy curse has now landed on poor Hastings’s miserable head!
target: O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll change that name for you.
target: Sir, my good friend, I’ll change that name with you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A big blast of wind shook our fortifications.
target: Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land, A fuller blast ne'er shook our battlements.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then let’s go in and hear what he has to say—though I think I can guess before the Frenchman has uttered a word.
target: Then go we in to know his embassy, Which I could with a ready guess declare Before the Frenchman speak a word of it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you sure of that?
target: Are you sure of that?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is it not enough, is it not enough, young man, that I’ll never be pretty enough to get a kind look from Demetrius?
target: Is ’t not enough, is ’t not enough, young man, That I did never, no, nor never can, Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius' eye, But you must flout my insufficiency?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Okay, now I’m dead.
target: Now am I dead.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s written you a letter.
target: Has here writ a letter to you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then my children will probably be illegitimate.
target: Then belike my children shall have no names.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will.
target: I shall do ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As sure as I’m standing here, I saw him.
target: If I stand here, I saw him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We are your servants, your highness, and as always our house and everything in it is at your disposal, for after all, we keep it in your trust and we’re glad to give you back what’s yours.
target: Your servants ever Have theirs, themselves, and what is theirs in compt, To make their audit at your highness' pleasure, Still to return your own.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Really, are you afraid of that?
target: Ay, do you fear it?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I can bear that pain, then I can bear my husband’s secrets.
target: Can I bear that with patience, And not my husband’s secrets?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When he raised his arm in command, the world trembled.
target: His reared arm Crested the world.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, I really think so.
target: Truly, I think they are.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go to my brother Cassius.
target: Go and commend me to my brother Cassius.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s just my bad luck.
target: It is my wretched fortune.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get me some ink, paper, and a candle.
target: Good fool, some ink, paper, and light, and convey what I will set down to my lady.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tie him up, I tell you.
target: Bind him, I say.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come, night.
target: Come, night.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As long as they didn’t do anything, it would only be a minor sin.
target: So they do nothing, ’tis a venial slip.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where are his eyes?
target: Where are his eyes?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll do what I can to make you even more comfortable.
target: I will piece out the comfort with what addition I can.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I had planned to celebrate it quietly, but since my lord is once more himself, I will be Cleopatra again.
target: I had thought t’ have held it poor; but since my lord Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ambition shouldn’t be so soft.
target: Ambition should be made of sterner stuff.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, he has only a little beard.
target: Nay, he hath but a little beard.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The only kind of tears you should shed in this case are the kind you might get from holding an onion to your nose.
target: Your old smock brings forth a new petticoat, and indeed the tears live in an onion that should water this sorrow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But the critics and I found it to be an excellent play, with well-ordered scenes that were clever but not fancy.
target: But it was—as I received it, and others, whose judgments in such matters cried in the top of mine—an excellent play, well digested in the scenes, set down with as much modesty as cunning.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can’t go any further with us, sir.
target: No further, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As it dissolves, so shall my life.
target: As it determines, so Dissolve my life!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A friend.
target: A friend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get yourself to a
target: Get thee to a nunnery.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll call it “Bottom’s Dream” because it’s so deep that it has no bottom.
target: It shall be called “Bottom’s Dream” because it hath no bottom.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ve got to act fast, my lord of the fairies.
target: My fairy lord, this must be done with haste.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tomorrow is the happy day, Audrey.
target: Tomorrow is the joyful day, Audrey.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, let it work.
target: Now let it work.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I am dying!—My lord, you still have one eye left to see Cornwall punished.
target: Oh, I am slain!—My lord, you have one eye left To see some mischief on him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I didn’t think you could even be so angry.
target: I did not think you could have been so angry.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can do whatever you want as long as it’s socially appropriate.
target: Even what it please my lord that shall become him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Does it really make sense, once we divide the world into three parts, that he should be one of the three rulers?
target: Is it fit, The threefold world divided, he should stand One of the three to share it?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have you returned smiling from the great battle for the world?
target: O infinite virtue, com’st thou smiling from The world’s great snare uncaught?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And I’ll tell him about the letter too.
target: This courtesy, forbid thee, shall the duke Instantly know, and of that letter too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For my part, I’m sorry this battle turned into a drinking match.
target: For my part, I am sorry it is turned to a drinking.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So have a seat and talk to her.
target: Sit then and talk with her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But if it is a sin to be selfish about honor, I am the most guilty soul alive.
target: But if it be a sin to covet honor, I am the most offending soul alive.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As for myself, I didn’t dare laugh, for fear of opening my lips and inhaling the stinking air.
target: And for mine own part, I durst not laugh for fear of opening my lips and receiving the bad air.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: To hell with this idiot!
target: The dropsy drown this fool!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Farewell, lady.
target: Fare thee well, dame.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Follow his chariot, like the greatest disgrace to your whole gender.
target: Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot Of all thy sex.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your mistress is a good mount.
target: Your mistress bears well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This treacherous Egyptian has betrayed me.
target: This foul Egyptian hath betrayèd me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, dear gods!
target: O the blessed gods!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I say you’re not.
target: I say you are not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who are these men?
target: What are these faces?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I swear, I don’t like the look of you.
target: I do not like thy look, I promise thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Keep my lover quiet.
target: Tie up my love’s tongue.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As I vowed, I will unite the York and Lancaster families.
target: And then, as we have ta'en the sacrament, We will unite the white rose and the red.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If they’d put you in the stocks for asking that question, you would’ve deserved it.
target: An thou hadst been set i' th' stocks for that question, thou’dst well deserved it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go to the gate.
target: Go to the gate.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She was here just now.
target: She was here even now.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And who can help thinking how monstrous it was for Malcolm and Donalbain to kill their gracious father?
target: Who cannot want the thought how monstrous It was for Malcolm and for Donalbain To kill their gracious father?

target: You can fool no more money out of me at this throw.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You are building your nest in
target: Urge neither charity nor shame to me.

target: But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart.

target: If thou art she, tell me where is that son That floated with thee on the fatal raft?

target: So I am free.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Think about the ones who have died.
target: Think upon these gone.

target: For I will make him tell the tale anew Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when He hath, and is again to cope your wife.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, help me, anyone who wants to live long!
target: He that will think to live till he be old, Give me some help!

target: O masters, if I were disposed to stir Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage, I should do Brutus wrong, and Cassius wrong— Who, you all know, are honorable men.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Find out what this villainous Edgar is thinking, Edmund.
target: Find out this villain, Edmund.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He couldn’t see you.
target: He sees thee not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Which he quickly allowed, given that you’re an obstacle to his lust.
target: Which soon he granted, Being an obstruct ’tween his lust and him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s my men who should call me “lord.” I’m your man, your fellow.
target: My men should call me “lord.” I am your goodman.

target: Therefore I say with noble Buckingham That it is meet so few should fetch the prince.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you Tyrrel?
target: Is thy name Tyrrel?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The count is neither sad nor sick nor cheerful nor well—he’s just civil, as Seville as an orange, with the same jealous-yellow complexion.
target: The Count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor well, but civil count, civil as an orange, and something of that jealous complexion.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sister, calm down.
target: Sister, have comfort.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish the fool were dead and married to her grave!
target: I would the fool were married to her grave!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, I’m half-blind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s got an answer for everything.

target: The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brother’s soul being in heaven.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All right, now I’m starting to lose my cool.
target: Now, by heaven, My blood begins my safer guides to rule, And passion, having my best judgment collied, Assays to lead the way.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You have the sacred power to cure both of us.
target: Both our remedies Within thy help and holy physic lies.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Until then, God be with you!
target: While then, God be with you!

target: Now my spirit is going.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wouldn’t allow any commerce.
target: For no kind of traffic Would I admit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m sorry about your daughter’s death, but I swear our accusations were true, and backed up with proof.
target: My heart is sorry for your daughter’s death, But, on my honor, she was charged with nothing But what was true and very full of proof.

target: As I discern, It burneth in the Capels' monument.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish I could see that man someday!
target: Would I might But ever see that man!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have it on me here.

target: Good fool, help me to some light and some paper.

target: Great Dunsinane he strongly fortifies.

target: Let me but bind it hard, within this hour It will be well.

target: Lysander, keep thy Hermia.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, you’re not on target there.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Swords don’t frighten me.
target: Thou liest, abhorrèd tyrant.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s your name?

target: By Jove that thunders!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me another horse!
target: Give me another horse!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’re glad to see you.
target: You are very well met.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let us prepare for our wedding.—On that day, I’ll take your oath of loyalty, my Lord of Burgundy and all my peers, to guarantee my treaty.
target: Prepare we for our marriage; on which day, My Lord of Burgundy, we’ll take your oath, And all the peers', for surety of our leagues.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’s only one hope for you, and even that’s a kind of illegitimate hope.
target: There is but one hope in it that can do you any good, and that is but a kind of bastard hope neither.

target: Thou told’st me Thou didst hold him in thy hate.

target: Ere he do leave this grove, Thou shalt fly him and he shall seek thy love.

target: Come, my spade.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Leave me alone.
target: Let me alone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get out, you horrible poison.
target: Out, loathèd medicine!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If a bloody head counts as a hurt, then you hurt me.

target: Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar?

target: It may be, these apparent prodigies, The unaccustomed terror of this night, And the persuasion of his augurers May hold him from the Capitol today.

target: Go then, find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the Count Claudio alone.

target: Therefore, when he sees reason of fears as we do, his fears, out of doubt, be of the same relish as ours are.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But a stronger pity, for the wrongs committed against Rome, drove out our pity for Caesar, as fire drives out fire, and so we killed him.
target: And pity to the general wrong of Rome— As fire drives out fire, so pity pity— Hath done this deed on Caesar.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you’ve got any music that can’t be heard, then play that.
target: If you have any music that may not be heard, to ’t again.

target: That’s one of them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I, who have never known how to beg and never had to beg, am starved for food, dizzy with lack of sleep, kept awake with curses and fed with brawling.
target: But I, who never knew how to entreat, Nor never needed that I should entreat, Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep, With oaths kept waking and with brawling fed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t let the heavens hear these chattery women abuse the Lord’s anointed king.
target: Let not the heavens hear these telltale women Rail on the Lord’s anointed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish we had a signed legal contract.
target: I would I had your bond, for I perceive A weak bond holds you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hello to you.

target: And look you get a prayer book in your hand And stand between two churchmen, good my lord, For on that ground I’ll make a holy descant.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If grief doesn’t kill me, I’ll find a quicker way to kill myself—even though I think grief will do the job just as well.
target: If swift thought break it not, a swifter mean Shall outstrike thought, but thought will do ’t, I feel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes.
target: Ay, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I am willing to fight you if I must.
target: If you did wear a beard upon your chin, I’d shake it on this quarrel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Heaven wanted Rosalind to have these gifts And me to live and die as her slave.
target: Heaven would that she these gifts should have And I to live and die her slave.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But don’t expect any more than that.
target: But do not look for further recompense Than thine own gladness that thou art employed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, Casca, you and I will go see Brutus at his house before sunrise.
target: Come, Casca, you and I will yet ere day See Brutus at his house.

target: I am loath to tell you what I would you knew.

target: No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Didn’t you talk to it?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll be married tomorrow.
target: Tomorrow will we be married.

target: No more a soldier.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ah, the countess is coming!
target: Here comes the Countess.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on.
target: Come on.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I come back from the battlefield again to kiss those lips, I’ll be covered in blood.
target: If from the field I shall return once more To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But now, I tell you—keep it to yourself, though—those enemies of mine are being put to death today, and I’m better than I’ve ever been.
target: But now, I tell thee—keep it to thyself— This day those enemies are put to death, And I in better state than e'er I was.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Rogue, you’ve lived too long!
target: Rogue, thou hast lived too long.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Of all the strange things I’ve ever heard, it seems most strange to me that men fear death, given that death, which can’t be avoided, will come whenever it wants.
target: Of all the wonders that I yet have heard, It seems to me most strange that men should fear, Seeing that death, a necessary end, Will come when it will come.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: May good luck follow you!
target: Fortune pursue thee!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You mean you don’t even want to hear my side?
target: What, will you not suffer me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did Cicero say anything?
target: Did Cicero say anything?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s an odd thing to say.
target: Thou art a strange fellow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s the matter with you, madam?
target: What mean you, madam?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve lost my name and title to a traitor.
target: O, know, my name is lost.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God will free you from blame.
target: Heaven make thee free of it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh angels, protect us!
target: Angels and ministers of grace defend us!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Not very well, but I’ve met him several times.
target: Not very well, but I have met him oft, And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds That the old carlot once was master of.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But when we have an hour to spare we can talk more about it, if you’re willing.
target: Yet, when we can entreat an hour to serve, We would spend it in some words upon that business, If you would grant the time.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And that’s what you want me to do!
target: And that you would have me to do!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stay in your cabins.
target: Keep your cabins.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I forgot about the reward.
target: I had forgot the reward.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why don’t you answer me, man?
target: Wilt thou not answer, man?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me my fishing rod.
target: Give me mine angle.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is this your idea of success?
target: Is this your speeding?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have my naked sword out.
target: My naked weapon is out.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But what about the bloody handkerchief?
target: But for the bloody napkin?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I sent for Cassio to come talk with you.
target: I have sent to bid Cassio come speak with you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You devil, you’ve put a spell on her!
target: Damned as thou art, thou hast enchanted her!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Put on your nightgown, in case someone comes and sees that we’re awake.
target: Get on your nightgown, lest occasion call us And show us to be watchers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s your name, please, friend?
target: Your name, I pray you, friend?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have him come to me here, soldier.
target: Call him hither to me, soldier.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And yet you say that exile is not death?
target: And sayst thou yet that exile is not death?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our closest relatives are the ones most likely to murder us.
target: The near in blood, The nearer bloody.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Maybe, but you’re wrinkled all the same.
target: Yet you are withered.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll be back here with you by two o'clock.
target: By two o'clock I will be with thee again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What are you  Nothing.
target: Nothing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When you free your children from the sword, your grandchildren will repay you in your old age.
target: If you do free your children from the sword, Your children’s children quits it in your age.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who wishes that?
target: What’s he that wishes so?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Everything would be produced without labor, and would be shared by all.
target: All things in common nature should produce Without sweat or endeavor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re lying, you shaggy-haired villain!
target: Thou liest, thou shag-haired villain!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If it pleases your Majesty, let his neck pay the price, if there is any martial law in the world.
target: An please your Majesty, let his neck answer for it, if there is any martial law in the world.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If your vengeful heart can’t forgive me, here—take my sword and bury it in my heart so that my soul, which adores you, can be free.
target: If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive, Lo, here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword, Which if thou please to hide in this true breast And let the soul forth that adoreth thee, I lay it naked to the deadly stroke And humbly beg the death upon my knee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go away and take your children.
target: Hence with your little ones.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Antonio, I married a woman as dear to me as life itself.
target: Antonio, I am married to a wife Which is as dear to me as life itself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My brother, your uncle Antonio—just listen to this (I still can’t believe a brother could be so disloyal!
target: My brother and thy uncle, called Antonio— I pray thee, mark me (that a brother should Be so perfidious!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So you had time as you were dying to look around?
target: Had you such leisure in the time of death To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go on, get out of here.
target: Go, go.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I’m ashamed to kiss, sir.
target: No, sir, God forbid, but ashamed to kiss.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But, sir— Why should you do this, you want to know?
target: But, my good lord— Wherefore should you do this?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now go, and hurry back.
target: Get you gone And hasten your return.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why should people like me be crawling around between earth and heaven?
target: What should such fellows as I do crawling between earth and heaven?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I never saw you before in my life.
target: I never saw you in my life till now.

target: My Lord of Warwick, here is, praised be God for it, a most contagious treason come to light, look you, as you shall desire in a summer’s day.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes.
target: Ay.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I myself am playing the man in the moon— Well then, that’s the biggest mistake of all.

target: It was in place where I could not breed no contention with him, but I will be so bold as to wear it in my cap till I see him once again, and then I will tell him a little piece of my desires.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My own safety is the only important thing now.

target: Rebellious dead, rise never till the wood Of Birnam rise, and our high-placed Macbeth Shall live the lease of nature, pay his breath To time and mortal custom.

target: Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain, As in revenge, have sucked up from the sea Contagious fogs, which falling in the land Have every pelting river made so proud That they have overborne their continents.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I repeated it to you, it would kill you as soon as you heard it.
target: O gentle lady, 'Tis not for you to hear what I can speak: The repetition, in a woman’s ear, Would murder as it fell.

target: Alas, poor Romeo!

target: I pray you, then, in love and dear alliance, Let that one article rank with the rest, And thereupon give me your daughter.

target: Enobarbus, welcome.

target: The greater part, the horse in general, Are come with Cassius.

target: If you be gentlemen, Do me this right: hear me with patience.

target: Where is the number of our English dead?

target: Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the king’s fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How did you tolerate prison?
target: How hath your lordship brooked imprisonment?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: After all, who would put up with all life’s humiliations—the abuse from superiors, the insults of arrogant men, the pangs of unrequited love, the inefficiency of the legal system, the rudeness of people in office, and the mistreatment good people have to take from bad—when you could simply take out your knife and call it quits?
target: For who would bear the whips and scorns of time, Th' oppressor’s wrong, the proud man’s contumely, The pangs of despised love, the law’s delay, The insolence of office, and the spurns That patient merit of th' unworthy takes, When he himself might his quietus make With a bare bodkin?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How can you ever hope for mercy for yourself, when you don’t give any now?
target: How shalt thou hope for mercy, rendering none?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, how stupid!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But before we reached the end point, Caesar cried, “Help me, Cassius, or I will sink!” And just as Aeneas, the hero who founded Rome, emerged from the fires of Troy with his elderly father Anchises on his shoulder, so I emerged from the Tiber carrying the tired Caesar.
target: But ere we could arrive the point proposed, Caesar cried, “Help me, Cassius, or I sink!” I, as Aeneas, our great ancestor, Did from the flames of Troy upon his shoulder The old Anchises bear, so from the waves of Tiber Did I the tired Caesar.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll have a couch made up that’s softer and more fragrant even than the bed of lustful
target: We’ll have thee to a couch Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed On purpose trimmed up for Semiramis.

target: No, my lord, unless I might have another for working days.
