source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’re strangers here.
target: We being strangers here, how dar’st thou trust So great a charge from thine own custody?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can.
target: That can I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So, thank God, there is no real need for me, as I wouldn’t be able to help you much.
target: But, God be thanked, there is no need of me, And much I need to help you, were there need.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But why aren’t you in your shop today?
target: But wherefore art not in thy shop today?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You were never with me for anything if you weren’t there for the goose.
target: Thou wast never with me for anything when thou wast not there for the goose.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Because you’re like the lowborn fellow who strikes the bell—you keep interrupting my thoughts.
target: Because that, like a jack, thou keep’st the stroke Betwixt thy begging and my meditation.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So I guess it’s you, you silver treasure house.
target: Why then, to thee, thou silver treasure house.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Gracious Lord, blunt the swords of those traitors who mean to tear poor England apart again!
target: Abate the edge of traitors, gracious Lord, That would reduce these bloody days again, And make poor England weep in streams of blood!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, if you could have just an inch of better fortune than me, where would you like the improvement?
target: Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better than I, where would you choose it?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stand aside, Captain Gower.
target: Stand away, Captain Gower.

target: Go shake your ears!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I could do it easily now.
target: Now might I do it pat.

target: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!

target: Thus I let you go And give you to the gods.

target: And what other oath Than honesty to honesty engaged, That this shall be, or we will fall for it?

target: One thing more rests, that thyself execute, to make one among these wooers.

target: The mariners all under hatches stowed, Who, with a charm joined to their suffered labor, I have left asleep.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then I’ll listen to her.
target: This if she perform, She shall not sue unheard.

target: I pray thee, let us go and find him out And quicken his embracèd heaviness With some delight or other.

target: Ay, do.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye, Jessica.
target: Fare you well, Jessica.

target: If the matter were good, my lord, I durst swear it were his.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll have to tell the story again every month, since you seem to forget it.
target: I must Once in a month recount what thou hast been, Which thou forget’st.

target: Come, good fellow, put thine iron on.

target: I do remember in this shepherd boy Some lively touches of my daughter’s favor.

target: I am content you shall entreat me stay, But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.

target: Twenty crowns.

target: Nay, you were better speak first, and when you were graveled for lack of matter, you might take occasion to kiss.

target: Come, father, I’ll bestow you with a friend.

target: Within a month, Ere yet the salt of most unrighteous tears Had left the flushing in her gallèd eyes, She married.

target: Nay, come, Kate, come.

target: How sweet is love itself possessed When but love’s shadows are so rich in joy!

target: Sweet Phoebe, pity me.

target: Truly, young gentlemen, though there was no great matter in the ditty, yet the note was very untunable.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They’re such oversexed gluttons that I feel like we’re living in a pub or a whorehouse rather than a respectable palace.
target: Epicurism and lust Make it more like a tavern or a brothel Than a graced palace.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s time for you to know the whole story.
target: Tis time I should inform thee farther.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Not really, unless you were ugly.
target: No, truly, unless thou wert hard-favored, for honesty coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And if we don’t shake hands, when I act all nice to the players it will seem like I’m happier to see them than you.
target: Let me comply with you in this garb—lest my extent to the players, which, I tell you, must show fairly outwards, should more appear like entertainment than yours.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Revenge.
target: Revenge.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: With this I avoid the grief of Antony’s death.
target: Thus I do escape the sorrow Of Antony’s death.

target: If there were no more women but Fulvia, then had you indeed a cut, and the case to be lamented.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish you’d be patient.
target: I wish, forbear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good and noble young man, don’t mess with someone who’s desperate.
target: Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goddammit!
target: God’s bread!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My husband is alive on earth, my vows of marriage are in heaven.
target: My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven.

target: Take heed of Cassius.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: With no more ceremony than that?
target: What, no more ceremony?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If your master wants a queen to beg from him, you should tell him that a queen will beg for no less than a kingdom.
target: If your master Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him, That majesty, to keep decorum, must No less beg than a kingdom.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll go wait for Dromio at the marketplace.
target: I’ll to the mart, and there for Dromio stay.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Everything’s OK.
target: All’s well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Before she began shedding tears all over her lovely face, she was the fairest creature in the world—and even now she has no equal.
target: And till the tears that she hath shed for thee Like envious floods o'errun her lovely face, She was the fairest creature in the world— And yet she is inferior to none.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your sister’s sister.
target: Thy sister’s sister.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s go!
target: Away!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s in there?
target: Who’s within?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve had very little joy as England’s queen.
target: Small joy have I in being England’s queen.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here’s some money for you.
target: Spend this for me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The smell of leek turns my stomach.
target: I am qualmish at the smell of leek.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s me.
target: The same.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The sun glints off our armor.
target: The sun doth gild our armor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, first of all, my horse is tired and my master and mistress have had a falling out.
target: First, know my horse is tired, my master and mistress fallen out.

target: Honest Nurse, farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It wouldn’t let my soul find its way to air but smothered it inside my gasping body.
target: Methought I had, and often did I strive To yield the ghost, but still the envious flood Stopped in my soul and would not let it forth To find the empty, vast, and wand'ring air, But smothered it within my panting bulk, Who almost burst to belch it in the sea.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But you’re lying out in the cold.
target: Yet thou liest in the bleak air.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: make your eyes jump out of their sockets, and your hair stand on end like porcupine quills.
target: Make thy two eyes, like stars, start from their spheres, Thy knotted and combinèd locks to part And each particular hair to stand on end, Like quills upon the fearful porpentine.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me have your attention for a moment.
target: Let me have audience for a word or two.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who are you, slave?
target: What art thou, fellow?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, Nerissa, I have many things to do that you don’t even know about yet.
target: Come on, Nerissa, I have work in hand That you yet know not of.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The general should be informed about this.
target: It were well The general were put in mind of it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your renowned uncle, Duke Menaphon, the famous soldier, brought me here.
target: Brought to this town by that most famous warrior Duke Menaphon, your most renownèd uncle.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now let the wind blow, waves swell, and ships sink!
target: Why, now, blow wind, swell billow, and swim bark!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Katherina, you may stay.
target: And so farewell.—Katherina, you may stay, For I have more to commune with Bianca.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s nine o'clock!
target: Tis nine o'clock.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And
target: So shall you quietly enjoy your hope And marry sweet Bianca with consent.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So give me your answer, and we’ll shake on it.
target: Give me your answer, i' faith, do; and so clap hands and a bargain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s somewhere between boy and man.
target: Tis with him in standing water, between boy and man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His mistake was hardly worth punishing him for in the first place—though in wartime it is sometimes necessary to make examples out of even the best soldiers.
target: In faith, he’s penitent, And yet his trespass, in our common reason (Save that, they say, the wars must make example Out of her best) is not, almost, a fault T' incur a private check.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Therefore my sadness is without limit.
target: Therefore the sadness is without limit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He only married out of political necessity.
target: He married but his occasion here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s been in an unusually good mood and has granted many gifts to your household and servants.
target: He hath been in unusual pleasure, and Sent forth great largess to your offices.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How do you feel, Laertes?
target: How is ’t, Laertes?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You won’t enjoy it much, I can tell you, the odds are so against this young man.
target: You will take little delight in it, I can tell you, there is such odds in the man.

target: Have you had quiet guard?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d rather break my own heart.
target: I had rather break mine own.

target: Now are we well prepared to know the pleasure Of our fair cousin Dauphin, for we hear Your greeting is from him, not from the king.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: who can control his fate?
target: Who can control his fate?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I could go around the world in forty minutes.
target: I’ll put a girdle round about the Earth In forty minutes.

target: So white, and such a traitor?

target: I’ll to the throng.

target: The elements be kind to thee and make Thy spirits all of comfort!

target: Let floods o'erswell and fiends for food howl on!

target: Look, here comes a walking fire.

target: Do you put tricks upon ’s with savages and men of Ind, ha?

target: I would lose all—ay, sacrifice them all Here to this devil—to deliver you.

target: Will you enforce me to a world of cares?

target: Dispatch, I say, and find the forester.

target: The terms of our estate may not endure Hazard so dangerous as doth hourly grow Out of his lunacies.

target: News, lads, Our wars are done!

target: His captain’s heart, Which in the scuffles of great fights hath burst The buckles on his breast, reneges all temper And is become the bellows and the fan To cool a gypsy’s lust.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hearts cannot think it, tongues cannot speak it, meas-urements cannot calculate it, scribes cannot write it, bards cannot sing it, and poets cannot make verses about it.
target: Hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number—hoo!— His love to Antony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me stand here until you remember your reason.
target: Let me stand here till thou remember it.

target: And for I know she taketh most delight In music, instruments, and poetry, Schoolmasters will I keep within my house, Fit to instruct her youth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: May the gods bless Antony today!
target: The gods make this a happy day to Antony!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, I’m nearly finished.
target: Well, I have done.

target: She was too fond of her most filthy bargain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s most appropriate.

target: Spakest thou of Juliet?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We beg you, for your own sake, to respect your safety and give up.
target: We pray you for your own sake to embrace your own safety and give over this attempt.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In a fit of rage she locked you up in a hollow pine tree, with the help of her powerful assistants, and left you there for twelve years.
target: And, for thou wast a spirit too delicate To act her earthy and abhorred commands, Refusing her grand hests, she did confine thee, By help of her more potent ministers And in her most unmitigable rage, Into a cloven pine, within which rift Imprisoned thou didst painfully remain A dozen years; within which space she died And left thee there, where thou didst vent thy groans As fast as mill wheels strike.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My wife and I ordered him to hang Cordelia in prison and then to make it look as if she committed suicide in despair.
target: He hath commission from thy wife and me To hang Cordelia in the prison and To lay the blame upon her own despair, That she fordid herself.

target: Now sits the wind fair, and we will aboard.

target: I pray you, let me look upon the bond.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, and you dared Caesar to fight the battle at Pharsalia, where he fought against Pompey.
target: Ay, and to wage this battle at Pharsalia, Where Caesar fought with Pompey.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Read the time there.
target: Tell the clock there.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And if you treat us badly, won’t we try to get revenge?
target: And if you wrong us, shall we not revenge?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If not, I’ll challenge you to a duel.
target: If not, assure yourself I will seek satisfaction of you.

target: Fare you well.

target: Portia, art thou gone?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Call Cleopatra what the Romans call her.
target: Name Cleopatra as she is called in Rome.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listening to their frightened voices, I couldn’t reply “Amen” when they said “God bless us!” Don’t think about it so much.
target: List'ning their fear I could not say “Amen,” When they did say “God bless us!” Consider it not so deeply.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, lying woman!
target: O perjured woman!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s very moral.
target: She’s full of most blessed condition.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Show him and make him grieve.
target: Show his eyes and grieve his heart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now you know the reason for the rush.
target: Now do you know the reason of this haste.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, you’ll have to excuse me.
target: No, you shall pardon me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, blessed, blessed night!
target: O blessèd, blessèd night!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He says more in one minute than he does in a whole month.
target: A gentleman, Nurse, that loves to hear himself talk, and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to in a month.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, Antony, don’t beg us to kill you.
target: O Antony, beg not your death of us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodnight, Michael.
target: Michael, good night.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Agree to swear.
target: Consent to swear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They haven’t been commanded to go to the west, mighty king.
target: They have not been commanded, mighty king.

target: I say I will make him eat some part of my leek, or I will peat his pate four days.—Bite, I pray you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, you’re speaking very well.
target: Excellent well!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ready.
target: Ready.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bianca’s love made me trade places with Tranio while he masqueraded as me around town.
target: Bianca’s love Made me exchange my state with Tranio, While he did bear my countenance in the town, And happily I have arrivèd at the last Unto the wishèd haven of my bliss.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you get what you want and you’re still not happy, you’ve spent everything and gained nothing.
target: Naught’s had, all’s spent, Where our desire is got without content.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His feelings don’t move in that direction.
target: His affections do not that way tend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is pure insanity.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t have to give you answers that you like.
target: I am not bound to please thee with my answers.

target: Thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But did you tell him she cheated on him?
target: But did you ever tell him she was false?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How did you know what happened to your poor father?
target: How have you known the miseries of your father?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll ask him for my position back again, and he’ll tell me I’m a drunk.
target: I will ask him for my place again, he shall tell me I am a drunkard.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They eat too much and get indigestion and nausea.
target: They lack retention.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But please forgive me, darling, for the sake of the vows we made to each other so recently.
target: Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows We made each other but so late ago.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This isn’t a monster, it’s a devil.
target: This is a devil, and no monster.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What a day this is!

target: Come, tailor, let us see these ornaments.

target: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more Than you have heard him brag to you he will.

target: But your news is not true.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then heaven have mercy on me.
target: Then heaven Have mercy on me!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In exchange for the blood I shed for you then, I ask you for justice now.
target: Even for the blood That then I lost for thee, now grant me justice.

target: But there’s a saying very old and true: “If that you will France win, Then with Scotland first begin.” For once the eagle England being in prey, To her unguarded nest the weasel Scot Comes sneaking and so sucks her princely eggs, Playing the mouse in absence of the cat, To ’tame and havoc more than she can eat.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish I could repay this happy news with good news of my own.

target: If there come truth from them— As upon thee, Macbeth, their speeches shine— Why, by the verities on thee made good, May they not be my oracles as well, And set me up in hope?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And that would get us all executed.
target: And that were enough to hang us all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We must form a better opinion of ourselves if our uprising can pull the insatiable Antony’s attention away from that Egyptian widow.
target: But let us rear The higher our opinion, that our stirring Can from the lap of Egypt’s widow pluck The ne’er lust-wearied Antony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, I’m sure he’s dead.

target: But, sir, such wanton, wild, and usual slips

target: Young men’s love then lies Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.

target: If thou say so, villain, Thou kill’st thy mistress.

target: Her waspish-headed son has broke his arrows, Swears he will shoot no more, but play with sparrows And be a boy right out.

target: Tybalt is dead, and Romeo banishèd.”

target: Oh, that’s a brave man.

target: Roderigo!

target: Then God be blessed, it is the blessèd sun.

target: My lord, I claim the gift, my due by promise, For which your honor and your faith is pawned— Th' earldom of Hereford and the movables Which you promisèd I shall possess.

target: O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.

target: Of lusty earls: Grandpré and Roussi, Faulconbridge and Foix, Beaumont and Marle, Vaudemont and Lestrale.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go!
target: Avaunt, you cullions!

target: And, honest company, I thank you all, That have beheld me give away myself To this most patient, sweet and virtuous wife.

target: That it would please you leave these sad designs To him that hath more cause to be a mourner, And presently repair to Crosby House, Where, after I have solemnly interred At Chertsey monast'ry this noble king And wet his grave with my repentant tears, I will with all expedient duty see you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good.

target: Should be”—should buzz!

target: They are all but stomachs, and we all but food.

target: Since the youth will not be entreated, his own peril on his forwardness.

target: Take in your love, and then let me alone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you know him?
target: Know you him?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m wide awake.
target: My spirits are nimble.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here he comes, my lord.
target: He comes, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The tunnels!
target: To the mines?

target: I will not leave him now till Cassio Be called to him.—How is ’t with you, my lord?

target: Tis he that sends us to destroy you here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ratcliffe!
target: Ratcliffe!

target: Did you ever cure any so?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you weren’t my brother, I’d leave this hand of mine on your neck until I’d pulled out your tongue for talking like this.
target: Wert thou not my brother, I would not take this hand from thy throat till this other had pulled out thy tongue for saying so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This will make our actions seem practical and not vengeful.
target: This shall make Our purpose necessary and not envious, Which so appearing to the common eyes, We shall be called purgers, not murderers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you really think there’s a man fool enough to marry into hell—however rich the father is?
target: Think’st thou, Hortensio, though her father be very rich, any man is so very a fool to be married to hell?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let everyone beware: I can shake off the tyranny that now oppresses me whenever I choose.
target: If I know this, know all the world besides, That part of tyranny that I do bear I can shake off at pleasure.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And you can do poor things that lead to rich results.
target: And most poor matters Point to rich ends.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Alas, I hate myself instead, because of the hateful deeds I’ve committed.
target: Alas, I rather hate myself For hateful deeds committed by myself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bring in more wine!
target: Some wine, ho!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Me too, lieutenant.
target: And so do I too, lieutenant.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s beautiful, if my eyes can see.
target: And fair she is, if that mine eyes be true.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s follow him.
target: Come away.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here it is, I think.
target: Here it is, I think.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: By God, I am not selfish when it comes to money: I don’t care who eats at my expense.
target: By Jove, I am not covetous for gold Nor care I who doth feed upon my cost; It yearns me not if men my garments wear; Such outward things dwell not in my desires.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m sure it is to knight you, Captain.
target: I warrant it is to knight you, Captain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hermia is lucky, wherever she is, because she has beautiful eyes.
target: Happy is Hermia, wheresoe'er she lies, For she hath blessèd and attractive eyes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get rid of your low-class trapping,” she said.
target: Cast thy humble slough,” says she.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I hate looking at his face now!
target: Oh, how mine eyes do loathe his visage now!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How late is it, lords?
target: How far into the morning is it, lords?

target: The ox hath therefore stretched his yoke in vain, The ploughman lost his sweat, and the green corn Hath rotted ere his youth attained a beard.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He plans to leave tomorrow.
target: Tomorrow, as he purposes.

target: With whom?

target: Brutus killed me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When this wood burns, it’ll weep for making you tired.
target: When this burns, 'Twill weep for having wearied you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Would I ever deny you anything?
target: Shall I deny you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Iago is gesturing for me to come closer.
target: Iago beckons me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, sir, they’re ready.
target: Ay, sir, they be ready.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s the matter?
target: What’s the matter?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If he’s nearby, I want an explanation.
target: But if he be at hand I shall be satisfied.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Therefore, great king, we surrender our town and lives to your kind mercy.
target: Therefore, great King, We yield our town and lives to thy soft mercy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And he’s rubbed himself with perfume.
target: Nay, he rubs himself with civet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Cousin, you didn’t used to be so thickheaded.
target: Cousin, thou wast not wont to be so dull.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t see ahead of me.
target: Night hangs upon mine eyes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He died like someone who had practiced how to toss away his most cherished possession as if it were a worthless a piece of garbage.
target: He died As one that had been studied in his death To throw away the dearest thing he owed As ’twere a careless trifle.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, follow straight after me.
target: I beseech you, follow straight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wicked woman, these white hairs you’re pulling off my chin will come to life and accuse you of wrong-doing.
target: Naughty lady, These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin Will quicken and accuse thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you dressed only to stay warm, you wouldn’t need these gorgeous clothes you’re wearing—which don’t keep you warm at all.
target: If only to go warm were gorgeous, Why, nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear’st, Which scarcely keeps thee warm.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Kind Tyrrel, will your news make me happy?
target: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll be nearby.
target: I’ll not be far from you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But if you didn’t know about it, then you were wrong to get mad at us.

target: Then bid adieu to me, and say the tears Belong to Egypt.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A woman who was beautiful but never proud, who could speak well but knew when to be quiet, who dressed well but was never overdressed, who had self-restraint even when she could get what she wanted, a woman who never took revenge, who overlooked it when people hurt her, who was too wise to do anything stupid, who could think without revealing her thoughts, and who could refrain from flirting with men in love with her, that kind of woman, if she ever existed, would— Would do what?
target: She that was ever fair and never proud, Had tongue at will and yet was never loud, Never lacked gold and yet went never gay, Fled from her wish and yet said “Now I may,” She that being angered, her revenge being nigh, Bade her wrong stay and her displeasure fly, She that in wisdom never was so frail To change the cod’s head for the salmon’s tail, She that could think and ne'er disclose her mind, See suitors following and not look behind, She was a wight, if ever such wights were— To do what?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is a classic example of the idiocy of the world: when we’re down and out—often because of our own excesses —we put all the blame on the sun, the moon, and the stars, as if they forced us to be bad, or the heavens compelled us to be villainous or stupid.
target: This is the excellent foppery of the world that when we are sick in fortune—often the surfeit of our own behavior—we make guilty of our disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars, as if we were villains by necessity, fools by heavenly compulsion, knaves, thieves, and treachers by spherical predominance, drunkards, liars, and adulterers by an enforced obedience of planetary influence, and all that we are evil in by a divine thrusting-on.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: True,” she said, “a fine little one.” “No,” I said, “a huge wit.” “Right,” she said, “a hugely awful one.” “No,” I said, “he has a good wit.” “Exactly,” she said, “it’s good and mild; it doesn’t hurt anyone.” “No,” I said, “Benedick is wise.” “He is certainly,” she said,  She cried a lot at that, and said she didn’t care.
target: True,” said she, “a fine little one.” “No,” said I, “a great wit.” “Right,” says she, “a great gross one.” “Nay,” said I, “a good wit.” “Just,” said she, “it hurts nobody.” “Nay,” said I, “the gentleman is wise.” “Certain,” said she, “a wise gentleman.” “Nay,” said I, “he hath the tongues.” “That I believe,” said she, “for he swore a thing to me on Monday night, which he forswore on Tuesday morning; there’s a double tongue, there’s two tongues.” Thus did she an hour together transshape thy particular virtues.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: These young children cry for Clarence and so do I, though they don’t cry for Edward, as I do.
target: These babes for Clarence weep and so do I; I for an Edward weep; so do not they.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell her that the king, who has the power to command people, asks her.
target: Tell her the king, that may command, entreats— That, at her hands, which the king’s King forbids.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And Cassio’s killed?
target: And Cassio killed!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I want to do a little good despite my evil nature.
target: Some good I mean to do Despite of mine own nature.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They did want me to tell her, but I persuaded them that, if they truly loved Benedick, they would try to get him to battle his emotions and keep Beatrice in the dark.
target: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it, But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick, To wish him wrestle with affection And never to let Beatrice know of it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You lie.
target: You lie.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sometimes she tickles a priest’s nose with a  Enough, enough!
target: And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig’s tail Tickling a parson’s nose as he lies asleep, Then he dreams of another benefice.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We, now at our largest, can only decrease.
target: We, at the height, are ready to decline.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But if I really laid him bare, I’d have to weep and hang my head, and you would not believe me, his behavior is so shocking.
target: I speak but brotherly of him, but should I anatomize him to thee as he is, I must blush and weep, and thou must look pale and wonder.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Examine them yourselves, then bring me your findings.
target: Take their examination yourself and bring it me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How is my generous sister?
target: How does my bounteous sister?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is exactly the false way that verses gallop along.
target: This is the very false gallop of verses.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I was not angry since I came to France until this instant.
target: I was not angry since I came to France Until this instant.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No one except her maid and a holy hermit.
target: None but a holy hermit and her maid.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Romeo, get out of here.
target: Romeo, away, be gone!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shame on you—get on board!
target: Aboard, aboard, for shame!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, that’s what you get to do.
target: Why then, thou hast it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, he told me so himself, and he said he didn’t care who knew it.
target: Marry, he told me so himself; and he said he cared not who knew it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I told him to knock at your gate and for the life of me could not get him to do it.
target: I bade the rascal knock upon your gate And could not get him for my heart to do it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, horror, horror, horror!
target: O horror, horror, horror!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My name is Hortensio, sir.
target: Know, sir, that I am called Hortensio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here, stand behind this wall; he’ll come right away.
target: Here, stand behind this bulk, straight will he come.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That was one hit.
target: One.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, well, well.
target: Well, well, well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Miserable England, I foresee for you the most frightening time you have ever experienced.—Come, lead me to the block.
target: Miserable England, I prophesy the fearfull’st time to thee That ever wretched age hath looked upon.— Come, lead me to the block.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t say anything.
target: Speak not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s noble Kent, your friend.
target: Tis noble Kent, your friend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me comfort.
target: Comfort me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hate it and want all good men’s love.
target: Tis death to me to be at enmity; I hate it, and desire all good men’s love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Whoever is already married (except one person I know) will stay married—all but one person.
target: Those that are married already, all but one, shall live.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Make your confession short.
target: Make a short shrift.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t you care about me?
target: Hast thou no care of me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s another Hero!
target: Another Hero!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look, he’s approaching Caesar.
target: Look how he makes to Caesar.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s enough for one lesson.
target: D'elbow.”      “D'elbow,”    “De nick,”  “De nick.”  “De chin.” “De sin.”

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What can I do for you?
target: What is your pleasure?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is Antonio, my dearest friend.
target: This is the man, this is Antonio, To whom I am so infinitely bound.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s me.
target: He, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But tell me, monsieur—what sport are the ladies missing?
target: But what is the sport, monsieur, that the ladies have lost?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know when a man is on fire, he’ll swear anything.
target: I do know, When the blood burns, how prodigal the soul Lends the tongue vows.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, his chest!
target: Ay, his breast.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What were the primary evils he claimed women were guilty of?
target: Can you remember any of the principal evils that he laid to the charge of women?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t think any woman like that exists.
target: I do not think there is any such woman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your shoes are in pretty bad shape.
target: Your shoes is not so good.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hear the shrill whistle that brings order to the hubbub.
target: Hear the shrill whistle, which doth order give To sounds confused.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He was so slick in covering over his plans that if it hadn’t been for his love affair with Shore’s wife, I would never have suspected him.
target: So smooth he daubed his vice with show of virtue That, his apparent open guilt omitted— I mean his conversation with Shore’s wife— He lived from all attainder of suspects.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do I know these men who are with you?
target: Know I these men that come along with you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t misunderstand me, sir.
target: Mistake me not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But, tell me, where is the noble Richmond now?
target: But, tell me, where is princely Richmond now?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, do you recognize this glove?
target: Sir, know you this glove?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you going to hide and watch them having sex?
target: Would you, the supervisor, grossly gape on, Behold her topped?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, I’m not wound up.
target: Not so, neither.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The Queen is coming.
target: The Queen approaches.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, gentle cousin, if it were light enough for you.
target: Ay, gentle cousin, were it light enough.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, Fool?
target: Why, Fool?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: By Jesus, I think they will blow up everything if we don’t improve our tactics.
target: By Cheshu, I think he will plow up all if there is not better directions.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me those flowers.
target: Give me those flowers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ve been competing with this king for my daughter.
target: We first address towards you, who with this king Hath rivaled for our daughter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You know where she is.
target: You best know the place.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Life, wealth, everything belongs to Death.
target: Life, living, all is Death’s.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You should know this: much luck is on my side, and my enemies have happened to wreck their ship on this island.
target: Know thus far forth: By accident most strange, bountiful Fortune (Now my dear lady) hath mine enemies Brought to this shore.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I admit two sleeves.
target: I confess two sleeves.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ha!
target: Ha!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And as for my soul, how can the ghost endanger that, since it’s as immortal as the ghost is?
target: I do not set my life in a pin’s fee, And for my soul—what can it do to that, Being a thing immortal as itself?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: England would be lucky to have this virtuous prince as king.
target: Happy were England would this virtuous prince Take on his grave the sovereignty thereof.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And isn’t a sheep’s grease as wholesome as a man’s sweat?
target: And is not the grease of a mutton as wholesome as the sweat of a man?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It takes a wise father to know his own child.
target: It is a wise father that knows his own child.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What?
target: What’s that?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The king’s a dear boy with a heart of gold, he’s a lively lad, a wag, born of fine parents, good with his fists.
target: The king’s a bawcock, and a heart of gold, A lad of life, an imp of fame, Of parents good, of fist most valiant.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When he regained consciousness again, he said that if he’d done or said anything wrong, he wanted them to know that it was all because of his sickness.
target: When he came to himself again, he said, if he had done or said anything amiss, he desired their worships to think it was his infirmity.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thank you, sir.
target: I thank you, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I swear on my life that I’m speaking the truth.
target: This to be true I do engage my life.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Pull them apart.
target: Pluck them asunder.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can push my buttons, but you can’t play me for a fool.
target: Call me what instrument you will, though you can fret me, yet you cannot play upon me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll ask only Benedick to come with me, for from the top of his head to the soles of his feet he’s a joker.
target: I will only be bold with Benedick for his company, for from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot he is all mirth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I should backtrack and begin with how my master, Don John, arranged for the Prince, Claudio, and himself to witness this friendly encounter from the orchard.
target: I should first tell thee how the Prince, Claudio and my master, planted and placed and possessed by my master Don John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wherever he goes, he inspires compassion and people turn against us.
target: Where he arrives he moves All hearts against us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come back to my house with me.
target: Go in with me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For God’s sake, find a house to duck into.
target: For God’s sake, take a house.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s why your daughter and son-in-law are punishing me shamefully.
target: Your son and daughter found this trespass worth The shame which here it suffers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look, it’s going away.
target: See, it stalks away.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our knocking woke him up.
target: Our knocking has awaked him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here comes Oberon.
target: Here comes Oberon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have to stop you, Cimber.
target: Most high, most mighty, and most puissant Caesar, Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat An humble heart—     I must prevent thee, Cimber.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, you’d answer, “The slaves are ours.” And that’s just how I’m answering you.
target: You will answer, “The slaves are ours.” So do I answer you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you want things done in the right way, you’ll have to let me read a crazy letter in a crazy voice.
target: An your ladyship will have it as it ought to be, you must allow  Prithee, read i' thy right wits.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who are you?
target: Who’s there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My darling Othello!
target: My dear Othello!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My dear Regan, your sister’s not worth anything.
target: Belovèd Regan, Thy sister’s naught.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’ll have to kill both of us, and indeed we’re both men.
target: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed, But that’s no matter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Does a madman scare me when he stares at me?
target: Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s go inside and we’ll answer all your questions truthfully.
target: Let us go in, And charge us there upon interr'gatories, And we will answer all things faithfully.

target: If thou rememb’rest not the slightest folly That ever love did make thee run into, Thou hast not loved.

target: This is the night That either makes me or fordoes me quite.

target: The Dauphin longs for morning.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, sad day!
target: O woeful day!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s there to say?
target: What’s to say?

target: But, till the king come forth, and not till then, Unto Southampton do we shift our scene.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll run, devil.
target: I will run, fiend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now tell me how long you intend to keep her.
target: Now tell me how long you would have her after you have possessed her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It probably has something to do with… I don’t know.
target: Belike Some things—I know not what.

target: Let music sound while he doth make his choice.

target: See where she comes from shrift with merry look.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Right on time.
target: Pat, pat.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What am I, a cane?
target: Do I look like a cudgel or a hovel-post, a staff or a prop?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I do, in fact.
target: I do, truly, for thou swear’st to me thou art honest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I swear, I’m telling you what I honestly think.
target: By my troth, I speak my thought.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t love him.
target: I cannot love him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Gracious brother, I will go with them.
target: Our gracious brother, I will go with them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can’t I say something?
target: May not one speak?

target: He that parts us shall bring a brand from heaven And fire us hence like foxes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But, my lord, this boy was born in the forest and has been schooled not in the usual subjects but only in magic.
target: But, my good lord, this boy is forest-born And hath been tutored in the rudiments Of many desperate studies by his uncle, Whom he reports to be a great magician Obscurèd in the circle of this forest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here I go.
target: I go.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But what’s he like?
target: Of very ill manner.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What, does your wife say you can come home?
target: What, says the married woman you may go?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So I  Your Honor’s actors, hearing of your recovery, have come to perform a pleasing comedy for you—and your doctors approve wholeheartedly.
target: Your Honor’s players, hearing your amendment, Are come to play a pleasant comedy, For so your doctors hold it very meet, Seeing too much sadness hath congealed your blood, And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I did.
target: I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If the English had any sense, they would run away.
target: If the English had any apprehension, they would run away.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You haven’t got it in you to frown or look displeased or bite your lip as angry women do.
target: Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance, Nor bite the lip as angry wenches will, Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It was some devil.
target: It was some fiend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good morning to you.
target: Good morrow to you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will die and leave Death everything.
target: I will die, And leave him all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We were pushed out of power by evil deeds, as you call them.
target: By foul play, as thou sayst, were we heaved thence, But blessedly holp hither.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who I am and what I want are a secret.
target: What I am and what I would are as secret as maidenhead.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But so what?
target: What of that?

target: I had a wound here that was like a “T,” But now ’tis made an “H.”                                                        They do retire.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s given me a second life, and marrying her makes him a second father to me.
target: And second father This lady makes him to me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And if she starts to drop off, I’ll rant and yell until I wake her up.
target: And, in conclusion, she shall watch all night, And if she chance to nod I’ll rail and brawl, And with the clamor keep her still awake.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: With the quick, intelligent wit she’s rumored to have, she can’t really be such a bad judge of character that she’d refuse a man as exceptional as Signior Benedick.
target: She cannot be so much without true judgment, Having so swift and excellent a wit As she is prized to have, as to refuse So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get out of my sight!
target: Out of my sight!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re right.
target: Thou’st spoken right.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t speak any more.
target: I can no more.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What, would you let a snake bite you twice?
target: What, wouldst thou have a serpent sting thee twice?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here’s the money you wanted, master.
target: Master, here’s The gold you sent me for.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t insult my master’s generosity by killing yourself.
target: Cleopatra, Do not abuse my master’s bounty by Th’ undoing of yourself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, Antony!
target: O Antony, O thou Arabian bird!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I even knew the tailor who made the disguise she wore when she ran off.
target: I, for my part, knew the tailor that made the wings she flew withal.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, you can go.
target: Come, away.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My master is being difficult.
target: My master is grown quarrelsome.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dressing my out-and-out wickedness in scraps of Scripture, I look like a saint exactly when I’m most like the devil.
target: Now they believe it and withal whet me To be revenged on Rivers, Dorset, Grey; But then I sigh and, with a piece of scripture, Tell them that God bids us do good for evil; And thus I clothe my naked villainy With odd old ends stolen out of Holy Writ, And seem a saint when most I play the devil.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But didn’t you expect us to cut the cloth?
target: But did you not request to have it cut?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She shall not.
target: She shall not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dorset, embrace Hastings.—Hastings, express your affection for the marquess of Dorset.
target: Dorset, embrace him.—Hastings, love Lord Marquess.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Got it?
target: Enough.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God bless you, sir.
target: God 'ild you, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get up, man!
target: What, rouse thee, man!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you so pious that you would pray for this man and his children, a man who has pushed you toward an early grave and put your family in poverty forever?
target: Are you so gospeled To pray for this good man and for his issue, Whose heavy hand hath bowed you to the grave And beggared yours forever?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Companions in sorrow alleviate our grief.
target: But then the mind much sufferance doth o'erskip When grief hath mates and bearing fellowship.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s the end of the announcement.
target: So much was his pleasure should be proclaimed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Has anyone seen Cesario?
target: Who saw Cesario, ho?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Normally I would ask you what your name is first.
target: In wisdom I should ask thy name.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He doesn’t miss a thing.
target: He misses not much.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who treated you badly?
target: Who does do you wrong?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish I could keep killing him for nine years straight.
target: I would have him nine years a-killing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: March to meet him at a dignified pace.
target: March gently on to meet him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s right, and then after we fixed the moon, we’d go bird-hunting.
target: We would so, and then go a-batfowling.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I surrender your dukedom and beg you to forgive me all my crimes.
target: Thy dukedom I resign and do entreat Thou pardon me my wrongs.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And I’m such a sensitive ass that if my hair even tickles me a little, I need to scratch.
target: And I am such a tender ass, if my hair do but tickle me, I must scratch.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If arguing makes us sweat, the real trial will turn that water to blood.
target: Never, till Caesar’s three and thirty wounds Be well avenged, or till another Caesar Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You are welcome for his sake.
target: You are welcome for his sake.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What kind of god is ceremony, which suffers more than its worshippers do?
target: What kind of god art thou, that suffer’st more Of mortal griefs than do thy worshippers?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If we are slated to die, the fewer, the better for our country, and if we’re slated to live, the fewer men, the greater the share of honor for each of us.
target: If we are marked to die, we are enough To do our country loss; and if to live, The fewer men, the greater share of honor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then by all means never let her walk in public.
target: Let her not walk i' th' sun.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I never saw her till now.
target: I never saw her till this time.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You suffered a loss like mine?
target: You the like loss?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you ever loved your poor dear father— Oh God!
target: If thou didst ever thy dear father love— O God!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Her fallow fields are overgrown with weeds, while the blade that should uproot such wilderness lies rusting.
target: Her fallow leas The darnel, hemlock, and rank fumitory Doth root upon, while that the coulter rusts That should deracinate such savagery.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He thinks that since his fortune is twenty times better than yours, it would be like pitting twenty men against one.
target: He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune, He is twenty men to one.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you say?
target: What say you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Welcome, gentlemen.
target: Am I come near ye now?— Welcome, gentlemen!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The devil inside him is rough, but we can’t treat it roughly.
target: The fiend is rough and will not be roughly used.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good-bye.
target: Farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In what chapter and verse of his heart?
target: In what chapter of his bosom?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The gods can hear you lying!
target: You lie up to the hearing of the gods.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Some French agents are already at work in our main ports and are on the verge of declaring open war.
target: From France there comes a power Into this scattered kingdom, who already, Wise in our negligence, have secret feet In some of our best ports and are at point To show their open banner.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me your hand.
target: Give me thy hand.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, I cannot tell how my difficult life has weathered my face, but I will never let those difficulties subdue my courage.
target: Well, I know not What counts harsh Fortune casts upon my face, But in my bosom shall she never come To make my heart her vassal.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m afraid of what they might encourage him to do, considering the state he’s in.
target: And what they may incense him to, being apt To have his ear abused, wisdom bids fear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But these days, people give each other their hands without their hearts.
target: The hearts of old gave hands, But our new heraldry is hands, not hearts.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Everyone’s there except Metellus Cimber, and he’s gone to look for you at your house.
target: All but Metellus Cimber, and he’s gone To seek you at your house.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, what was your dream?
target: Well, what was yours?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My father can’t think straight—a hundred knights!
target: This man hath had good counsel—a hundred knights!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Huh!
target: Ha!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m just stating the facts as I see them.
target: I speak but as I find.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So she is drowned.
target: Therefore this project

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Would you try to lift Mount Olympus?
target: Wilt thou lift up Olympus?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What if this mixture doesn’t work at all?
target: What if this mixture do not work at all?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What a painful condition responsibility is.
target: We must bear all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who doesn’t know that the good duke is dead?
target: Who knows not that the gentle duke is dead?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you mean to say that the duke has abandoned the glamorous court to live as a monk?
target: Sir, by your patience: if I heard you rightly, The duke hath put on a religious life And thrown into neglect the pompous court.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Mistress, think about your end—beware of your death!
target: Mistress,  Wilt thou still talk?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is the worst well?
target: Yea, is the worst well?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s blocking the way?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can a good thing hide itself?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I was reminded of my son, even though I despised my son at that time.
target: My son Came then into my mind, and yet my mind Was then scarce friends with him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You certainly made me believe you did, my lord.
target: Indeed, my lord, you made me believe so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Fathers, never trust your daughters just because they act obedient and innocent.
target: Fathers, from hence trust not your daughters' minds By what you see them act.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s for sure.
target: Nay, that’s certain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me, you villainous lowlife, where are my children?
target: Tell me, thou villain-slave, where are my children?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How are you, madam?
target: How do you, madam?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Barnardo’s taken my place.
target: Barnardo has my place.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t harp on that point, madam—it’s past.
target: Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Pardon me but I do not know what is “like me.” An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel.
target: An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, Signior Petruchio, how are you getting on with my daughter?
target: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me if it’s good or bad, and I’ll wait for the details.
target: Say either, and I’ll stay the circumstance.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I knew him when he listened to nothing but the military drum and fife; now he would rather hear the sweet and refined music of the tabor and pipe.
target: I have known when there was no music with him but the drum and the fife, and now had he rather hear the tabor and the pipe.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come over here, gentlemen, and put your hands on my sword again.
target: Come hither, gentlemen, And lay your hands again upon my sword.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Very suspicious.
target: A great suspicion.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Cicero, I’ve seen storms in which the angry winds split old oak trees, and I’ve seen the ocean swell, rage, and foam, as if it wanted to reach the storm clouds, but never before tonight, never until now, have I experienced a storm that drops fire.
target: O Cicero, I have seen tempests when the scolding winds Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen Th' ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam To be exalted with the threatening clouds, But never till tonight, never till now, Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio have been deceived.
target: Why then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio Have been deceived.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t you realize the duke has also banished me, his daughter?
target: Know’st thou not the duke Hath banished me, his daughter?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shall I include hell as well?
target: And shall I couple hell?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yet I wish I could take that promise back, so I had it to give again.
target: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it, And yet I would it were to give again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Explain.
target: Your reason.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You have ruined my innocent child.
target: I say thou hast belied mine innocent child.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tranio, I think I’ve got it!
target: I have it, Tranio!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We know each other’s faces, but as for our thoughts, he doesn’t know any more about my thinking than I do about yours or his—or you do about mine.
target: We know each other’s faces; for our hearts, He knows no more of mine than I of yours, Or I of his, my lord, than you of mine.— Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good-bye, son.
target: Farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, to think you’ve been rejected!
target: That ever I should call thee castaway!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t have the cash right now.
target: I am not furnished with the present money.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, give me the worst news.
target: Well, what worst?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Therefore, drink up.—Servant-monster, drink a toast to me.
target: Therefore bear up and board 'em.—Servant- monster, drink to me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t believe you’re my son.
target: I cannot think you are my son.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why didn’t I just adopt a beggar’s child left at my doorstep, whose shame and dishonor I could have denied, not being its true father?
target: Why had I not with charitable hand Took up a beggar’s issue at my gates, Who, smirchèd thus, and mired with infamy, I might have said, “No part of it is mine; This shame derives itself from unknown loins”?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And did you see the handkerchief?
target: And did you see the handkerchief?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lights, lights, get us some lights!
target: Lights, lights, lights!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Killed?
target: My life, sir!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s the ruler here?
target: Who governs here?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Never.
target: Never.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That would make anyone cry enough to water his garden with his tears.
target: Why, this would make a man a man of salt, To use his eyes for garden water-pots, Ay, and laying autumn’s dust.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I haven’t seen such a promising candidate for your love.
target: Yet I have not seen So likely an ambassador of love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can see in your eyes there’s been some good news.
target: I know by that same eye there’s some good news.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So will we all.
target: So all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A fortunate coincidence—more fortunate for your son.
target: Happily met, the happier for thy son.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Pronounce them—it is just as nice to say.
target: Sound them, it doth become the mouth as well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But come on, start.
target: Come, begin.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Mark Antony, take Caesar’s body.
target: Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar’s body.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, Lord!
target: O Lord!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have you forgotten her?
target: Hast thou forgot her?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Once I’ve put my rackets to these balls, I’ll play a set in France, God willing, that will knock his father’s crown right out of the court.
target: When we have matched our rackets to these balls, We will in France, by God’s grace, play a set Shall strike his father’s crown into the hazard.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t say “banishment.” From now on, you are banished from Verona.
target: Do not say “banishment.” Hence from Verona art thou banishèd.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But he’d been there before me, and they told me he’d gone out looking for me.
target: Yet there he was, and there I found this credit, That he did range the town to seek me out.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Treat me well.
target: Use me well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But if it overwhelms you to look at Caesar’s wounded cloak, how will you feel, kind men, now?
target: Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold Our Caesar’s vesture wounded?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I was such a beast to be angry at him.
target: Sole monarch of the universal earth, Oh, what a beast was I to chide at him!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let him hoist you up in front of the shouting crowds!
target: Let him take thee And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen to many people, but talk to few.
target: Give every man thy ear but few thy voice.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The present time is like a woman in labor, each minute giving birth to some piece of news.
target: With news the time’s with labor, and throws forth Each minute some.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And what did Surrey say to that?
target: And what said Surrey then?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, okay.—I swear to God, both their stories match.
target: Well, stand aside.—'Fore God, they are both in a ale.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So, may the gods protect you and change the hearts of the Romans so that they turn and give you their support.
target: So the gods keep you And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hail!
target: Hail!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I tell you, man, it’s better for me, too, than the last time we met here.
target: I tell thee, man, ’tis better with me now Than when thou met’st me last where now we meet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tie up his withered old arms.
target: Bind fast his corky arms.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can confirm that all these shocking things are true.
target: All this amazement can I qualify When after that the holy rites are ended I’ll tell you largely of fair Hero’s death.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know that she is worthy of that love.
target: That she is worthy, I know.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get some light!
target: Light!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For God’s sake, Sir Toby, you’ve got to come home earlier at night.
target: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o' nights.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is just a trifling matter here, sir.
target: Even a toy in hand here, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hold off burying her until I’ve caught her in my arms once more.
target: Hold off the earth awhile Till I have caught her once more in mine arms.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You, who are neither honest nor good.
target: To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now I’ll tell you so you don’t have to ask.
target: Now I’ll tell you without asking.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She thinks I’ll marry her because she loves me.
target: She is persuaded I will marry her, out of her own love and flattery, not out of my promise.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, we talked for a couple of hours.
target: Ay, two hours together.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: To tell the truth, though, I think the duke hasn’t lost a single man, except for one who will probably be executed for robbing a church, one Bardolph—I don’t know if your Majesty knows the man.
target: Marry, for my part, I think the duke hath lost never a man, but one that is like to be executed for robbing a church, one Bardolph, if your Majesty know the man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He hasn’t told this to the king, has he?
target: He hath not told his thought to the king?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who are you talking about, niece?
target: What is he that you ask for, niece?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Two of my brother’s men, all tied up!
target: Two of my brother’s men bound!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is Caesar you’re looking at.
target: Look upon Caesar.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who can blame him for acting crazy, when inside he condemns himself for everything he’s done?
target: Who then shall blame His pestered senses to recoil and start, When all that is within him does condemn Itself for being there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I want you to live, since to me, death is happiness.
target: I’d have thee live, For in my sense ’tis happiness to die.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I told him we’ll stay for at least a month, and he says that he hopes we’ll stay longer.
target: I tell him we shall stay here at the least a month, and he heartily prays some occasion may detain us longer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My dearest sister!
target: My dear’st sister!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can you tell me?
target: May I know?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But, hey, this doesn’t mean you’re looking to get married, does it?
target: But I hope you have no intent to turn husband, have you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Absolutely everything.
target: All, all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We should all kneel before her, men of Cyprus!
target: You men of Cyprus, let her have your knees.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I said she was.
target: I have said.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And she is very smart.
target: And she is exceeding wise.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I didn’t tell you to get rid of one love and replace her with another.
target: Not in a grave, To lay one in, another out to have.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come sit on me.
target: Come, sit on me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I could do without another toast.
target: I could well forbear ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: O Lord, I could stay here all night listening to such good advice.
target: O Lord, I could have stayed here all the night To hear good counsel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, fool, go away.
target: I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen to me, you traitor.
target: Hear me, recreant!

target: But he hath chid me hence and threatened me To strike me, spurn me—nay, to kill me too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Nobody will hurt us.
target: They will surely do us no harm.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s sad, but Iago knows she had sex with Cassio a thousand times.
target: Tis pitiful, but yet Iago knows That she with Cassio hath the act of shame A thousand times committed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Say, what’s the trouble?
target: How now, what’s the matter?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’s a farmer here who won’t leave without seeing your Highness.
target: Here is a rural fellow That will not be denied your Highness’ presence.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Some of you go to Decius’s house and some to Casca’s.
target: Some to Decius' house and some to Casca’s.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lovers, moan and weep.
target: Lovers, make moan.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t follow me.
target: Follow me not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It did, it did.
target: It did, it did.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Better, since your lordship was nice enough to ask.
target: The better that your Lordship please to ask.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This was the most unkind cut of all.
target: This was the most unkindest cut of all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You, will you join with me?
target: Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s me, sir.
target: Or I do forget myself?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s women crying, my good lord.
target: It is the cry of women, my good lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lighten up.
target: killed a cat?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s what Fulvia told me.
target: So Fulvia told me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hold on a moment, and listen to my advice.
target: Pause awhile, And let my counsel sway you in this case.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I accept that offer happily, madam.
target: Madam, I am most apt to embrace your offer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me enjoy my privacy.
target: Let me enjoy my private.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll tell you before you have to ask me again.
target: I’ll tell thee ere thou ask it me again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And the one who commands us is our king.
target: And he that hath commanded is our king.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you killed Lysander while he was sleeping, then you’re already up to your ankles in blood.
target: If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep, Being o'er shoes in blood, plunge in the deep, And kill me too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And no doubt he is, gracious madam.
target: And so no doubt he is, my gracious madam.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So, take me, death!
target: Tis but one cast away, and so, come, death.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: See, now I have you.
target: Look, here I have you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He fell down in the marketplace and foamed at the mouth and was speechless.
target: He fell down in the marketplace, and foamed at mouth, and was speechless.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Error in the bill, sir, error in the bill!
target: Error i' the bill, sir, error i' the bill!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Soon enough.
target: It will be short.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, then, put your sword away.
target: Well, well, put up your sword.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He smiles so much his face has more lines in it than a map of the East Indies.
target: He does smile his face into more lines than is in the new map with the augmentation of the Indies.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Madam, here comes your husband.
target: Madam, here comes my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s the way of the world.
target: And laid the love juice on some true love’s sight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have drawn my sword.
target: My sword is drawn.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go wisely and slowly.
target: Wisely and slow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go get me a crow.
target: Go, borrow me a crow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Madam, you have to go to your uncle’s.
target: Madam, you must come to your uncle.
