target: Neither to you nor any one, having no witness to confirm my speech.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Absolutely, yes indeed.
target: Why, in good time.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d better stop up my ears against this siren’s song.
target: But lest myself be guilty to self wrong, I’ll stop mine ears against the mermaid’s song.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You scolded him in private?
target: Haply in private.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then run away.
target: Think on Lord Hastings.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Captain Macmorris, I think, see—correct me if I’m wrong—there are not many of your nation— My nation?
target: Captain Macmorris, I think, look you, under your correction, there is not many of your nation—  Of my nation?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Because it will make you angry, and that will get me another beating.
target: Lest it make you choleric and purchase me another dry basting.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s all over now, and so am I.  Let’s forgive each other.
target: Tis past, and so am I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How is lieutenant Cassio?
target: How does lieutenant Cassio?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stillness and nighttime are perfect for beautiful music.
target: Soft stillness and the night Become the touches of sweet harmony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve brought him a present.
target: I have brought him a present.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s weird.
target: Tis strange.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It turns kings into gods and men of lower rank into kings.
target: Kings it makes gods, and meaner creatures kings.

target: Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s a villain and a bastard and a coward and a rascal.
target: Ish a villain and a basterd and a knave and a rascal.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So please rest.
target: Pray now, rest yourself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The Dauphin, whom we asked for reinforcements, sends back the answer that he’s not yet in a position to raise so great an army.
target: The Dauphin, whom of succors we entreated, Returns us that his powers are yet not ready To raise so great a siege.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look, and you’ll see.
target: Look, and thou shalt see.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And I understand perfectly his sneering reference to my wilder days.
target: And we understand him well, How he comes o'er us with our wilder days, Not measuring what use we made of them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If they have spoken the truth about Hero, I will tear her apart with my bare hands.
target: If they speak but truth of her, These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honor, The proudest of them shall well hear of it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But are you sure that Benedick loves Beatrice that much?
target: But are you sure That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So, are you done?
target: I am fire and air, my other elements I give to baser life.—So, have you done?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The ground is brown.
target: The ground indeed is tawny.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m listening to you only because I’ve got nothing better to do.
target: Well, sir, for want of other idleness, I’ll bide your proof.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why should he call her a whore?
target: Why should he call her “whore”?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll sleep here until morning.
target: Here will I rest me till the break of day.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What gentleman?
target: What gentleman?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wouldn’t care about my spirits, if my legs weren’t tired.
target: I care not for my spirits, if my legs were not weary.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: At least two hours past.
target: At least two glasses.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Absolutely, people should be what they appear to be.
target: Certain, men should be what they seem.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If he isn’t what he might be, then I wish to God he were!
target: If what he might he is not, I would to heaven he were!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our leader is being led.
target: So our leader’s led, And we are women’s men.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me see what he looks like, so when I see another man who resembles him, I’ll know to avoid him.
target: Let me see his eyes, That, when I note another man like him, I may avoid him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, my lord?
target: My lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, all of you, stand up.
target: I pray you all, stand up.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Play with me, Charmian.
target: Come, Charmian.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Large and increasing.
target: Great and increasing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, you keep getting paler.
target: Come, you look paler and paler.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Today’s a holiday, so the beggar’s shop is shut.
target: Being holiday, the beggar’s shop is shut.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You have my friendship.
target: Thou hast my love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where is he?
target: Where is he?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ah, here she comes, angry and sad.
target: Here she comes, cursed and sad.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have no idea what you’re talking about, Hamlet.
target: I have nothing with this answer, Hamlet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t be sad that this happened because of you, because Lady Luck’s been nicer to me than usual.
target: Grieve not that I am fall'n to this for you, For herein Fortune shows herself more kind Than is her custom.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell my servants not to mention that we were gone.
target: Give order to my servants that they take No note at all of our being absent hence.— Nor you, Lorenzo.—Jessica, nor you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Brother, I’ll go and bring it to you.
target: Brother, I’ll go and bring it thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Aren’t you a rational human being?
target: Are you a man?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I’m a wasp, look out for my stinger.
target: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Out, out, brief candle.
target: Out, out, brief candle!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My noble uncle, do you know why he acts this way?
target: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can you ask around and find out?
target: Can you inquire him out and be edified by report?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stand up if you’re really a man.
target: Stand, an you be a man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll give you frets!” With that, she clobbers me with the lute so that my head goes right through,
target: I’ll fume with them!” And with that word she struck me on the head, And through the instrument my pate made way,

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will, sir.
target: I shall, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The sweet and bitter fool Will appear right away.
target: The sweet and bitter fool Will presently appear— The one in motley here, The other found out there.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I said “your husband.”—Do you understand that word?
target: I say “thy husband”—dost understand the word?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All right then, back home we go.
target: Why, then let’s home again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let it be.
target: Let be.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll never speak to you again.
target: Hear me a word, For I shall never speak to thee again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, my lady, just confirm that you’re the lady of the house so I can get on with my speech.
target: Good gentle one, give me modest assurance if you be the lady of the house, that I may proceed in my speech.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Because I didn’t want to watch while you gouged out his poor old eyes with your cruel fingernails, or while your vicious sister sank her fangs into his sacred flesh.
target: Because I would not see thy cruèl nails Pluck out his poor old eyes, nor thy fierce sister In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll go to him.
target: I’ll come to him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your two sons?
target: Where are thy two sons?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Certainly, I did.
target: Marry, and did.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Enobarbus, Antony has sent you all your treasure, with generous gifts besides.
target: Enobarbus, Antony Hath after thee sent all thy treasure, with His bounty overplus.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bassanio told him he’d try to hurry back.
target: Bassanio told him he would make some speed Of his return.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’re ready if our minds are ready.
target: All things are ready if our minds be so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, uncle, let’s go in and ask your daughters to forgive you.
target: Good nuncle, in, and ask thy daughters blessing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You kick me out, he kicks me back.
target: You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wait, let me hire him too.—Here’s my fool’s cap, a token of my gratitude.
target: Let me hire him too.—Here’s my coxcomb.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Or am I asleep now and imagining all this?
target: Or sleep I now and think I hear all this?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s the whore’s curse, to seduce many men, but to be seduced by one.
target: It is a creature That dotes on Cassio, as ’tis the strumpet’s plague To beguile many and be beguiled by one.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What does the silver one say?
target: What says the silver with her virgin hue?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon.
target: I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thanks, good Egeus.
target: Thanks, good Egeus.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let go of me.
target: Hold off your hands.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Me too, Lord!
target: And me too, good Lord!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll get some cloth and egg whites to bandage his bleeding face.
target: I’ll fetch some flax and whites of eggs To apply to his bleeding face.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m warning you.
target: Petruchio, patience.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What else did you hear?
target: What else, fellow?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can’t get out of trouble by praying or crying, so don’t bother.
target: Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses, Therefore use none.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A constant pain to me!
target: A pestilent gall to me!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The rest of my life will be nothing but bitterness.
target: And what’s to come of my despisèd time Is naught but bitterness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lily-livered coward, what’s he doing there?
target: White-livered runagate, what doth he there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll fight you.
target: I am for you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If he becomes pale, I know what to do.
target: If he do blench, I know my course.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen to Antony.
target: Hear Antony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But as for now—before two weeks have gone by, I’m going to send some people packing.
target: Well, Catesby, ere a fortnight make me older I’ll send some packing that yet think not on ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Eros, can you still see me?
target: Eros, thou yet behold’st me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, I don’t—except as a friend.
target: No, truly, but in friendly recompense.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did you say Cassio?
target: Did you say with Cassio?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll send goblins out at night to work their nasty deeds on you.
target: Urchins Shall, forth at vast of night that they may work, All exercise on thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I pitied you, worked hard to teach you to speak, and taught you some new thing practically every hour.
target: I pitied thee, Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour One thing or other.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, no.
target: O, in the battle think on Buckingham, And die in terror of thy guiltiness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Horns?
target: Horns?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m sure he’s somewhere on the island.
target: For he is, sure, i' th' island.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good sir, as a friend, I advise you to leave this place.
target: Good sir, I do in friendship counsel you To leave this place.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s given his empire to a whore, and now they’re gathering kings to wage a war.
target: He hath given his empire Up to a whore; who now are levying The kings o’ th’ earth for war.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If she refuses my proposal, I’ll tell her how much I’m looking forward to the announcement and the wedding.
target: If she deny to wed, I’ll crave the day When I shall ask the banns and when be marrièd.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You know me too well.
target: You know me well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you lie, boy, we’ll have you whipped.
target: An you lie, sirrah, we’ll have you whipped.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Speaking for myself—and no offense to the general or anyone else—I hope I’m going to heaven.
target: For mine own part, no offence to the general nor any man of quality, I hope to be saved.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did you hear this, Gonzalo?
target: Heard you this, Gonzalo?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, I do.
target: I do.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hail!
target: Hail!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m sorry my noble brother is suspicious of me.
target: Sorry I am my noble cousin should Suspect me that I mean no good to him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, that I don’t remember.
target: But that I do not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: May I only do well in these dangerous battles if my intention to repent and prosper is sincere!
target: As I intend to prosper and repent, So thrive I in my dangerous affairs Of hostile arms!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, if I know the language and the letters.
target: Ay, if I know the letters and the language.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll be with you right away.
target: I’ll be with thee straight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I say she shall.—And first begin with her.
target: I say she shall.—And first begin with her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The king performs more wonders than seem humanly possible, challenging every enemy he sees.
target: The king enacts more wonders than a man, Daring an opposite to every danger.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then why am I worried?
target: Then wherefore should I doubt?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, sir, I’ll take you to Lear and have you stay with him a while.
target: Well, sir, I’ll bring you to our master Lear And leave you to attend him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Seriously, cousin, I love a woman.
target: In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What is this?
target: How, how, how, how?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A beautiful target is the one that gets hit the fastest.
target: A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Really, I’ll help.
target: Sooth, la, I’ll help.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You were worn with honor.
target: You have been nobly borne.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know how his mind works.
target: I know his heart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you need me to do?
target: To do what, Signior?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, may I ask?
target: Why, may one ask?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re not leaving the house today.
target: You shall not stir out of your house today.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tybalt was my dearest cousin.
target: My dearest cousin and my dearer lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I swear the only ransom will be these bones of mine.
target: They shall have none, I swear, but these my joints, Which, if they have, as I will leave 'em them, Shall yield them little.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll miss you, Ariel, but you’ll be free.—Yes, you will, yes.—Go to the king’s ship in your invisible state.
target: I shall miss thee, But yet thou shalt have freedom.—So, so, so.— To the king’s ship, invisible as thou art.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Enjoy your frankness; it suits you.
target: Enjoy thy plainness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll maintain that she died the instant she was accused, and everyone who hears this will grieve for her, pity her, and excuse her actions.
target: She, dying, as it must so be maintained, Upon the instant that she was accused, Shall be lamented, pitied and excused Of every hearer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do as you please, because I’m done worrying about you.
target: Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me see you dance.
target: Let me see the caper.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Farewell, then, Signior Lucentio.
target: And so farewell, Signior Lucentio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So I thank you all, and I invite each and every one of you to come watch me be crowned king of Scotland at Scone.
target: So, thanks to all at once and to each one, Whom we invite to see us crowned at Scone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dear sister, it’s unfair to me—and unfair to yourself—to turn me into a slave.
target: Good sister, wrong me not nor wrong yourself, To make a bondmaid and a slave of me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You told me to make it well and properly and in keeping with the current style.
target: You bid me make it orderly and well, According to the fashion and the time.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You asked for justice, so rest assured you’ll get more justice than you bargained for.
target: For as thou urgest justice, be assured Thou shalt have justice more than thou desirest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come with me to see the duchess.
target: Go with me to the duchess.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: O, everlasting shame!
target: O perdurable shame!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The king of England’s approach is as forceful as a whirlpool.
target: For England his approaches makes as fierce As waters to the sucking of a gulf.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is it good news?
target: Are they good?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In private?
target: In private?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, Brutus, you have only yourself to thank.
target: Flatterers?—Now, Brutus, thank yourself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You mean I should groan and tell you?
target: What, shall I groan and tell thee?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Spring, summer, fertile autumn and angry winter have all changed places, and now the confused world doesn’t know which is which.
target: The spring, the summer, The childing autumn, angry winter change Their wonted liveries, and the mazèd world, By their increase, now knows not which is which.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who wouldn’t get sad thinking about things like that?
target: Shall I have the thought To think on this, and shall I lack the thought That such a thing bechanced would make me sad?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But Antonio’s certainly ruined.
target: But Antonio is certainly undone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Just like the rabbit, who lives where she is born.
target: As the cony that you see dwell where she is kindled.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let them start something.
target: Let them begin.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thursday it is, then.
target: O' Thursday be it, then.— Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Young Fortinbras, returning in triumph from Poland, is firing his guns to greet the English ambassadors.
target: Young Fortinbras, with conquest come from Poland, To th' ambassadors of England gives This warlike volley.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, no, that was my lady’s voice.
target: Out and alas, that was my lady’s voice.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What are you going to do?
target: What’s to be done?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did you fall?
target: Dost fall?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The other girl did not love me.
target: The other did not so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, please.
target: No, pray thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Gone?
target: Gone?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You may do whatever you want in the world.
target: And may, through all the world!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Be quiet, Signior Gremio.
target: Talk not, Signior Gremio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Pay you?
target: I answer you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You might have a great opportunity to give it to him right now.
target: You may have very fit occasion for ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, wait.
target: Nay, I will give thee a kiss.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They’re natural enough.” I think these things are omens of things to come in our country.
target: They are natural.” For I believe they are portentous things Unto the climate that they point upon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What are you doing?
target: What mean you, sir?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My God, they’ve given me a lot to drink.
target: Fore heaven, they have given me a rouse already.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you meet the Prince in the night, you can order him to stop.
target: If you meet the Prince in the night, you may stay him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So, in that case, tell me who’s next in line to inherit the kingdom of Naples?
target: Then, tell me, Who’s the next heir of Naples?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, Iras, Charmian!
target: O Iras, Charmian!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You are my other self, my oracle, my prophet, my dear brother!
target: My other self, my council’s consistory, My oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin, I, as a child, will go by thy direction Toward Ludlow then, for we’ll not stay behind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, I’ve had my say.
target: Nay, I have done.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, just walk with me a little ways, and tell me if I’ll see you later tonight.
target: I pray you bring me on the way a little And say if I shall see you soon at night.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you mean the king?
target: Mean you his majesty?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you mean, the seventh cause?
target: How “seventh cause”?—Good my lord, like this fellow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I never heard so loud a voice issue from such an empty heart.
target: I did never know so full a voice issue from so empty a heart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, I haven’t had lunch.
target: No, no.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All that glitters is not gold— You’ve often heard that said.
target: All that glisters is not gold— Often have you heard that told.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He woke up the whole house with his loud and cowardly screams.
target: He raised the house with loud and coward cries.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Unleash the dogs in the western valley.
target: Uncouple in the western valley.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And my king goes on: if your royal father does not sweeten the bitter insult you sent my king and grant all our demands, Henry’s artillery will give you so resounding an answer that the very caves and vaulted cathedrals of France shall echo your mocking of him back in your face.
target: Thus says my king: an if your father’s Highness Do not, in grant of all demands at large, Sweeten the bitter mock you sent his Majesty, He’ll call you to so hot an answer of it That caves and womby vaultages of France Shall chide your trespass and return your mock In second accent of his ordinance.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A lover would have to be weepier, of course.
target: A lover is more condoling.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But though I was born here and should consider that tradition part of my own heritage, I think it would be better to ignore it than practice it.
target: But to my mind, though I am native here And to the manner born, it is a custom More honored in the breach than the observance.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What color, madam?
target: What color, madam?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Leave him alone.
target: Let him alone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you remember her face?
target: Bear’st thou her face in mind?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come, everyone.
target: Come, sirs.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have some of my servants take care of Malvolio.
target: Let some of my people have a special care of him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And all because I use my own money to make a profit.
target: You call me misbeliever, cutthroat dog, And spet upon my Jewish gaberdine— And all for use of that which is mine own.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You know where I live.
target: Thou know’st my lodging.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He did, my lord.
target: He had, my lord, and when he ran in here, These people saw the chain about his neck.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Though he seems a little old-fashioned, there is much care and courage in this Welshman.
target: Though it appear a little out of fashion, There is much care and valor in this Welshman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For a necklace your husband had him make.
target: Due for a chain your husband had of him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, your report is too poetic, but it sounds so true!
target: Oh, relation Too nice and yet too true!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You swear never to mention what you’ve seen.
target: Never to speak of this that you have seen.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good to see you, Signior Hortensio.
target: And you are well met, Signior Hortensio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where’s Dolabella?
target: Where’s Dolabella, To second Proculeius?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Because who is this man they follow?
target: For what is he they follow?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know all of this.
target: What can he say in this?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Not old enough to be a man, but not young enough to be a boy.
target: Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for a boy, as a squash is before ’tis a peascod, or a codling when ’tis almost an apple.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It doesn’t need to be witty as long as it’s eloquent and imaginative.
target: It is no matter how witty, so it be eloquent and full of invention.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How can this drama be so many contradictory things?
target: How shall we find the concord of this discord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve only made it this far since I left her place, walking at a moderate pace.
target: On a moderate pace I have since arrived but hither.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s definitely Maria’s handwriting.
target: But out of question, ’tis Maria’s hand.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A little bit of grief shows a lot of love.
target: Some grief shows much of love, But much of grief shows still some want of wit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s go.
target: Come away, away.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The one who plays the part of the king will be particularly welcome.
target: He that plays the king shall be welcome.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s true I’m not married, Caesar.
target: I am not married, Caesar.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me see it.
target: I pray you, let me see it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, sir, will you come aboard?
target: Come, sir, will you aboard?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You say you’re a better soldier.
target: You say you are a better soldier.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My uncle?
target: My uncle?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If this dream vision is typical of what this island conjures up, then I’ll lose my son twice.
target: If this prove A vision of the Island, one dear son Shall I twice lose.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Damn it!
target: Away!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stop right there!
target: Stand there!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your speech is more refined than I would expect in such a remote place as this.
target: Your accent is something finer than you could purchase in so removed a dwelling.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give him room.
target: Room!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I just saw your father the Lord Gloucester and notified him that the Duke of Cornwall and his wife Regan will stay with him here tonight.
target: I have been with your father and given him notice that the Duke of Cornwall and Regan his duchess will be here with him this night.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You call this house dark?
target: Sayest thou that house is dark?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If he loves Caesar, then he can only hurt himself—by grieving and dying for Caesar.
target: If he love Caesar, all that he can do Is to himself: take thought and die for Caesar.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I saw that.
target: That I beheld.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So were their daggers, which we found on their pillows, unwiped.
target: So were their daggers, which unwiped we found Upon their pillows.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let the rain spray!
target: Spout, rain!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve relinquished my authority, so please—I’ll see you all before long.
target: Pray you now, Nay, do so, for indeed I have lost command.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, sweet mermaid, don’t command me to drown myself in the flood of your sister’s tears.
target: O, train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note To drown me in thy sister’s flood of tears.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll get her, but I won’t keep her long.
target: I’ll have her, but I will not keep her long.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God be with all of you, princes.
target: God be wi' you, princes all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you mean, “in a strange way”?
target: What man dost thou dig it for?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll give my vile body back to the earth.
target: Vile earth, to earth resign.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s his wife, Lady Grey, who got him to do this.
target: My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, ’tis she That tempers him to this extremity.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If someone like me is fit to be king, let me know.
target: If such a one be fit to govern, speak.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You wouldn’t tell a sick man he “seriously” has to make his will—it would just make him worse.
target: A sick man in sadness makes his will, A word ill urged to one that is so ill.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The king made peace among all of us.
target: I hope the king made peace with all of us; And the compact is firm and true in me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: you, as sure as your name’s Roderigo, if I were the Moor I wouldn’t want to be Iago.
target: For, sir, It is as sure as you are Roderigo, Were I the Moor, I would not be Iago.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Whisper to her that Ursula and I are walking in the orchard and that we’re talking all about her.
target: Whisper her ear and tell her I and Ursula Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse Is all of her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You mustn’t hold my earlier outburst against me.
target: Thou must not take my former sharpness ill.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t you know, master, that some men’s best qualities do them in?
target: Know you not, master, to some kind of men Their graces serve them but as enemies?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Gentlemen, we won’t stay here and anger you further.
target: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where is my mother?
target: Where is my mother?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is no place for you; this home is now a slaughterhouse.
target: This is no place, this house is but a butchery.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Pish!
target: Pish!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What about that?
target: What of that?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Master, master, I’ve been on the lookout so long, I’m ready to fall down dead—but I’ve got one, finally!
target: Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master, That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This diamond is a present from him to your wife for her boundless hospitality.
target: This diamond he greets your wife withal, By the name of most kind hostess, and shut up In measureless content.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The poor thing, I really think she loves me.
target: Alas, poor rogue, I think indeed she loves me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I can’t play a melody.
target: But these cannot I command to any utterance of harmony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There are no bushes or shrubs to protect me from the weather here.
target: Here’s neither bush nor shrub to bear off any weather at all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You don’t love me.
target: You love me not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I could marry you there, gentle Hermia, where the strict laws of Athens can’t touch us.
target: There, gentle Hermia, may I marry thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, you did, sir.
target: Yes, that you did, sir, and forswore it too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I see.
target: Oh, then belike you fancy riches more.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It makes me mad.
target: It makes me mad.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t trust you.
target: I’ll not trust your word.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Although many people said she looked like me, she was considered beautiful.
target: A lady, sir, though it was said she much resembled me, was yet of many accounted beautiful.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Even her worst faults are charming, and holy priests bless her even when she acts the slut.
target: Other women cloy The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry Where most she satisfies, for vilest things Become themselves in her, that the holy priests Bless her when she is riggish.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Start a fight?
target: Quarrel, sir?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our tolerance for slavery and oppression shows us to be weak, like women.
target: Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you mean, beside yourself?
target: And how besides thyself?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, why is this so?
target: Alack, why thus?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will.
target: That will I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I recognize his trumpet.
target: I know his trumpet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let him sink there so the sea will cover him!
target: There let him sink, and be the seas on him!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who do you think you are, keeping me out of my own house?
target: What art thou that keep’st me out from the house I owe?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We have not betrayed you.
target: Do not yourself such wrong, who are in this Relieved but not betrayed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Not yet.
target: Not yet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They are full of pity for Caesar.
target: They are pitiful.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How often tonight have my old feet stumbled on gravestones!
target: How oft tonight Have my old feet stumbled at graves!—Who’s there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I assure you, sir, the tender love I feel in my heart is stronger than the sexual passions stirring down below.
target: I warrant you, sir, The white cold virgin snow upon my heart Abates the ardor of my liver.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When a woman is virtuous, talents like these just make her better.
target: Where virtue is, these are more virtuous.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Strike!
target: Strike!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Add details of your own to back up what I’m saying.
target: Inform her full of my particular fear, And thereto add such reasons of your own As may compact it more.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As moral as me!
target: As I!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Partly to confirm my opinion and partly for the satisfaction, see, of my mind, with respect to the demands of proper military practice—that’s the point?
target: In the way of argument, look you, and friendly communication, partly to satisfy my opinion, and partly for the satisfaction, look you, of my mind, as touching the direction of the military discipline, that is the point.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A thin face, which you don’t have; a sleepless, sunken eye, which you don’t have; an irritable temper, which you don’t have; a neglected beard, which you don’t have—but that might not be so telling, since you don’t have much beard anyway.
target: A lean cheek, which you have not; a blue eye and sunken, which you have not; an unquestionable spirit, which you have not; a beard neglected, which you have not—but I pardon you for that, for simply your having in beard is a younger brother’s revenue.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Each day new widows howl, new orphans cry, and new sorrows slap heaven in the face, until it sounds like heaven itself feels Scotland’s anguish and screams in pain.
target: Each new morn New widows howl, new orphans cry, new sorrows Strike heaven on the face, that it resounds As if it felt with Scotland and yelled out Like syllable of dolor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The harvest comes shortly after that.

target: I prithee, Remember I have done thee worthy service, Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served Without or grudge or grumblings.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If it’s possible to do this without putting yourself in danger, dear Captain Blunt, say goodnight to him from me and give him this important note.
target: If without peril it be possible, Sweet Blunt, make some good means to speak with him, And give him from me this most needful note.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ever since these deadly conflicts erupted between your violent countrymen and ours, both you Syracusians and we Ephesians have held serious councils and decided not to permit any travel between our two hostile towns.
target: For, since the mortal and intestine jars 'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us, It hath in solemn synods been decreed Both by the Syracusians and ourselves, To admit no traffic to our adverse towns.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bellario sends his greetings.
target: Bellario greets your grace.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I asked you for gold to pay my soldiers, and you wouldn’t give it to me.
target: I did send To you for gold to pay my legions, Which you denied me.

target: He’ll speak with you, will you or no.

target: Yond same black cloud, yond huge one, looks like a foul bombard that would shed his liquor.

target: To show an unfelt sorrow is an office Which the false man does easy.

target: I beseech you pardon me, my lord, if I be mistaken—for my duty cannot be silent when I think your highness wronged.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And you’ll speak on the same platform as I do, after I’m done.
target: And you shall speak In the same pulpit whereto I am going, After my speech is ended.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, that’s a joke made out of leather that spreads itself thin, from the width of an inch to as fat as a yard.
target: Oh, here’s a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an inch narrow to an ell broad!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll say goodbye once more.
target: I once more take my leave.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Reading their mail isn’t as bad.
target: Their papers is more lawful.

target: Shylock, there’s thrice thy money offered thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He swore that he’d never get married, but now, despite his earlier protestations, he loves ungrudgingly.
target: He swore he would never marry, and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats his meat without grudging.

target: Beshrew his soul for me!

target: Lady!

target: Then bring me to their sights.

target: I am an ass, indeed; you may prove it by my long ears.—I have served him from the hour of my nativity to this instant, and have nothing at his hands for my service but blows.

target: Romeo, he cries aloud, “Hold, friends!

target: Thou villain, what sayest thou?

target: Hereafter, in a better world than this, I shall desire more love and knowledge of you.

target: Fall to.

target: Give him a halter.

target: I am in my condition A prince, Miranda—I do think, a king; I would, not so!—and would no more endure This wooden slavery than to suffer The flesh-fly blow my mouth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: These men all have one intention, and it’s directed against Caesar.
target: There is but one mind in all these men, and it is bent against Caesar.

target: But jealous souls will not be answered so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, not a bit.

target: O villainy!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So go away.
target: So be gone.

target: Do not you love me?

target: Tis a naughty night to swim in.

target: No, I am promised forth.

target: Othello, leave some officer behind And he shall our commission bring to you, And such things else of quality and respect As doth import you.

target: Monster, your fairy, which you say is a harmless fairy, has done little better than played the jack with us.

target: No, sir, no jot.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In the meantime I’ll tell you all, as honestly as I confess my sins to God, how I wooed this beautiful lady, and how she came to love me.
target: And till she come, as truly as to heaven I do confess the vices of my blood So justly to your grave ears I’ll present How I did thrive in this fair lady’s love And she in mine.

target: Why then I think Cassio’s an honest man.

target: Why then, my cousin, Margaret, and Ursula Are much deceived, for they did swear you did.

target: But next day I told him of myself, which was as much As to have asked him pardon.

target: Howl, howl, howl, howl!

target: Look you, if you take the matter otherwise than is meant, Captain Macmorris, peradventure I shall think you do not use me with that affability as, in discretion, you ought to use me, look you, being as good a man as yourself, both in the disciplines of war and in the derivation of my birth and in other particularities.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good morning, cousin.

target: Gracious Olivia— What do you say, Cesario?—Good my lord— My lord would speak.

target: Canidius and the rest That fell away have entertainment but No honorable trust.

target: I thank you for your pains and courtesy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: be like the fountain that my children and all my descendants flow from, has rejected me!
target: But there where I have garnered up my heart, Where either I must live or bear no life, The fountain from the which my current runs Or else dries up—to be discarded thence!

target: Now go to the door and stay there till we call.

target: At seventeen years, many their fortunes seek, But at fourscore, it is too late a week.

target: He will keep that good name still.

target: Holy Franciscan Friar!

target: Tis bitter cold, And I am sick at heart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We both have eaten as well, and we can both endure the cold winter as well as he.
target: We both have fed as well, and we can both Endure the winter’s cold as well as he.

target: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say.

target: Thou knowest that the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a man.

target: Ay, and a kind one too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think we’ll have to leave out all the killing, come to think of it.
target: I believe we must leave the killing out, when all is done.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Callow youth, you don’t yet know how to love!
target: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.   Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.

target: Come, Menas.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The king my father?!
target: The king my father?!

target: Away, make haste.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh sweet Nurse, what news do you bring?
target: O God, she comes.—O honey Nurse, what news?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s what I conceive of him.
target: Thus I conceive by him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is Scotland the same as when I left it?
target: Stands Scotland where it did?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lucius, wake up!
target: Lucius, awake.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hereby grant your request, and hope you have a good time.
target: What dost you mean by this?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And what is this useless ceremony of kings?
target: And what art thou, thou idol ceremony?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But she’s modest and ladylike too.
target: An inviting eye, and yet methinks right modest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This disrespectful stance toward the man who is your lord, your king, your governor tarnishes your beauty the way the frosts of winter blights the land.
target: Unknit that threat'ning unkind brow And dart not scornful glances from those eyes To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I like your new wig and headdress, though I’d like it more if the hair were a shade browner.
target: I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair were a thought browner; and your gown’s a most rare fashion, i' faith.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How many people who are humble now would be great then?
target: How many then should cover that stand bare!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As I came down?
target: As I descended?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you really saying these things, or am I dreaming?
target: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Me, “greedy”!
target: I “an itching palm”!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You have to stop talking like this.
target: You must leave this.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Absolutely.
target: Most certain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you mean?
target: What is ’t you say?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll think over what you’ve said, I’ll listen patiently to whatever else you have to say, and I’ll find a good time for us to discuss further such weighty matters.
target: What you have said I will consider, what you have to say I will with patience hear, and find a time Both meet to hear and answer such high things.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get into your cold beds and warm yourselves up.
target: Go to thy cold bed and warm thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And I swear by my wickedness (if I had any) that I am a knave.
target: By my knavery (if I had it), then I were.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s a proper count, that Count Sugarplum, a sweet gentleman, for sure!
target: Surely, a princely testimony, a goodly count, Count Comfect, a sweet gallant, surely!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Nothing is what it is.
target: Nothing that is so is so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t trust you.
target: I fear your disposition.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It isn’t proper for you to know how much Caesar loved you.
target: It is not meet you know how Caesar loved you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, you speak like an experienced and quiet watchman.
target: Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet watchman, for I cannot see how sleeping should offend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take me to Antony.
target: Bring me to Antony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who calls so coldly?
target: Who is that calls so coldly?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Speak one rhyme, and I’ll be satisfied.
target: Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve been stripped of everything, betrayed.
target: Betrayed I am.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Cheer up as much as you can.
target: Receive what cheer you may.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll give him equal thanks, so we’re even.
target: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Name one.
target: Faith, none but Humfrey Hower, that called your Grace To breakfast once, forth of my company.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He only lived long enough to become a man, and as soon as he proved that he was a man by fighting like one, he died.
target: He only lived but till he was a man, The which no sooner had his prowess confirmed In the unshrinking station where he fought, But like a man he died.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But, hang on!
target: But, soft!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do whatever you want, and I’ll say your insults are just a bad mood.
target: Do what you will, dishonor shall be humor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Regan, I hope you didn’t know anything about that.—Ah, who’s this?
target: Regan, I have good hope Thou didst not know on ’t.—Who comes here?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye.
target: Fare thee well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s leave him.
target: Let us leave him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have to eat my dinner now.
target: I must eat my dinner.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He ran this way and jumped over this orchard wall.
target: He ran this way and leapt this orchard wall.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown—though it wasn’t a real crown, just a small circlet—and, as I told you, he refused it once—though in my opinion he would’ve liked to have it.
target: I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown (yet ’twas not a crown neither, ’twas one of these coronets) and, as I told you, he put it by once—but, for all that, to my thinking, he would fain have had it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I could imagine he’s divine, since I never saw anything so noble-looking on earth before.
target: I might call him A thing divine, for nothing natural I ever saw so noble.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t even know how much I’m spending to find them.
target: And I know not what’s spent in the search.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m in a good mood now and likely to give you what you want.
target: Come, woo me, woo me, for now I am in a holiday humor, and like enough to consent.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I believe you, and I ask you to forgive me.
target: I do believe it, and I ask your pardon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What are you going to do for a father?
target: How wilt thou do for a father?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, death is the end for everybody.
target: Death’s the end of all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hello there, sir!
target: How now, sir?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have mercy, Jesus!—Wait, I was only dreaming.
target: Have mercy, Jesu!—Soft, I did but dream.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll be right here, silent.
target: And so am I revenged.—That would be scanned.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here it is.

target: Even now a tailor called me in his shop And showed me silks that he had bought for me, And therewithal took measure of my body.

target: Good madam, let me see your face.

target: Would thou’dst be ruled by me!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Pour in the blood of a sow who has eaten her nine offspring.
target: Pour in sow’s blood, that hath eaten Her nine farrow; grease that’s sweaten From the murderer’s gibbet throw Into the flame.

target: Virtue that transgresses is but patched with sin, and sin that amends is but patched with virtue.

target: Son, I’ll be your half Bianca comes.

target: He is as full of valor as of kindness, Princely in both.

target: If you come slack of former services, You shall do well.

target: Hymen from heaven brought her, Yea, brought her hither, That thou mightst join her hand with his Whose heart within his bosom is.

target: They did, Fluellen.

target: A likely piece of work, that you should find it in your chamber, and not know who left it there!

target: Then to have seen much and to have nothing is to have rich eyes and poor hands.

target: Five shillings to one on ’t, with any man that knows the statutes, he may stay him—marry, not without the Prince be willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man, and it is an offense to stay a man against his will.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If his cause is wrong, our obedience to the king clears us of responsibility for it.
target: If his cause be wrong, our obedience to the king wipes the crime of it out of us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Talk to the ambassadors who’ve just come back: ask them how majestically he responded to their message, how well supplied he was with good advisors, how restrained in expressing his displeasure, and, moreover, how terrifyingly firm he was in his resolve.
target: Question your Grace the late ambassadors With what great state he heard their embassy, How well supplied with noble counselors, How modest in exception, and withal How terrible in constant resolution, And you shall find his vanities forespent Were but the outside of the Roman Brutus, Covering discretion with a coat of folly, As gardeners do with ordure hide those roots That shall first spring and be most delicate.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll tell you at a better time.

target: I doubt it not, sir, but you will curse your wooing.— Neighbor, this is a gift very grateful, I am sure of it.

target: Hear a little further And then I’ll bring thee to the present business Which now ’s upon ’s, without the which this story Were most impertinent.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hastings and Edward’s children, Rivers and Grey, holy King Henry and your fine son Edward, Vaughan, and all who have died from underhanded, corrupt, fiendish injustice, if your angry souls are witnessing this moment through the clouds, enjoy the revenge—laugh at my ruin!
target: Hastings and Edward’s children, Grey and Rivers, Holy King Henry and thy fair son Edward, Vaughan, and all that have miscarrièd By underhand, corrupted, foul injustice, If that your moody, discontented souls Do through the clouds behold this present hour, Even for revenge mock my destruction.— This is All Souls' Day, fellow, is it not?
