source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ve won the wager, and I will add twenty thousand crowns to what they owe you.
target: The wager thou hast won, and I will add Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns, Another dowry to another daughter, For she is changed as she had never been.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you think, girl!
target: What, girl, though gray Do something mingle with our younger brown, yet ha’ we A brain that nourishes our nerves and can Get goal for goal of youth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No more, please.
target: On my knees I beg That you’ll vouchsafe me raiment, bed, and food.” Good sir, no more.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That light we see is coming from my hall.
target: That light we see is burning in my hall.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What an idiot that monster is!
target: That a monster should be such a natural!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you say now?
target: How say you now?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I suffered along with all the men I watched suffer!
target: Oh, I have suffered With those that I saw suffer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When such a great man dies there should be a thunderclap.
target: The breaking of so great a thing should make A greater crack.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He is indeed worthy of the name “horse,” and you can call all the rest beasts.
target: He is indeed a horse, and all other jades you may call beasts.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The weather is fair.
target: The morn is fair.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who, Hero?
target: Who, Hero?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know you know something— Thanks for the compliment, I’m happy you know that.
target: I know you are not ignorant— I would you did, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Clever lies.
target: And false.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Holy Father Lawrence instructed me to fall on my knees and beg your forgiveness.
target: Where I have learned me to repent the sin Of disobedient opposition To you and your behests, and am enjoined By holy Lawrence to fall prostrate here To beg your pardon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Won’t King Richard let me speak with him?
target: Will not King Richard let me speak with him?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I put my trust in you.
target: I will lay trust upon thee, and thou shalt find a dearer father in my love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Remember you!
target: Remember thee!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your servant Kent.
target: Your servant Kent.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Just as you’d like to have your sins forgiven, Indulge me, forgive me, and set me free.
target: As you from crimes would pardoned be, Let your indulgence set me free.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Young people often lose their self-control even without any help from others.
target: Youth to itself rebels, though none else near.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bring your master home.
target: Fetch thy master home.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here’s Romeo’s man.
target: Here’s Romeo’s man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s cheap and nasty!
target: Fie, fie, ’tis lewd and filthy!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Has it come to this?
target: Is it come to this?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh Iago!
target: O Iago!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You corrupt judge, why did you let her escape?
target: False justicer, why hast thou let her ’scape?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Romeo killed Tybalt.
target: Romeo slew Tybalt.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The mayor is here at hand.
target: The mayor is here at hand.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Quiet!
target: Peace!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, aren’t you a good man?
target: Are you not good?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Like love, my lord, before it learns to love.
target: As love is, my lord, before it loves.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Believe me, I’ll draw my sword as quick as any other man if I see a fight starting and the law is on my side.
target: I dare draw as soon as another man if I see occasion in a good quarrel and the law on my side.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hate him so much it makes me sick, and whoever can ruin his happiness will make me happy.
target: I am sick in displeasure to him, and whatsoever comes athwart his affection ranges evenly with mine.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, Regan, Goneril, your kind old father whose generous heart gave you everything—Oh, if I think about that I’ll go mad.
target: O Regan, Goneril, Your old kind father, whose frank heart gave all— Oh, that way madness lies.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You talk to him, ma'am.
target: Madam, do you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll get him to come here, and you can ask him yourself.
target: I will send for him, and question him yourself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, you’re a fool, and driven to extreme measures by love.
target: Come, come, you are a fool, And turned into the extremity of love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are my master and his wife coming, Grumio?
target: Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How can I marry him, this husband, before he comes to court me?
target: I wonder at this haste, that I must wed Ere he, that should be husband, comes to woo.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You sent me to the port to find a ship.
target: You sent me to the bay, sir, for a bark.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What is, my lord?
target: What is, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take whatever wife you want to bed with you, You’ll have a fool’s head forever.
target: Take what wife you will to bed, I will ever be your head.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stay here at your own risk.
target: Stay, on thy peril.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: O, this evil wind that spreads nothing but misery.
target: O ill-dispersing wind of misery!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t, ma'am.
target: I may not, madam.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Or are we both on drugs?
target: Or have we eaten on the insane root That takes the reason prisoner?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll hold on to your money and leave you for an hour.
target: I’ll be your purse-bearer and leave you For an hour.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All this suggests that she has a good reason for doing this to you.
target: And doubt not, sir, but she will well excuse Why at this time the doors are made against you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But ships are just fragile boards, and sailors are just men.
target: But ships are but boards, sailors but men.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ve never thought of me like that, and you have no reason to.
target: You have not called me so, nor have you cause.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I will go out, for these bad omens apply to the world in general as much as they do to me.
target: Yet Caesar shall go forth, for these predictions Are to the world in general as to Caesar.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I beg your
target: I do beseech your Grace to pardon me, and withal Forbear your conference with the noble duke.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That was my turquoise ring!
target: It was my turquoise.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’s no crab-apple here, so don’t look sour.
target: Why, here’s no crab, and therefore look not sour.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s only going to make you sad, Monsieur Jaques.
target: It will make you melancholy, Monsieur Jaques.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Quiet!
target: Hush!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The fact that he serves as a go-between for his lord and my niece Olivia confirms this.
target: His employment between his lord and my niece confirms no less.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.
target: Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t play any nasty tricks on me.
target: Do me no foul play, friends.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But don’t be too tame, either—let your good sense guide you.
target: Be not too tame neither, but let your own discretion be your tutor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell her that I’ve been arrested and the money will be my bail.
target: Tell her I am arrested in the street, And that shall bail me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ungodly and monstrous!
target: Most heathenish and most gross!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell her my love is purer than anything else in the whole world, and has nothing to do with her property.
target: Tell her my love, more noble than the world, Prizes not quantity of dirty lands; The parts that fortune hath bestowed upon her, Tell her, I hold as giddily as fortune; But ’tis that miracle and queen of gems That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye!
target: Oh, farewell!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That rotten scoundrel!
target: Scurvy knave!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tom’s chilly.
target: Tom’s a- cold.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think he must have turned into an animal, because I can’t find him anywhere looking like a man.
target: I think he be transformed into a beast, For I can nowhere find him like a man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can’t he pay back the money?
target: Is he not able to discharge the money?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If she and I are happy, what’s it to you?
target: If she and I be pleased, what’s that to you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Or, if you don’t delay, make my wedding bed in the tomb where Tybalt lies.
target: Or, if you do not, make the bridal bed In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s doubly wrong to cheat on your wife and then let her see the offense in your eyes.
target: Tis double wrong to truant with your bed And let her read it in thy looks at board.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Doesn’t he deserve it?
target: Doth he not deserve well?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, it heals gradually.
target: What wound did ever heal but by degrees?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Help!
target: Help, ho, help!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s not true.
target: Tis false.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But what am I afraid of?
target: What do I fear?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d bet my life that, as young as you are, you’ve fallen in love with someone.
target: My life upon ’t, young though thou art, thine eye Hath stay’d upon some favor that it loves.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But he’s not better than mine.
target: No better.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can only do it by lying, my lord, but I can do it so secretly that no one will suspect me.
target: Not honestly, my lord, but so covertly that no dishonesty shall appear in me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Drive it out of you.
target: Self-harming jealousy, fie, beat it hence.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I didn’t see him.
target: I saw him not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you want to sleep?
target: Apollo plays, And twenty cagèd nightingales do sing: Or wilt thou sleep?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You look happier already, and I’ll be back quickly.
target: Thou look’st cheerly, and I’ll be with thee quickly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I won’t live long enough, and all my efforts will fail me.
target: My life will be too short, And every measure fail me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Under Captain Gower, my liege.
target: Under Captain Gower, my liege.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When all these extraordinary things happen at once, we shouldn’t say, “These happenings can be explained rationally.
target: When these prodigies Do so conjointly meet, let not men say, “These are their reasons.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Their shadows are like a deadly canopy, under which our army lies, ready to die.
target: Their shadows seem A canopy most fatal, under which Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: On my life I swear to you that your youngest daughter doesn’t love you least.
target: Answer my life my judgment, Thy youngest daughter does not love thee least, Nor are those empty-hearted whose low sound Reverbs no hollowness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good idea.
target: Well thought on.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, God!
target: Heaven and earth!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hurry, hurry—prepare my horse.
target: Come, bustle, bustle.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll finish my lecture after dinner.
target: I’ll end my exhortation after dinner.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I would not.
target: I would not see ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who here is so low that he wants to be a slave?
target: Who is here so base that would be a bondman?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The glowworm’s light is beginning to fade, so morning is near.
target: The glowworm shows the matin to be near, And 'gins to pale his uneffectual fire.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You will feel the loss, but the man you weep for will feel nothing.
target: So shall you feel the loss, but not the friend Which you weep for.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Easy, Petruchio.
target: I am Grumio’s pledge.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, sir, I live by the church.
target: No, sir, I live by the church.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Both, both, my girl.
target: Both, both, my girl.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is this the family tomb of Leonato?
target: Is this the monument of Leonato?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And even though you know I’m very close to the Prince and Claudio, I swear I’ll keep your counsel and deal with this secretly and justly.
target: And though you know my inwardness and love Is very much unto the Prince and Claudio, Yet, by mine honor, I will deal in this As secretly and justly as your soul Should with your body.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But do you mean what you’re saying?
target: But goes thy heart with this?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, my good lord.
target: Ay, my good lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve said too much in telling you of it.
target: I have o'ershot myself to tell you of it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I do believe your Majesty takes no shame in wearing the leek on Saint Davy’s Day.
target: And I do believe your Majesty takes no scorn to wear the leek upon Saint Tavy’s day.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is she dead?
target: Dead?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, enough about them.—Come here, Catesby.
target: Well, let them rest.—Come hither, Catesby.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, some of it is about my child’s father.
target: No, some of it is for my child’s father.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now any effort ruins what it attempts.
target: Now all labor Mars what it does.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, you devil, you devil!
target: Oh, devil, devil!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m biting my thumb.
target: I do bite my thumb, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Will we be separated?
target: Shall we be sundered?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s a big prize for such a small sin.
target: It is a great price for a small vice.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your clothes aren’t spattered with my family’s blood, and you aren’t affected by my curse.
target: Thy garments are not spotted with our blood, Nor thou within the compass of my curse.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t wait to hear him call the drunkard “husband,” and to watch my men smother their laughter as they pay their respects to this simple peasant.
target: I long to hear him call the drunkard “husband,” And how my men will stay themselves from laughter When they do homage to this simple peasant.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wouldn’t it be better—since I’m unusually tall for a woman—to dress myself like a man?
target: Were it not better, Because that I am more than common tall, That I did suit me all points like a man?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Even  What, were you all snarling before I arrived, ready to catch each other by the throat like dogs, but now that I’m here, you turn your hatred toward me?
target: What, were you snarling all before I came, Ready to catch each other by the throat, And turn you all your hatred now on me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did he lose his other eye?
target: One way I like this well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ll get some of what you want.
target: You shall have some part of your will.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is it feasible?
target: Is it within reason and compass?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: These are gracious tears.
target: These are gracious drops.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You knew my father well; therefore, you know me, the sole heir to all his property and possessions, which I have added to rather than depleted.
target: You knew my father well, and in him me, Left solely heir to all his lands and goods, Which I have bettered rather than decreased.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It shall be seven o'clock before I get on my horse.
target: It shall be seven ere I go to horse.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And her cook yelled, mocked, and teased me, right?
target: Did not her kitchen maid rail, taunt, and scorn me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You know from my clothing who I am.
target: You know me by my habit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I guess now she’s going to be my sister-in-law and not my wife.
target: She now shall be my sister, not my wife.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you mean I faked you out?
target: What counterfeit did I give you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tybalt wanted to kill you, but you killed Tybalt.
target: Tybalt would kill thee, But thou slew’st Tybalt—there art thou happy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Though that must have been a pitiful sight, the ground looked beautiful.
target: Though it be pity to see such a sight, it well becomes the ground.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have them come in front of the master constable.
target: Let them come before Master Constable.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I love to argue with him when he’s having one of these fits, because then he always has a lot to say.
target: I love to cope him in these sullen fits, For then he’s full of matter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where, sir?
target: Where, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I had seen something like that, I would have quickly pulled out my weapon.
target: If I had, my weapon should quickly have been out, I warrant you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Cassio doesn’t know you.
target: Cassio knows you not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Or in the power of reason.
target: And never could maintain his part but in the force of his will.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll go and join my men.
target: I’ll to my charge.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who asked you to call her?
target: Who bids thee call?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But he isn’t here now.
target: He is not here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, I won’t take it any longer.
target: I will indeed no longer endure it, nor am I yet persuaded to put up in peace what already I have foolishly suffered.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go.
target: Yet I will adventure.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now sit down, everybody, and rehearse your parts—Pyramus, you start.
target: Come, sit down, every mother’s son, and rehearse your parts.—Pyramus, you begin.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did you call me?
target: Call you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good afternoon, fair lady.
target: God ye good e'en, fair gentlewoman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell us what happened today that put Caesar in such a serious mood.
target: Tell us what hath chanced today That Caesar looks so sad.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who put out the light?
target: Who did strike out the light?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get up and listen to me.
target: Rise, and lend thine ear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, time is the old judge that tries your kind of criminal.
target: Well, time is the old justice that examines all such offenders, and let time try.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll be back soon to wake up your generosity.
target: But, as you say, sir, let your bounty take a nap, I will awake it anon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wear it with pride, for I am Welsh you know, good countryman.
target: I wear it for a memorable honor, For I am Welsh, you know, good countryman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t have the thing that makes time fly.
target: Not having that which, having, makes them short.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I may command the one I love.” Well, she commands me.
target: I may command where I adore.” Why, she may command me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sit down, Jessica.
target: Sit, Jessica.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll tell him all of this, dear lady.
target: This I’ll report, dear lady.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, his cuckold’s horns, of course—the kind you men are always blaming on your wives.
target: Why, horns, which such as you are fain to be beholding to your wives for.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our friends are all waiting for you.
target: Our friends all stay for you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can command a beggar to bow on bended knee, but can you take possession of his health?
target: Canst thou, when thou command’st the beggar’s knee, Command the health of it?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He took aim at a beautiful young virgin who was sitting on a throne in the western part of the world, and he shot his arrow of love well enough to have pierced a hundred thousand hearts.
target: A certain aim he took At a fair vestal thronèd by the west, And loosed his love shaft smartly from his bow As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His military understanding is all theory, no practice.
target: Mere prattle without practice Is all his soldiership.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You have a noble wife who is much more beautiful than any other woman in this declining age.
target: Thou hast a lady far more beautiful Than any woman in this waning age.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, right now.
target: Presently.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Claudio?
target: Count Claudio?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Alright, let’s fight, boy!
target: Then have at thee, boy!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You have to be patient with me.
target: Thou must be patient.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m beginning to understand what you want me to do.
target: What you would work me to, I have some aim.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: From this moment on I have a higher opinion of you than before.
target: Why, now I see there’s mettle in thee, and even from this instant to build on thee a better opinion than ever before.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Petruchio?
target: That Petruchio came?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ll see shortly how the murderer wins the love of Gonzago’s wife.
target: You shall see anon how the murderer gets the love of Gonzago’s wife.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What is it, Octavia?
target: What, Octavia?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I appreciate your frankness and your brevity.
target: Your plainness and your shortness please me well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She was worried about my absence, and about the fact that young Octavius and Mark Antony have grown so strong—which I found out at the same time as the news of her death.
target: Impatient of my absence, And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony Have made themselves so strong—for with her death That tidings came—with this she fell distract And, her attendants absent, swallowed fire.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye, sir.
target: Sir, fare you well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In every good thing they do.
target: In every good thing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, at Philippi.
target: Ay, at Philippi.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But fortune could not reward me better than to let me die well, without owing my master anything.
target: Yet fortune cannot recompense me better Than to die well, and not my master’s debtor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can’t blame anyone for it anyone, I say.
target: None does offend—none, I say, none.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What were those things?
target: What were these?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hortensio
target: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But you have all the advantages from the harm done.
target: Yet you have all the vantage of her wrong.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now what?
target: But who comes here?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s my prisoner and you can’t have him.
target: He is my prisoner, and you shall not have him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ll be lord of the island then, and I’ll be your servant.
target: Thou shalt be lord of it and I’ll serve thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know the real reason.
target: His reason well I know.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t find it.
target: I cannot find it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, Syracusian, tell us–briefly–why you left your hometown and came to Ephesus.
target: Well, Syracusian, say in brief the cause Why thou dep-artedst from thy native home And for what cause thou camest to Ephesus.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where?
target: Whither?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good Lord, how bright and splendid is the moon tonight!
target: Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Kate is as straight and slender as a hazel-twig, her hair as brown as hazelnut shells, and she herself sweeter than the kernels.
target: Kate like the hazel-twig Is straight and slender and as brown in hue As hazel nuts, and sweeter than the kernels.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And you saw how the beggar ran from the mutt?
target: And the creature run from the cur?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s not talk about it.
target: No more of that.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thank you.
target: The  I thank you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me the vial.
target: No warmth, no breath shall testify thou livest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dear Mr. Fabian, do me another favor first.
target: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As king of this country I like to reward wit when I hear it.
target: Wit shall not go unrewarded while I am king of this country.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why has all this been put on the table?
target: Why is this “impawned,” as you call it?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shame, eternal shame, and nothing but shame!
target: Shame, and eternal shame, nothing but shame!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know him well by reputation.
target: By report I know him well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Since Macbeth went to war, I have seen her rise from her bed, put on her nightgown, unlock her closet, take out some paper, fold it, write on it, read it, seal it up, and then return to bed, remaining asleep the entire time.
target: Since his majesty went into the field, I have seen her rise from her bed, throw her nightgown upon her, unlock her closet, take forth paper, fold it, write upon ’t, read it, afterwards seal it, and again return to bed; yet all this while in a most fast sleep.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m going to stand so I can see him pass on the way to the Capitol.
target: I go to take my stand To see him pass on to the Capitol.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He lets the bird hop a little from his hand and then yanks him back by a string.
target: And yet no further than a wanton’s bird, That lets it hop a little from his hand Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves, And with a silken thread plucks it back again, So loving-jealous of his liberty.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stop eating?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now that he’s old, we can expect to have to deal not only with his old character flaws, which have turned into deep-rooted habits, but also with the uncontrollable crabbiness that comes with old age.
target: Then must we look from his age to receive not alone the imperfections of long-engrafted condition, but therewithal the unruly waywardness that infirm and choleric years bring with them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sin from my lips?
target: Sin from thy lips?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think I hear Antony call me.
target: Methinks I hear Antony call.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And as you said (and you said it wisely), it’s good to have someone other than a mother listening in on them, since she can be too partial to him.
target: And, as you said (and wisely was it said) 'Tis meet that some more audience than a mother— Since nature makes them partial—should o'erhear The speech, of vantage.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I swear to God, madam, you’ve wronged me, and I’ll tell the whole world.
target: By the Lord, madam, you wrong me, and the world shall know it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, not a sad song.
target: Not a dump, we.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sometimes all I want to do is see plays and go out dancing.
target: I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You gentle Romans— Quiet there!
target: You gentle Romans—     Peace, ho!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How’s the queen?
target: How does the queen?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A two-hundred-year-old witch sewed it while she was in a fevered trance.
target: A sibyl, that had numbered in the world The sun to course two hundred compasses, In her prophetic fury sewed the work.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good night, good night.
target: Good night, good night.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me see Philostrate.
target: Call Philostrate.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is what happens when you visit whores.
target: This is the fruits of whoring.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You go pale, you stare, and you act in awe of the strange disturbance in the heavens.
target: You look pale, and gaze, And put on fear, and cast yourself in wonder To see the strange impatience of the heavens.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s the deal.
target: So is the bargain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You knew—no one knew, no one knew as well as you did—about my daughter’s plans to run away.
target: You knew—none so well, none so well as you—of my daughter’s flight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go ahead, you fool.
target: Here is thy fee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why?
target: Thy adversary’s wife doth pray for thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good.
target: Good.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s new with you?
target: What’s the news with thee?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s enough, Dromio, please.
target: Come, Dromio, come, these jests are out of season.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He loves to hear me tell him how men can be snared by flatterers, just like unicorns can be captured in trees, elephants in holes, and lions with nets.
target: For he loves to hear That unicorns may be betrayed with trees, And bears with glasses, elephants with holes, Lions with toils, and men with flatterers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, my son, my son!
target: O my son, my son!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You said it when you were furious.
target: That was in thy rage.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I must go report what happened.
target: I must needs report the truth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why are you enraged?
target: Why art thou angry?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I doubt it.
target: I do not think ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Nothing that interests me, my good lord.
target: Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Beat—
target: Beat—

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And here I am, with that piece.
target: To a rope’s end, sir, and to that end am I returned.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good shining, Moon!—Really, the Moon shines very well.
target: Well shone, Moon!—Truly, the moon shines with a good grace.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They are, my lord.
target: They are, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If so, when it’s day, where are you going to find a cave dark enough to hide your monstrous face?
target: O, then by day Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough To mask thy monstrous visage?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you say to that, Malvolio?
target: How say you to that, Malvolio?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Kind and dear princess!
target: Kind and dear princess!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is the building of your love already in ruins?
target: Shall, Antipholus, Even in the spring of love thy love-springs rot?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hortensio, good friends like us can get by on a few words.
target: Signior Hortensio, ’twixt such friends as we Few words suffice.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But his kindness was nobler than even his desire for revenge, his natural goodness was stronger than his need to give his brother what he deserved.
target: Twice did he turn his back and purposed so, But kindness, nobler ever than revenge, And nature, stronger than his just occasion, Made him give battle to the lioness, Who quickly fell before him; in which hurtling, From miserable slumber I awaked.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We don’t have any music that can’t be heard.
target: We have none such, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Anger does not protect the angry well.
target: Never anger Made good guard for itself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And women.
target: And of women.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve said what I have to say.
target: I have said.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m going to get my  Please, listen to me.
target: I pray thee, hear me speak.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But come on, inconsistent young man, come with me.
target: But come, young waverer, come, go with me, In one respect I’ll thy assistant be, For this alliance may so happy prove To turn your households' rancor to pure love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get out!
target: Unreal mockery, hence!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can stand in his place.
target: Do thou for him stand.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In the meantime, think about how I can do you good and give you what you want.
target: Meantime, but think how I may do thee good, And be inheritor of thy desire.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did you kill him, then?
target: Hast thou slain him then?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Truthfully, my name is Cinna.
target: Truly, my name is Cinna.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is it true that good King Edward has died?
target: Doth this news hold of good King Edward’s death?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re acting like an ass, don’t you think?
target: You see an ass head of your own, do you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes,” said my uncle Gloucester, “Small plants are graceful, while ugly weeds grow fast.” And since then, I’ve wished I wouldn’t grow so fast, because sweet flowers are slow while the weeds grow in a hurry.
target: Grandam, one night as we did sit at supper, My uncle Rivers talked how I did grow More than my brother: “Ay,” quoth my uncle Gloucester, “Small herbs have grace; great weeds do grow apace.” And since, methinks I would not grow so fast Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And when that time comes, then you can mock me, but please don’t pity me, because I won’t pity you.
target: And when that time comes, Afflict me with thy mocks, pity me not, As till that time I shall not pity thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your lives are over.
target: The limit of your lives is out.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, my friends praise me and make me look like an idiot, while my enemies tell me straightforwardly that I am an idiot.
target: Marry, sir, they praise me and make an ass of me, now my foes tell me plainly I am an ass.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You must be the one who laughs when boys or women tell you their dreams.
target: You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, would that have fixed my hair?
target: Why, would that have mended my hair?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They’ve switched their operation to the sea today.
target: Their preparation is today by sea.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A crow without feathers?
target: A crow without feather?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Very near, my master.
target: Close by, my master.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I stay longer, I’ll embarrass you and disgrace myself by crying.
target: I am so much a fool, should I stay longer It would be my disgrace and your discomfort.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who is so low that he wouldn’t?
target: What bastard doth not?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your wife and children were savagely slaughtered.
target: Your castle is surprised, your wife and babes Savagely slaughtered.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s not wise enough to be brave.
target: His discretion, I am sure, cannot carry his valor, for the goose carries not the fox.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Demetrius loves her, and he doesn’t love you.
target: Demetrius loves her, and he loves not you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Richmond is sailing on the sea.
target: Richmond is on the seas.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come here, Sir Seacole.
target: Come hither, neighbor Seacole.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If not, to tell you I will die is true, but not for love, by God.
target: If not, to say to thee that I shall die is true, but for thy love, by the Lord, no.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It is.
target: It is.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hello, everyone!
target: The goodness of the night upon you, friends!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But here’s a paper with Caesar’s seal on it.
target: But here’s a parchment with the seal of Caesar.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m your little dog, Demetrius.
target: I am your spaniel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me live here forever.
target: Let me live here ever.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your vote will be as strong as anyone’s in the reordering of the government.
target: Your voice shall be as strong as any man’s In the disposing of new dignities.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Does anyone know if Donalbain is with his brother?
target: Who knows if Donalbain be with his brother?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who were you chasing with your sword?
target: What was he that you followed with your sword?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Life is a story told by an idiot, full of noise and emotional disturbance but devoid of meaning.
target: It is a tale Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, Signifying nothing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, I swear, I’m so angry that I’m shaking all over.
target: Now, afore God, I am so vexed that every part about me quivers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’s magic in its fabric.
target: There’s magic in the web of it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll be there shortly.
target: Dismiss your attendant there, look ’t be done.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your husband knew about everything.
target: Thy husband knew it all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll stop your mouth with a kiss.
target: I will stop your mouth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s gone forever.
target: She’s gone forever.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s this?
target: Ha!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I don’t think it’ll hurt him to tell the truth.
target: Yet I persuade myself to speak the truth Shall nothing wrong him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s there?
target: Who’s there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look how shapely your legs are.
target: I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy leg, it was formed under the star of a galliard.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I bet my life some evil busybody, some meddling, lying jerk made up this rumor to get some position.
target: I will be hanged, if some eternal villain, Some busy and insinuating rogue, Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office, Have not devised this slander.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Quickly, quickly, good Iras, quickly.
target: Yare, yare, good Iras, quick.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, I’d rather you stayed here.
target: By your patience, no.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And I beg you, please come here again tomorrow.
target: And I beseech you come again tomorrow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, no, I’m as ugly as a bear, since animals that see me run away in terror.
target: No, no, I am as ugly as a bear, For beasts that meet me run away for fear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: See the wound that Casca made.
target: See what a rent the envious Casca made.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, most noble Brutus, the gods are friendly with us today so that we, who want peace, can live on to old age!
target: Now, most noble Brutus, The gods today stand friendly that we may, Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m tired of this moon.
target: I am aweary of this moon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If only I could somehow relate them to me!
target: If I could make that resemble something in me—Softly!

target: I’ll read the writing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s that noise?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Away, away, be gone.
target: Away, away, be gone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Just to the Tower—I’m guessing, for the same reason you are: to salute the noble princes who are staying there.
target: No farther than the Tower, and, as I guess, Upon the like devotion as yourselves, To gratulate the gentle princes there.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, for Pete’s sake!
target: O heavens!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You and I have heard our fathers talk of another Brutus—your ancestor—who would’ve let the devil himself reign in his Roman Republic before he let a king rule.
target: Oh, you and I have heard our fathers say, There was a Brutus once that would have brooked Th' eternal devil to keep his state in Rome As easily as a king.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is Claudio your enemy?
target: Is Claudio thine enemy?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m dying an innocent woman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go.
target: Go.

target: O, good sir, I do.

target: Go, bind this man, for he is frantic too.

target: He taught me how to know a man in love, in which cage of rushes I am sure you are not prisoner.

target: You are, and do not know ’t.

target: There is ten thousand— Geese, villain?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I humbly thank you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m afraid that may be the case, madam.
target: Tis to be doubted, madam.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The law has another hold on you.
target: The law hath yet another hold on you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: An era of universal peace is about to start.
target: The time of universal peace is near.

target: Ere the bat hath flown His cloistered flight, ere to black Hecate’s summons The shard-borne beetle with his drowsy hums Hath rung night’s yawning peal, there shall be done A deed of dreadful note.

target: There, drink that for me.

target: Richard of York, how fares our loving brother?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here’s the east.

target: My soul, and not my child!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You don’t?

target: Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!

target: O Charmian, I will never go from hence.

target: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look, love, see how devoted I am?
target: Here love, thou seest how diligent I am, To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee.

target: A thing for me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And the poor old man just wept, mixing his tears with the rain.
target: Yet poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And as you know, his connections, if he put them to good use, might be enough to hurt us all.
target: And, you know, his means, If he improve them, may well stretch so far As to annoy us all; which to prevent, Let Antony and Caesar fall together.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you hear that, men?
target: Do you hear, masters?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ve won.
target: Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.

target: Another way I have to man my haggard, To make her come and know her keeper’s call.

target: Why, ’tis good to be sad and say nothing.

target: Graces will appear, and there’s an end.

target: Who’s there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We have enough supplies for it, and they’ve earned it.
target: We have store to do ’t, And they have earned the waste.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d swear to you on my soul that she’s a good, honest person, sir.
target: I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest, Lay down my soul at stake.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you choose the one that contains my picture, we’ll be married right away.
target: If you choose that wherein I am contained, Straight shall our nuptial rites be solemnized.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come, let’s have an early dinner so that we have time to work out our plans.
target: Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards We may digest our complots in some form.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My words are dull.
target: My words are dull.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is Horatio here too?
target: Say what, is Horatio there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I never saw him like this before.
target: I ne'er saw this before.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get out!
target: O hated potion, hence!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I found Orlando under a tree, like a dropped acorn.
target: I found him under a tree like a dropped acorn.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish that no one could avenge my cousin’s death except me!
target: Would none but I might venge my cousin’s death!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I was ordered not to.
target: I was forbid it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What a spoiled little brat.
target: Maid’s mild behavior and sobriety.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your Emperor is still a king among gods.
target: Your Emperor Continues still a Jove.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And he would have deserved it too.
target: He would have deserved it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He smiled and said, “The better for us.” He’s right, and that’s how it is.
target: He smiled and said “The better for our purpose.” He was in the right, and so indeed it is.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, sir.
target: Ay, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If that’s what you mean, I’ll melt this gold and pour it down your throat that speaks these hateful words.
target: Bring it to that, The gold I give thee will I melt and pour Down thy ill-uttering throat.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lock yourself in and send him word that you’re dead.
target: There lock yourself and send him word you are dead.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What right did he have to scold me like that?
target: For what had he to do to chide at me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t I deserve more than this?
target: Are my deserts no better?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go there and compare her objectively to some other girls I’ll show you.
target: Go thither, and with unattainted eye Compare her face with some that I shall show, And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is this my prize?
target: Is that my prize?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But if you remember, I didn’t tell you to parody the style.
target: But if you be remembered, I did not bid you mar it to the time.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t admit that, since you’d have to compare his excellence to mine.
target: I dare not confess that lest I should compare with him in excellence, but to know a man well were to know himself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good morning, gentlemen.
target: Good morrow, masters.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And yet I would have made her happy had our luck not been so bad.
target: In Syracusa was I born, and wed Unto a woman happy but for me, And by me, had not our hap been bad.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As long as heaven and nature extend it.
target: As long as heaven and nature lengthens it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I speak to you as a plain soldier.
target: I speak to thee plain soldier.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You don’t need a ghost returning from the grave to tell you that, sir.
target: There needs no ghost, my lord, come from the grave To tell us this.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now all the young men of England are inspired and have stored their party clothes in the closet.
target: Now all the youth of England are on fire, And silken dalliance in the wardrobe lies.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, but there’s one more thing to tell you.
target: O, but one word.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If that’s true, I think the same thing about you.
target: If I think so, I think the same of you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This story breaks my heart.
target: It is a hint That wrings mine eyes to ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Victory is with us.
target: Victory sits on our helms.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then it’s no surprise they had a bad influence on him.
target: No marvel then, though he were ill affected.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But please don’t let any of your people wake me up.
target: But, I pray you, let none of your people stir me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Snip and snip and cut and slash—it’s got more holes than a sieve!
target: Here’s snip and nip and cut and slish and slash, Like to a censer in a barber’s shop.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me your hand, Roderigo.
target: Give me thy hand, Roderigo.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sometimes you get a bit too wild, and you let your voice get a bit loud and rude.
target: Thou art too wild, too rude and bold of voice— Parts that become thee happily enough And in such eyes as ours appear not faults.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did he get away clean?
target: Is he gone and hath nothing?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your horn is a foot long, and I’m at least that size.
target: Why, thy horn is a foot, and so long am I, at the least.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good spirit!
target: My brave spirit!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: First, you have to speak to the watchmen who accused them.
target: You must call forth the watch that are their accusers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me access to them, and soon you won’t have to worry about them anymore.
target: Let me have open means to come to them, And soon I’ll rid you from the fear of them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you want to know who they are, then?
target: Poor Ophelia Divided from herself and her fair judgment, Without the which we are pictures, or mere beasts.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How do you mean?
target: Say, how is that?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And yet, against all odds, I win her over!
target: And yet to win her, all the world to nothing!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where’s the gold I gave you?
target: Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m speechless.
target: I am dumb.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Those are the things we pine for now.
target: All which we pine for now.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord, could I have a word with you?
target: Good my lord, vouchsafe me a word with you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God forbid that I snatch the crown from him.
target: On him I lay what you would lay on me, The right and fortune of his happy stars, Which God defend that I should wring from him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Her eyes are saying something.
target: Her eye discourses.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, it would be impossible.
target: It is not possible.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re a cobbler, are you?
target: Thou art a cobbler, art thou?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We chase everything in life more excitedly than we actually enjoy it when we get it.
target: All things that are, Are with more spirit chasèd than enjoyed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s give them room.
target: Make good room.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can see in your eyes that you’re starving.
target: Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, it certainly wasn’t true for Richard!
target: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold In him that did object the same to thee!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is this really happening?
target: And is it thus?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s a nasty garter belt.
target: Look, he wears cruel garters.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look, my cousin is whispering to Claudio that she loves him.
target: My cousin tells him in his ear that he is in her heart.

target: He that commends me to mine own content Commends me to the thing I cannot get.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, you monstrous hags, I’ll get revenge on you both that will make the whole world… I will do such things—I don’t know what I’ll do exactly, but it’ll be devastating.
target: I will have such revenges on you both That all the world shall—I will do such things— What they are yet I know not, but they shall be The terrors of the earth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I drink to you.

target: Thou hast braved many men; brave not me.

target: Every inordinate cup is unblessed and the ingredient is a devil.

target: He lays it on.

target: Ah, Juliet, if the measure of thy joy Be heaped like mine, and that thy skill be more To blazon it, then sweeten with thy breath This neighbor air, and let rich music’s tongue Unfold the imagined happiness that both Receive in either by this dear encounter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, of course.
target: Yes, marry, sir.

target: And she’s obedient, as you say, obedient, Very obedient.—Proceed you in your tears.— Concerning this, sir—Oh, well-painted passion!— I am commanded home.—Get you away, I’ll send for you anon.—Sir, I obey the mandate And will return to Venice.—Hence, avaunt!

target: Why, here begins his morning story right; These two Antipholuses, these two so like, And these two Dromios, one in semblance— Besides her urging of her wreck at sea— These are the parents to these children, Which accidentally are met together.

target: No marvel, lord, though it affrighted you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Another case: Hugh Capet, who usurped the crown from Charles the duke of Lorraine—sole male heir in a direct line from Charles the Great—passed himself off as heir to Lady Lingare, daughter of Charlemagne, who was the son of Lewis the Emperor (who was the son of Charles the Great), in order to give his claim to the throne more validity (though, in fact, the claim was completely false and worthless).
target: Hugh Capet also, who usurped the crown Of Charles the duke of Lorraine, sole heir male Of the true line and stock of Charles the Great, To find his title with some shows of truth, Though in pure truth it was corrupt and naught, Conveyed himself as th' heir to th' Lady Lingare, Daughter to Charlemagne, who was the son To Lewis the Emperor, and Lewis the son Of Charles the Great.
