source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If my eyes don’t deceive me, you are my daughter.
target: If there be truth in sight, you are my daughter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Servants, take these gentlemen to see Hamlet.
target: Go, some of you, And bring these gentlemen where Hamlet is.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where does he sleep?
target: Where lodges he?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sorrow interrupts all hours and seasons.
target: Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours, Makes the night morning, and the noontide night.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think I see my cousin Tybalt’s ghost.
target: Methinks I see my cousin’s ghost Seeking out Romeo, that did spit his body Upon a rapier’s point.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What are you doing, old man?
target: What wouldst thou do, old man?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A gullible father and a brother who’s so innocent that he can’t suspect anyone else of wanting to hurt him—these are the two fools I need for my plan to work.
target: A credulous father, and a brother noble— Whose nature is so far from doing harms That he suspects none, on whose foolish honesty My practices ride easy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re doing the right thing.
target: You are in the right.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen to me, Beatrice— Talking with a man outside her bedroom window!
target: Hear me, Beatrice— Talk with a man out at a window!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d like to munch on some good dry oats.
target: I could munch your good dry oats.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The Lord in heaven bless you, noble Harry!
target: The Lord in heaven bless thee, noble Harry!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get up, get up, and look at this image of doomsday!
target: Up, up, and see The great doom’s image!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s the beginning of the day we see, but I don’t think we’ll see the end of it.—Who goes there?
target: We see yonder the beginning of the day, but I think we shall never see the end of it.—Who goes there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So, what’s the news on the Rialto?
target: Now, what news on the Rialto?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Signor Valentio and his cousin Tybalt, Lucio and the lively Helena.” That’s a nice group of people.
target: Seigneur Valentio and his cousin Tybalt; Lucio and the lively Helena.” A fair assembly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I were, I wouldn’t need to ask you what happened.
target: I should not then ask Casca what had chanced.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Be patient until I finish.
target: Be patient till the last.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t deny it.
target: I deny it not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Neither the sky nor the earth have been quiet tonight.
target: Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace tonight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thank you.
target: I humbly thank your ladyship.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll put it on anyway.
target: I’ll put it on.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How are you feeling now?
target: How dost thou feel thyself now?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Since she would love both of you, you two would be joined in that love.
target: Her love to both Would each to other and all loves to both Draw after her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Answer me like men.
target: Answer me like men.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Nonsense!
target: Fie, for shame!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take him to the surgeons.
target: Go get him surgeons.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you ever had a mother, come in quickly to Sir John.
target: As ever you come of women, come in quickly to Sir John.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why do you complain about your birth, the heavens, and the earth?
target: Why rail’st thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That these crimes are punished so quickly is proof.
target: Both, both, my lord.— This letter, madam, craves a speedy answer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll make ground beef out of you.
target: I’ll make a sop o' th' moonshine of you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When he leaves, it’s very important that I talk to you.
target: When he is gone I would on great occasion speak with you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I insist, don’t be more distressed than I am.
target: I charge thee, be not thou more grieved than I am.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His spirits are listening to me, but I can’t help cursing him anyway.
target: His spirits hear me And yet I needs must curse.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And don’t be suspicious of me, noble Brutus.
target: And be not jealous on me, gentle Brutus.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, God be praised, I have managed to earn his favor.
target: Ay, I praise God, and I have merited some love at his hands.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give him the instructions for our amusing little contract, and I’ll go get the money for you right away.
target: Give him direction for this merry bond, And I will go and purse the ducats straight, See to my house left in the fearful guard Of an unthrifty knave, and presently I will be with you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What are you thinking?
target: What dost thou mean?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Read it, Mark Antony.
target: Read it, Mark Antony!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No we’re not—it’s night.
target: We waste our lights in vain, like lights by day.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Quiet, quiet, Iras.
target: Peace, peace, Iras.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please wait, sir.
target: Patience, good sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now my sin has been taken from my lips by yours.
target: Thus from my lips, by thine, my sin is purged.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He has called for his horse, but I don’t know where he’s headed.
target: He calls to horse, but will I know not whither.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me at her!.
target: Let me come to her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who among us stabbed him for any cause but justice?
target: What villain touched his body, that did stab, And not for justice?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good morning, Caesar.
target: Good morrow, Caesar.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s come again.
target: Look where it comes again!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll call you “Hamlet Senior,” “King,” “Father,” “royal Dane.” Answer me!
target: I’ll call thee “Hamlet,” “King,” “Father,” “royal Dane.” O, answer me!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I’m dying of hunger.
target: Oh, I die for food.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Which of you has been complaining to the king that I don’t like them?
target: Who is it that complains unto the king That I, forsooth, am stern and love them not?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look how the judge yells at a simple thief.
target: See how yon justice rails upon yon simple thief.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My situation is desperate.
target: I am desperate of my fortunes if they check me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tsk, you’re wrong.
target: Tush, thou art deceived.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Whatever happens to me, this is a soldier’s kiss.
target: Whate’er becomes of me, This is a soldier’s kiss.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ask your husband if you doubt me.
target: Cassio did top her, ask thy husband else.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wash your hands.
target: Wash your hands.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The law allows it, and the court awards it.
target: The law allows it, and the court awards it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Caliban, who now serves me.
target: He, that Caliban Whom now I keep in service.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Farewell.
target: Farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Eat your dinner and pay no attention to him.
target: Feed and regard him not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look, Don Pedro has come back for you.
target: Look, Don Pedro is returned to seek you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m telling you, just watch his face.
target: I say, but mark his gesture.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You wouldn’t have dared, out of fear for your life.
target: For your life you durst not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, you already hurt me in the church, in the town, and in the fields.
target: Ay, in the temple, in the town, the field You do me mischief.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What is the matter?
target: What is the matter?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You are what’s left of the noblest man that ever lived.
target: Thou art the ruins of the noblest man That ever livèd in the tide of times.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There isn’t a nobler man than Antony in all of Rome.
target: There’s not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good friends, go in and have some wine with me.
target: Good friends, go in and taste some wine with me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, dear God, please help him!
target: O, help him, you sweet heavens!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your lord knows what I think.
target: Your lord does know my mind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s a fine woman, all right.
target: Before me, she’s a good wench.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I will tell you this very plainly: I have challenged Claudio, and either he’ll accept the challenge or admit he’s a coward.
target: But I must tell thee plainly, Claudio undergoes my challenge, and either I must shortly hear from him, or I will subscribe him a coward.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good night.
target: Good night.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have nothing to do with what you’re talking about, my lord.
target: With this, my lord, myself have naught to do.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It blushes, is easily embarrassed, and stages regular uprisings in a man’s heart.
target: Tis a blushing, shamefaced spirit that mutinies in a man’s bosom.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, fellow, what have you got there?
target: Now, fellow, What is there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t get that song out of my head tonight.
target: That song tonight Will not go from my mind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Quiet!
target: You bring me out.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I’ll tell you something from my soul.
target: Hear my soul speak.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A gentleman?
target: A gentleman?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s this?
target: How now?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A lively young one!
target: A very forward March-chick!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come and get it!
target: Come, come.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, bring them in.
target: Go, bring them in.—And take your places, ladies.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve rented land from you and your father for eighty years.
target: I have been your tenant and your father’s tenant these fourscore years.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look, it’s the Prince and Mr. Love.
target: The Prince and Monsieur Love!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, like that.
target: Even so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Because if that’s the case, I will tell you a plan that will get rid of your enemy and bring you closer to me.
target: And I another So weary with disasters, tugged with fortune, That I would set my life on any chance, To mend it or be rid on ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A lot of words.
target: Words, words, words.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And for the sake of those you grieve for, do me a favor: tell me the full story of what has happened to you and them, up to this point.
target: And for the sake of them thou sorrowest for, Do me the favour to dilate at full What hath befall'n of them and thee till now.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m not sick if you’ve prepared some honorable exploit for me.
target: I am not sick if Brutus have in hand Any exploit worthy the name of honor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where is this man?
target: Where is he?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The next person to strike again dies.
target: He dies that strikes again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now that I’m done, Wall can go away.
target: And, being done, thus Wall away doth go.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is that the rope ladder Romeo told you to pick up?
target: The cords That Romeo bid thee fetch?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, my friends, don’t please fate by giving it your sorrow as well.
target: Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate To grace it with your sorrows.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Something about Hamlet.
target: So please you, something touching the Lord Hamlet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s comforting.
target: There’s comfort yet; they are assailable.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you believe?
target: What do you think?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This strong poison’s overpowering me.
target: The potent poison quite o'ercrows my spirit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, if you are the same Egeon, speak now, and speak to that same Emilia!
target: O, if thou be’st the same Egeon, speak, And speak unto the same Emilia.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Brother— Quiet.
target: Brother— Content yourself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So that’s what I’ll do, not because I love her but because I’ll get something out of it.
target: The readiest way to make the wench amends Is to become her husband and her father; The which will I, not all so much for love As for another secret close intent By marrying her which I must reach unto.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Meanwhile, after you.
target: Till then, lead thou first.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For God’s sake, let me hear it.
target: For God’s love, let me hear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Remember you!
target: Remember thee!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m finished.
target: I am sped.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll leave you without revealing any emotion, like a man of steel.
target: I’ll leave thee Now like a man of steel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, stop, fool.
target: Out, fool.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You mean an officer?
target: What, thou meanest an officer?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s good if you love Hero, because she’s worthy of your love.
target: Amen, if you love her, for the lady is very well worthy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Though our lives—   We have decided, my lord.
target: Though our lives— Your spirits shine through you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What have you heard from her?
target: What news from her?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You know, you’re right.
target: Well aimed of such a young one.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Terrible.
target: Alack, alack!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What evil and deceitful mirror made me think I could rival Hermia’s starry eyes?
target: What wicked and dissembling glass of mine Made me compare with Hermia’s sphery eyne?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Madam, how are you liking this play?
target: Madam, how like you this play?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But fire also gives off light, and fire will burn you.
target: Light is an effect of fire, and fire will burn: ergo, light wenches will burn.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Calling death banishment is like cutting off my head with a golden ax and smiling while I’m being murdered.
target: Calling death “banishment,” Thou cutt’st my head off with a golden ax And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Brutus, you give a nice speech along with your evil strokes.
target: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s no longer my daughter, and I’ll never see her face again.
target: Let her be thine, for we Have no such daughter, nor shall ever see That face of hers again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why Dover?
target: Wherefore to Dover?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Didn’t you hear it?
target: Did ’t not wake you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Write them together—yours is just as good a name.
target: Write them together, yours is as fair a name.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That was me, but it’s not me— I’m not ashamed to tell you what I once was, since I’m so happy to have since converted.
target: Twas I, but ’tis not I. I do not shame To tell you what I was, since my conversion So sweetly tastes, being the thing I am.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good heavens, man, give them more than that!
target: God’s bodykins, man, much better.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lady told me to tell you that while she lets you stay at her house because you’re a relative, she doesn’t approve of your behavior.
target: My lady bade me tell you, that, though she harbors you as her kinsman, she’s nothing allied to your disorders.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It doesn’t matter.
target: Tis no matter.— Go to the fellow, good Alexas.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take your time.
target: Take your time.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s hear what Antony has to say.
target: Let us hear what Antony can say.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As for us, you know we are Antony’s, and he is Caesar’s.
target: For us, you know Whose he is we are, and that is Caesar’s.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It is written that shoemakers and tailors should play with each others' tools, that fisherman should play with paints, and painters should play with with fishing nets.
target: It is written, that the shoemaker should meddle with his yard and the tailor with his last, the fisher with his pencil and the painter with his nets.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re not responsible for my death and my father’s, and I’m not responsible for yours.
target: Mine and my father’s death come not upon thee, Nor thine on me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Am I in France?
target: Am I in France?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Indeed, before he fell down, when he realized the commoners were glad he refused the crown, he pulled open his robe and offered them his throat to cut.
target: Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the common herd was glad he refused the crown, he plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his throat to cut.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll recite something for you, guy.
target: Sirrah, I’ll teach thee a speech.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: King Lear, I’ve always honored you as king, loved you as my father, obeyed you as my master, and thanked you in my prayers— I’m furious and ready to snap.
target: Royal Lear, Whom I have ever honored as my king, Loved as my father, as my master followed, As my great patron thought on in my prayers— The bow is bent and drawn.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I remember when I was in love, I broke my sword on a stone, and told him to take that for coming at night to see Jane Smile.
target: I remember when I was in love I broke my sword upon a stone and bid him take that for coming a- night to Jane Smile.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s why I’ve begged him to come on our shift tonight, so that if the ghost appears he can see what we see and speak to it.
target: Therefore I have entreated him along With us to watch the minutes of this night, That if again this apparition come He may approve our eyes and speak to it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The woman I love is beautiful.
target: And she’s fair I love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s going on, daughter?
target: How now, daughter?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Love each other and be friends, like two such men should be.
target: Love, and be friends as two such men should be.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All right, we’ll have a prologue then.
target: Well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That pretty boy, Claudio?
target: The most exquisite Claudio?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish you could face your bad news like a man!
target: Would you would bear your fortune like a man!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s discuss it some more.
target: I will talk further with you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Three thousand ducats.
target: For me, three thousand ducats.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Anyone who has a house to cover his head has a good head on his shoulders.
target: He that has a house to put ’s head in has a good headpiece.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My servants might overhear, and old Gremio is still hanging around, so we might be interrupted.
target: Besides, old Gremio is heark'ning still, And happily we might be interrupted.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Fierce civil war will paralyze all of Italy.
target: Domestic fury and fierce civil strife Shall cumber all the parts of Italy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: With a doctor’s help he might recover and become an ass again.
target: With the help of a surgeon he might yet recover and prove an ass.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His eyes were as green as leeks.
target: His eyes were green as leeks.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: From then on we’ll turn our backs on Athens.
target: There my Lysander and myself shall meet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And you can’t put your heads together and figure out why he’s acting so dazed and confused, ruining his peace and quiet with such dangerous displays of lunacy?
target: And can you by no drift of conference Get from him why he puts on this confusion, Grating so harshly all his days of quiet With turbulent and dangerous lunacy?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take me to Octavius.
target: Bring me to Octavius.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s disgraceful!
target: Hark, hark!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We shouldn’t expect men to be perfect, or for them to be as polite as on the weddingday.
target: Nay, we must think men are not gods, Nor of them look for such observances As fit the bridal.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I just saw him yesterday,” or “the other day,” or whenever it is, you know, “and there he was gambling,” or “there he was, totally wasted, or fighting with somebody about a tennis match, or going into a house of ill repute”—that means a whorehouse, you know—or whatever.
target: I saw him yesterday”—or “t' other day,” Or then, or then, with such or such—“and, as you say, There was he gaming, there o'ertook in’s rouse, There falling out at tennis,” or, perchance, “I saw him enter such a house of sale”—   Your bait of falsehood takes this carp of truth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you want from me, my good man?
target: What would you with me, honest neighbor?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And I’ll turn you into a spirit like us, so you won’t die as humans do.—Come here, Peaseblossom, Cobweb, Moth, and Mustardseed!
target: And I will purge thy mortal grossness so That thou shalt like an airy spirit go.— Peaseblossom, Cobweb, Moth, and Mustardseed!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But where will I lie tomorrow?
target: But where tomorrow?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He feels the need to grace all his other tramps with his presence while I sit at home starving for a smile from him.
target: His company must do his minions grace, Whilst I at home starve for a merry look.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hate to say it, but it’s almost two and we won’t get there before suppertime.
target: I dare assure you, sir, ’tis almost two, And ’twill be supper time ere you come there.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ma'am, my master’s coming.
target: Madam, here comes my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now that I think about it, I really want it.
target: And now methinks I have a mind to it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, with his sordid desertion, he sets the example for our own.
target: Oh, he has given example for our flight Most grossly by his own!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Brutus speaks.
target: Brutus speaks.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t worry, sir.
target: Fear not, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s not for me to say.
target: I cannot tell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Every one of us is a criminal.
target: We are arrant knaves, all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m really worried about that.
target: I fear it, I promise you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll make you an example for the others to learn from.
target: I’ll make thee an example.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He couldn’t eat without me talking about it.
target: Alone, it was the subject of my theme; In company I often glancèd it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s as good as proof that the sweet young man’s in love.
target: That’s as much as to say, the sweet youth’s in love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m sick, Charmian.
target: I am pale, Charmian.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What captain do you serve?
target: Under what captain serve you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come, Kate, let’s go to bed.
target: Come, Kate, we’ll to bed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get lost!
target: Go to.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hello!
target: Hail.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: May your sword be victorious and everything you do succeed.
target: Upon your sword Sit laurel victory, and smooth success Be strewed before your feet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The letters he spoke of may help me.
target: The letters that he speaks of  May be my friends.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The king won’t live, I hope.
target: He cannot live, I hope, and must not die Till George be packed with post-horse up to heaven.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, is it not news that Petruchio’s coming?
target: Why, is it not news to hear of Petruchio’s coming?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My soul will keep yours company on the way to heaven.
target: My soul shall thine keep company to heaven.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take it easy!
target: Will you let it fall?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will walk around and mingle with all of you, playing the humble host.
target: Ourself will mingle with society And play the humble host.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shut up, fool.
target: Peace, fool.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His father, if I do say so myself, is an honest but very poor man, and, thank God, likely to live a long time.
target: His father, though I say ’t, is an honest exceeding poor man and, God be thanked, well to live.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good, I’m satisfied.
target: So, I am satisfied.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, as much as you look like yourself.
target: As thou art to thyself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here.
target: Think’st thou I jest?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Worthy sir, greetings!
target: Grave sir, hail!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: From there we’ll safely carry you to France and back, calming the waters of the Channel to provide you with a smooth voyage.
target: There is the playhouse now, there must you sit, And thence to France shall we convey you safe And bring you back, charming the narrow seas To give you gentle pass; for, if we may, We’ll not offend one stomach with our play.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Unpunished!
target: Chastisement!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, you are.
target: Ay, marry, must you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I found him here,  Beating?
target: I found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a warren.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Damn my suspicious thoughts!
target: But beshrew my jealousy!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lead the way, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For it is written in the book of Numbers: “When the man dies, let the inheritance descend unto the daughter.” Gracious lord, claim what is yours.

target: Marry, my child, early next Thursday morn, The gallant, young, and noble gentleman, The County Paris, at Saint Peter’s Church, Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.

target: Thence we looked toward England And cited up a thousand fearful times, During the wars of York and Lancaster That had befall'n us.

target: It faded on the crowing of the cock.

target: A marvelous witty fellow, I assure you, but I will go about with him.—Come you hither, sirrah, a word in your ear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And I love Hastings with all my heart.
target: And I as I love Hastings with my heart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Her reputation was as pure as the snow, but now it’s as dirty and black as my own face.

target: And, for his passage, The soldiers' music and the rites of war Speak loudly for him.

target: By my head, here comes the Capulets.

target: We’ll go along together, And ere we have thy youthful wages spent, We’ll light upon some settled low content.

target: I pray you, what thinks he of our estate?

target: By heaven, I’ll make a ghost of him that lets me.

target: Why not, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Unless I’ve mistaken his battle flags, which I’m sure I haven’t, his regiment lies at least half a mile south of the king’s mighty army.
target: Unless I have mista'en his colors much, Which well I am assured I have not done, His regiment lies half a mile, at least, South from the mighty power of the king.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I invite you all aboard my ship.
target: It nothing ill becomes thee.— Aboard my galley I invite you all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There is no indication of the mighty army that surrounds them in his expression, nor has the long, sleepless night robbed his face of an ounce of color.
target: Upon his royal face there is no note How dread an army hath enrounded him, Nor doth he dedicate one jot of color Unto the weary and all-watchèd night, But freshly looks and overbears attaint With cheerful semblance and sweet majesty, That every wretch, pining and pale before, Beholding him, plucks comfort from his looks.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, sir; crack jokes over lunch.
target: I pray you, jest, sir, as you sit at dinner.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will.

target: Set your countenance, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is Casca.
target: This, Casca.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: By eight o'clock.
target: By the eighth hour.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Since your woes are only a portion of mine, I have every reason to surpass your lamentations and drown out your cries with my own.
target: O, what cause have I, Thine being but a moiety of my moan, To overgo thy woes and drown thy cries!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Actually, their hearts are as sensitive and loyal as ours are.
target: In faith, they are as true of heart as we.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: At your service, madam.
target: Here, madam, at your service.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wait for mine, sweet soul.
target: Tarry, sweet soul, for mine; then fly abreast, As in this glorious and well-foughten field We kept together in our chivalry.” Upon these words I came and cheered him up.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And if he advances unopposed, my lord, let us abandon France.
target: An if he be not fought withal, my lord, Let us not live in France.

target: Think it no more.

target: Heavens thank you for ’t!

target: I am no child, no babe.

target: Look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east.

target: Whoe'er he be that in this foul proceeding Hath thus beguiled your daughter of herself And you of her, the bloody book of law You shall yourself read in the bitter letter, After your own sense, yea, though our proper son Stood in your action.

target: Tis meet I should be used so, very meet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My son will win.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There are only friends here.
target: None but friends.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Speak once again.
target: Speak once again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m even happier that I’m not stupid, and I can learn.
target: Happier than this— She is not bred so dull but she can learn.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me your hand, Kate.

target: Made she no verbal question?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If she can’t find out what his secret is, then send him off to England or wherever you think best.
target: If she find him not, To England send him or confine him where Your wisdom best shall think.

target: Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher.

target: My lord, the first time that I ever saw him Methought he was a brother to your daughter.

target: Alas now, pray you, Work not so hard.

target: Run to your houses, fall upon your knees, Pray to the gods to intermit the plague That needs must light on this ingratitude.

target: Be collected.

target: Intend a kind of zeal both to the Prince and Claudio, as in love of your brother’s honor, who hath made this match, and his friend’s reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with the semblance of a maid, that you have discovered thus.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She flirted with the messenger boy to exasperate you, fire up your passions, and make you angry and jealous.
target: She did show favor to the youth in your sight only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valor, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It was just an accident!
target: Twas a fault unwilling.

target: Be pleased to tell us— For this is from the present—how you take The offers we have sent you.

target: I have within my mind A thousand raw tricks of these bragging jacks Which I will practice.

target: He may show what outward courage he will, but I believe, as cold a night as ’tis, he could wish himself in Thames up to the neck; and so I would he were, and I by him, at all adventures, so we were quit here.

target: But for your husband, He is noble, wise, judicious, and best knows The fits o' th' season.

target: Happy be Theseus, our renownèd duke.

target: If he were dead, you’d weep for him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If she lives a long and happy life, then all women may as well turn into monsters.
target: If she live long, And in the end meet the old course of death, Women will all turn monsters.

target: We will spare for no wit, I warrant you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tomorrow is the day.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, that’s the one.
target: Ay, he.

target: On what compulsion must I?

target: Fear it, Ophelia.

target: You may do your will, But he’s a tried and valiant soldier.

target: He had a fever when he was in Spain, And when the fit was on him, I did mark How he did shake.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll be your wife if you’ll have me.
target: I am your wife if you will marry me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve heard a lot more.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And like I am for no woman.
target: And I for no woman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, the poor bird.
target: Alas, poor hurt fowl, now will he creep into sedges.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well that’s good.
target: All the better.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will not trade my horse for any that walks on four legs.
target: I will not change my horse with any that treads but on four pasterns.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When we’re faced with a wretched person, bruised and crying with hardship, we try to get them to shush up.
target: A wretched soul, bruised with adversity We bid be quiet when we hear it cry, But were we burdened with like weight of pain, As much or more we should ourselves complain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go, Pindarus, climb a little higher on this hill.
target: Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If its juice is put on someone’s eyelids while they’re asleep, that person will fall in love with the next living creature he or she sees.
target: The juice of it on sleeping eyelids laid Will make or man or woman madly dote Upon the next live creature that it sees.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you have me, you have me now at my worst; and if you have me, you’ll appreciate me better and better.
target: Thou hast me, if thou hast me, at the worst, and thou shalt wear me, if thou wear me, better and better.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you talking about young Master Launcelot?
target: Talk you of young Master Launcelot?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The news I have to tell your majesty is that Buckingham’s army has dispersed from sudden floods and heavy rainfall.
target: In Kent, my liege, the Guilfords are in arms, And every hour more competitors Flock to the rebels, and their power grows strong.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Even if we said that this behavior suits him—though only a man with a perfect character could avoid being disgraced by such antics—there’s no excuse for the extra work we’ve had to take on while he’s been off amusing himself.
target: Say this becomes him— As his composure must be rare indeed Whom these things cannot blemish—yet must Antony No way excuse his foils when we do bear So great weight in his lightness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shall I stay in this dreary world, which is no better than a pigsty without you?
target: Shall I abide In this dull world, which in thy absence is No better than a sty?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’ll do whatever Hastings does.
target: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who measured the ground?
target: Who hath measured the ground?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My worthy Cawdor!
target: My worthy Cawdor!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God has blessed you with a good name.
target: God hath blessed you with a good name.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I had my father’s signet ring in my pocket, with the royal seal of Denmark on it.
target: I had my father’s signet in my purse, Which was the model of that Danish seal.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, spite of spites!
target: O spite of spites!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Informed them”?
target: Informed them”?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can I have a word with you privately?
target: Shall I speak a word in your ear?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You should be ashamed of yourself, Satan, you liar!
target: Fie, thou dishonest Satan!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re smiling?
target: Smilest thou?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What a heavy sigh!
target: What a sigh is there!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Aren’t these woods less perilous than the court, with all its jealousies and intrigues?
target: Are not these woods More free from peril than the envious court?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What work can you do?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Me neither.
target: Nor I neither.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen to my reasons and be silent so you can hear.
target: Hear me for my cause, and be silent that you may hear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Mend” me, you impertinent fellow?
target: Mend” me, thou saucy fellow?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will, my lord.
target: I will, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish you all the comfort that such a dark night as this can offer, noble father-in-law.
target: All comfort that the dark night can afford Be to thy person, noble father-in-law.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think you’ve been frowning too much recently.
target: Methinks you are too much of late i' th' frown.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s the reason for this horrible shouting?
target: What is the reason of this terrible summons?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, return and tell me if your master looks well, because he was sick when he left.
target: Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well, For he went sickly forth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why have you collapsed?
target: wherefore sink you down?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lord Hamlet.— Please let him be all right!
target: Lord Hamlet— Heaven secure him!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Speak, man, what’s the matter?
target: Why, man, what is the matter?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My brother thinks highly of you, and because of his affection, has helped arrange your marriage—but that was definitely a waste of his time and energy.
target: For my brother, I think he holds you well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage—surely suit ill spent and labor ill bestowed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ask it something, Horatio.
target: Question it, Horatio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His life was gentle, and the elements mixed so well in him that Nature might stand up and say to all the world, “This was a man.” Let’s treat him according to his virtue, with all the respect and rituals of burial.
target: His life was gentle, and the elements So mixed in him that Nature might stand up And say to all the world, “This was a man.” According to his virtue let us use him, With all respect and rites of burial.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh no, my reasons are deep and as permanent as death.
target: O no, my reasons are too deep and dead— Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their graves.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And that’s everything, Leonato.—Claudio, Benedick—my dear friend Leonato has invited you all to stay here at Messina.
target: That is the sum of all, Leonato.—Signior Claudio and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Her worth is carried on the wind And it blows throughout the world, carrying the name of Rosalind.
target: Her worth being mounted on the wind, Through all the world bears Rosalind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t want to go mad.
target: I would not be mad.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I was never disloyal, and I never will be.
target: I never was nor never will be false.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m serving under him to take advantage of him.
target: I follow him to serve my turn upon him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll wait for you in your cave, where you can tell me what you need from me.
target: What you would have I’ll stay to know at your abandoned cave.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Those men you just mentioned will be beheaded today.
target: Today the lords you talked of are beheaded.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is his ship sturdy?
target: Is he well shipped?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I tell you, you’ve ruined her gown.
target: I tell thee, I, that thou hast marred her gown.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And I know that by now they’re waiting for me on the porch outside Pompey’s theater.
target: And I do know by this they stay for me In Pompey’s porch.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why are you so rude to someone who loves you so much?
target: Oh, why rebuke you him that loves you so?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll give  Thank you, darling.
target: I thank you, madam.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Madam, some actors happened to cross our paths on the way here.
target: Madam, it so fell out, that certain players We o'erraught on the way.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you say that, you’ll only be telling the truth.
target: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d deny whatever evidence you had against me—even if it were in my own handwriting—and turn it all into evidence against you and your plans for treachery.
target: What I should deny— As this I would, ay, though thou didst produce My very character—I’d turn it all To thy suggestion, plot, and damnèd practice.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now grit your teeth and let your nostrils flare.
target: Now set the teeth and stretch the nostril wide, Hold hard the breath and bend up every spirit To his full height.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What could I hope to get from you, who’ve got nothing but your charm to support you in life?
target: For what advancement may I hope from thee That no revenue hast but thy good spirits, To feed and clothe thee?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: These lovers are saying some strange things, Theseus.
target: Tis strange, my Theseus, that these lovers speak of.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If only that were all it is— It is, I promise.
target: If ’twere no other— 'Tis but so, I warrant.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go to the platform, Brutus.
target: Go to the pulpit, Brutus.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think I’m getting delirious.
target: Why, therefore fire, for I have caught extreme cold.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There was a noise, that’s certainly true.
target: There was a noise, That’s verily.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I will tell you that I seduced Margaret, the Lady Hero’s waiting woman, tonight.
target: But know that I have tonight wooed Margaret, the Lady Hero’s gentlewoman, by the name of Hero.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s that coming over here?
target: See, who comes here?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think I’ve found one already, thanks to you, my lord.
target: I thank your lordship, you have got me one.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And just try to remember a few rules of life.
target: And these few precepts in thy memory Look thou character.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hope you’re not drowned.
target: I hope now thou art not drowned.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why couldn’t you be attended by my servants, or by Regan’s?
target: Why might not you, my lord, receive attendance From those that she calls servants, or from mine?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ha, ha!
target: Ha, ha!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Play your flutes!
target: Come, the recorders!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, you lie there on the path.
target: Lie thou there (throwing down a letter), for here comes the trout that must be caught with tickling.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, isn’t all this joking better than groaning about love?
target: Why, is not this better now than groaning for love?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take me to him.
target: Show me the place.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, after you.
target: Nay, then.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wait, countrymen.
target: Stay, countrymen.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where else would she be?
target: Where should she be?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, you prophesied that the time would come when I would want your help in cursing that humpbacked spider, that hideous toad!
target: O, thou didst prophesy the time would come That I should wish for thee to help me curse That bottled spider, that foul bunch-backed toad!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They’re certainly a peaceful couple!
target: Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A governor shines as brightly as a king until a king is near by, and the governor suddenly looks like a nobody.
target: A substitute shines brightly as a king Until a king be by, and then his state Empties itself, as doth an inland brook Into the main of waters.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They should advance immediately, because I sense Octavius’s side is a bit fainthearted right now, and a sudden push would overthrow him.
target: Let them set on at once, for I perceive But cold demeanor in Octavius' wing, And sudden push gives them the overthrow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I loved this man so much it makes me weep.
target: So dear I loved the man that I must weep.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What is the matter here?
target: What is the matter here?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do tell.
target: Impart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lucius!
target: Lucius!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t you hear it ring?
target: Do you not hear it ring?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why would you have me betray the truth of my emotions and make my love wander in some other direction?
target: Against my soul’s pure truth why labour you To make it wander in an unknown field?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hope so too, Madam.
target: Madam, I wish it may.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is the news good or bad?
target: Is thy news good, or bad?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go disguise yourself as a sea nymph.
target: Go make thyself like a nymph o' th' sea.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here’s something good.
target: Here’s goodly gear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It is not destiny’s fault, but our own faults, that we’re slaves.
target: The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars But in ourselves, that we are underlings.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The friar’s ready.
target: Here’s the friar ready.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then turn your noble face away from me, that face that the whole world adores.
target: Turn from me then that noble countenance Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In a half an hour he’ll be asleep.
target: Within this half hour will he be asleep.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So what do you say to my suit?
target: And what say’st thou then to my love?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, as you’re a Roman, tell me the truth.
target: Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Some tardy cripple must have taken the counter-order, who came after Clarence was already buried.
target: Some tardy cripple bear the countermand, That came too lag to see him burièd.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s been gone for nine years and he’s leaving again soon.
target: He hath been out nine years, and away he shall again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If everyone looked so lovely in their sorrow, then sorrow would be highly prized.
target: In brief, Sorrow would be a rarity most beloved If all could so become it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good countrymen, let me leave alone.
target: Good countrymen, let me depart alone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s too frightened to look at itself.
target: Almost afraid to know itself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You make me want to agree with the philosopher Pythagoras that animal souls are reincarnated in human bodies.
target: Thou almost makest me waver in my faith To hold opinion with Pythagoras That souls of animals infuse themselves Into the trunks of men.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I thank you all.
target: I thank thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can I have some?
target: I prithee let me have it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He was the one who denounced his father.
target: Twas he informed against him, And quit the house on purpose that their punishment Might have the freer course.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And when you married him and made him the master of your bed, I gave you my word that I would do everything I possibly could for him.
target: Long since thy husband served me in my wars, And I to thee engaged a prince’s word, When thou didst make him master of thy bed, To do him all the grace and good I could.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you struggle to bring down a tyrant, you will sleep peacefully when the tyrant is killed.
target: If you do sweat to put a tyrant down, You sleep in peace, the tyrant being slain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How old is he?
target: Of what personage and years is he?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Anyway, he is what he is.
target: It is well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Maybe we can benefit from the same chaos that has defeated us.
target: Disorder, that hath spoiled us, friend us now.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Three thousand ducats for three months, and Antonio will guarantee it.
target: Three thousand ducats for three months, and Antonio bound.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, sir.
target: No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then the window lets day in, and life goes out the window.
target: Then, window, let day in and let life out.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m going inside to think up some way to kill that beautiful devil.
target: I will withdraw To furnish me with some swift means of death For the fair devil.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Excuse me.
target: I will, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I just want everything to be all right between you.
target: I would have all well betwixt you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You could’ve done this without your beard and gown.
target: Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and gown.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And yet I think you look with your eyes just like every other woman does.
target: And how you may be converted I know not, but methinks you look with your eyes as other women do.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His military ability is double that of the other two.
target: His soldiership Is twice the other twain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I never tried to win over a friend or enemy with sweet words.
target: I never sued to friend, nor enemy; My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We would have liked to have heard your good advice, which has always been serious and helpful, at the council today, but we’ll wait until tomorrow.
target: We should have else desired your good advice— Which still hath been both grave and prosperous— In this day’s council, but we’ll take tomorrow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I just meant that our hearts are joined, so we can almost think of them as one heart.
target: I mean that my heart unto yours is knit So that but one heart we can make of it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: People with too much invested in the world always get hurt.
target: You have too much respect upon the world.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, cousin, I’m crying.
target: No, coz, I rather weep.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But suppose I did all the things you named out of love for her.
target: Say that I did all this for love of her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye.
target: Fare you well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He thinks “G” is me.
target: And for my name of George begins with  It follows in his thought that I am he.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m sorry, but I memorized what I’m supposed to say here today, and that question isn’t part of the speech I learned.
target: I can say little more than I have studied, and that question’s out of my part.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It seems that the guards who were supposed to be protecting his chamber did it.
target: Those of his chamber, as it seemed, had done ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here’s mine.
target: Behold: it is the privilege of mine honors, My oath, and my profession.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What did you say?
target: What dost thou say?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Prepare your troops.
target: Draw up your powers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And yet for all that, if she didn’t hate him to death, she’d love him to death.
target: But yet for all that, an if she did not hate him deadly, she would love him dearly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Not me.
target: Not I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There are lots of ways to get on the general’s good side again.
target: What, man, there are ways to recover the general again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you know any, Hero?
target: Know you any, Hero?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Anyone who says you’re a man must not notice how young you are.
target: For they shall yet belie thy happy years That say thou art a man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Many of you own slaves, which—like your donkeys and dogs and mules—you use to perform awful jobs just because you bought them.
target: You have among you many a purchased slave, Which—like your asses and your dogs and mules— You use in abject and in slavish parts Because you bought them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Absolutely—he is stuffed, like a dummy.
target: But for the stuffing—well, we are all mortal.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She has a low-pitched voice.
target: She is low-voiced.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish I had two fool’s caps and two daughters.
target: Would I had two coxcombs and two daughters.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Speak to us.
target: Speak to us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you shut the windows, it will pour out the keyhole.
target: Shut that, and ’twill out at the keyhole.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, what’s the matter?
target: Why, what’s the matter?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ask her to help you heal the rift between her husband and you.
target: This broken joint between you and her husband entreat her to splinter, and, my fortunes against any lay worth naming, this crack of your love shall grow stronger than it was before.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think you’re trustworthy one minute and then not the next.
target: I think that thou art just and think thou art not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who ever saw the heavens threaten like this?
target: Who ever knew the heavens menace so?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s a disgrace to us all.
target: So God sa' me, ’tis shame to stand still.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Put the torch out, so I can’t be seen.
target: Yet put it out, for I would not be seen.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And what do you know, boy?
target: Why, what canst thou tell, my boy?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: To Dover.
target: To Dover.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You always loved to tell me I couldn’t do anything without being told.
target: Your worship was wont to tell me that I could do nothing without bidding.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Didn’t I tell you she was innocent?
target: Did I not tell you she was innocent?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hope I never achieve success if I don’t feel some of your heartbroken grief right now.
target: Would I might never O’ertake pursued success, but I do feel, By the rebound of yours, a grief that smites My very heart at root.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you think, Bottom?
target: What say you, Bottom?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I didn’t take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me.
target: I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to thank me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s calling?
target: Who calls?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The fact that this summer bird, the house martin, builds his nests here proves how inviting the breezes are.
target: This guest of summer, The temple-haunting martlet, does approve, By his loved mansionry, that the heaven’s breath Smells wooingly here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s go at it, coward!
target: Have at thee, coward!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But you’re all wound up about fashion, too.
target: But art not thou thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I was.
target: I was, but I do find more pain in banishment Than death can yield me here by my abode.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He writes brave poems, speaks brave words, makes brave promises, and then breaks them just as bravely.
target: But what talk we of fathers when there is such a man as Orlando?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, I swear it.
target: No, as I shall be saved.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wouldn’t change my mind even if she were
target: I’ll hold my mind were she an Ethiope.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What are we going to do, Enobarbus?
target: What shall we do, Enobarbus?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Leave me alone.
target: Let me be clear of thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where did he go?
target: Wherein went he?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A backbiting friend, one who grabs people, who patrols the streets and passageways.
target: The passages of alleys, creeks, and narrow lands; A hound that runs counter and yet draws dryfoot well, One that before the judgment carries poor souls to hell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come, Romeo.
target: Come, Romeo.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, I found it and gave it to my husband.
target: No, alas, I found it And I did give ’t my husband.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll have glory in this losing day—more than Octavius and Mark Antony will gain by their foul conquest.
target: I shall have glory by this losing day More than Octavius and Mark Antony By this vile conquest shall attain unto.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Madam?
target: Madam?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The king acts unnaturally—father against child.
target: The king falls from bias of nature—there’s father against child.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re sure the handwriting is your brother’s?
target: You know the character to be your brother’s?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me what I want to know.
target: I conjure you by that which you profess— Howe'er you come to know it—answer me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The ambassadors are back from Norway, sir.
target: Th' ambassadors from Norway, my good lord, Are joyfully returned.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shame on you!
target: Fie, fie!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Pindarus, order our commanders to lead their charges a little ways away from this ground.
target: Pindarus, Bid our commanders lead their charges off A little from this ground.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish your Highness knew my true feelings in this matter: I have never in my life loved my brother.
target: Oh, that your Highness knew my heart in this: I never loved my brother in my life.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He says I won’t get into heaven because I’m a Jew’s daughter, and he says you’re irresponsible because by converting Jews to Christianity you’re raising the price of pork.
target: He tells me flatly there is no mercy for me in heaven because I am a Jew’s daughter, and he says you are no good member of the commonwealth, for in converting Jews to Christians you raise the price of pork.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here comes my little bird.
target: Look where the youngest wren of nine comes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m going.
target: I go.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: On me, though I am barely half the man that Edward was?
target: On me, whose all not equals Edward’s moiety?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The king will be offended to find out that his messenger is so badly treated.
target: The king his master needs must take it ill, That he, so slightly valued in his messenger, Should have him thus restrained.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The servants Macbeth killed.
target: Those that Macbeth hath slain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God and your work be praised, victorious friends.
target: God and your arms be praised, victorious friends!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But has Catesby gone?
target: But what, is Catesby gone?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, he won’t wake up till Judgment Day.
target: Why, he shall never wake until the great Judgment Day.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As I get to leech him, I will show some mercy.
target: As I suck blood, I will some mercy show.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go then, goodbye.
target: Go to, farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And  Madam, with all my heart.
target: Madam, with all my heart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, sir, that can’t be true.
target: Sir, sir, that cannot be.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So tell me, Grumio, how goes the world?
target: I prithee, good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You lover of that damned whore, you’re talking to me of “ifs”?
target: Thou protector of this damnèd strumpet, Talk’st thou to me of “ifs”?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here, hang them on this clothesline.
target: Come, hang them on this line.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your magic spell has such an effect on them that if you saw them now, you’d feel sorry for them.
target: Your charm so strongly works 'em That if you now beheld them, your affections Would become tender.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lysander I want to stop, but Hermia stops my heart from beating.
target: The one I’ll stay, the other stayeth me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This clearing will be the stage, and this hawthorn bush will be our dressing room.
target: This green plot shall be our stage, this hawthorn-brake our tiring-house, and we will do it in action as we will do it before the duke.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you get to drink, instead of sweet obedience, but poisonous flattery?
target: What drink’st thou oft, instead of homage sweet, But poisoned flattery?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And why did you come?
target: Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Merciful heaven!
target: Merciful heaven!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What income, what profit does it bring in?
target: What are thy comings in?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ruining his meals, his enjoyment, and his sleep would drive any man or beast mad.
target: In food, in sport, and life-preserving rest To be disturbed, would mad or man or beast.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well hello, my good boy.
target: How now, my pretty knave?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll agree to those terms and even say that Jews are nice.
target: I’ll seal to such a bond, And say there is much kindness in the Jew.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sweetheart, go on.
target: Sweet, say on.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You horrid slave, you can’t be trained to be good, and you’re capable of anything evil!
target: Abhorrèd slave, Which any print of goodness wilt not take, Being capable of all ill!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Show me the caskets and let me try my luck.
target: Therefore I pray you lead me to the caskets To try my fortune.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord Sebastian, even though what you say is true, your way of saying it is tactless and comes at the wrong time.
target: My lord Sebastian, The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness And time to speak it in.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your highness will have to force me to tell.
target: I would your grace would constrain me to tell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’re going to have an out-and-out brawl if I stay any longer.
target: We shall chide downright, if I longer stay.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, onward, then.
target: Well, forward, forward!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is an asp’s trail, and these fig leaves have slime on them, just like the kind that asps deposit on the caves by the Nile.
target: This is an aspic’s trail, and these fig leaves Have slime upon them, such as th’ aspic leaves Upon the caves of Nile.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me try: If there’s a buck who needs a doe Tell him Rosalind will do.
target: For a taste: If a hart do lack a hind, Let him seek out Rosalind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you acting so boldly from hardship or because you despise good manners?
target: Art thou thus boldened, man, by thy distress Or else a rude despiser of good manners, That in civility thou seem’st so empty?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You might as well try to stab the air with your sword.
target: As easy mayst thou the intrenchant air With thy keen sword impress as make me bleed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Advancement to some scaffold, to lose their heads.
target: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Answer all of us, now.
target: Answer every man directly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is Signior Lucentio at home, sir?
target: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Strategy makes a better soldier than haste.
target: Advantage is a better soldier than rashness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Show me the way.
target: Lead me on.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your name is Lucentio, you say.
target: Lucentio is your name.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is his second fit like this.
target: This is his second fit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If that’s what you want, all right.
target: Then, with your will, go on.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Me too.
target: Nor I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What are you doing?
target: What is ’t you do?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ha, ha, ha!
target: Ha, ha, ha!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stop crying.
target: Then weep no more.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But, oh, it makes me bitter to look at happiness through another man’s eyes.
target: But Oh, how bitter a thing it is to look into happiness through another man’s eyes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have I accomplished so much in battle, but now I’m afraid to tell some old men the truth?
target: Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I got it from him.
target: I had it of him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go and tell my daughter I want to speak with her.
target: Go you and tell my daughter I would speak with her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why would they do that, my lord?
target: To what end, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where are they?
target: Where are they?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t bring me any more reports.
target: Bring me no more reports.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take this.
target: I’ll make division of my present with you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s not a false gallop, anyway.
target: Not a false gallop.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on in, tailor.
target: Come in, tailor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, that turned out well in the end.
target: This business is well ended.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t let her say I kept you.

target: My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire, As I by friends am well advertisèd, Sir Edward Courtney and the haughty prelate, Bishop of Exeter, his elder brother, With many more confederates are in arms.
