source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll both be safer if we go separate ways.
target: Our separated fortune Shall keep us both the safer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sounds good to us.
target: We are for you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But, Lepidus, go to Caesar’s house.
target: But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar’s house.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Find out the way, and I’ll find the right man.
target: Find thou the means, and I’ll find such a man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My God, that’s my handkerchief!
target: By heaven, that should be my handkerchief!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And don’t lie.
target: See thou dissemble not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If we’re all pork-eaters, we won’t be able to get our hands on a slice of bacon, even if we’ve got the money for it.
target: If we grow all to be pork-eaters, we shall not shortly have a rasher on the coals for money.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t like her name.
target: I do not like her name.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ha?
target: Ha?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, this fun is not for me.
target: To see no pastime I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Only three so far?
target: Yet but three?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, to hell with those people!
target: Oh, fie upon them!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As for me, I’m surrendering all my power over to him, giving him absolute authority for the rest of his life.
target: For us, we will resign During the life of this old majesty To him our absolute power.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’s no darkness except ignorance, and you’re more ignorant than the Egyptians during the plague of fog.
target: I say, there is no darkness but ignorance, in which thou art more puzzled than the Egyptians in their fog.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then you must take the truth I have to tell like a Roman.
target: Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It would be better if they were all on his father’s side, or that there were none at all on his father’s side.
target: Better it were they all came by his father, Or by the father there were none at all, For emulation who shall now be nearest Will touch us all too near if God prevent not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, by this I can see that you don’t love me as much as I love you.
target: Herein I see thou lov’st me not with the full weight that I love thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll go see my mother soon.
target: Then I will come to my mother by and by.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He was graced with lots of natural gifts, he was young, valiant, wise, and no doubt meant to be king.
target: A sweeter and a Lovellier gentleman, Framed in the prodigality of nature, Young, valiant, wise, and, no doubt, right royal, The spacious world cannot again afford.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our regiments are full to the brim; our cause is ready.
target: You must note beside, That we have tried the utmost of our friends, Our legions are brim-full, our cause is ripe.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Young man, have you challenged Charles the Wrestler?
target: Young man, have you challenged Charles the wrestler?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll be back quicker than you can think a thought.
target: I will be here again, even with a thought.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I regret my crime more than my death, and I beg your Highness to forgive me, while punishing my body with death.
target: Our purposes God justly hath discovered, And I repent my fault more than my death, Which I beseech Your Highness to forgive, Although my body pay the price of it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, she’s so witty and creative!
target: Of so high and plenteous wit and invention!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wouldn’t be the villain you think I am even if I were offered all of Macbeth’s kingdom and the riches of the East too.
target: I would not be the villain that thou think’st For the whole space that’s in the tyrant’s grasp, And the rich East to boot.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is that you, Diomedes?
target: Art thou there, Diomed?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, before the sun comes up and burns away the dew, I have to fill this basket of mine with poisonous weeds and medicinal flowers.
target: Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye, The day to cheer and night’s dank dew to dry, I must upfill this osier cage of ours With baleful weeds and precious-juicèd flowers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you really think so?
target: Will you think so?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take a tip from me, then.
target: Be warned by me, then: they that ride so, and ride not warily, fall into foul bogs.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll call you a minstrel.
target: I will give you the minstrel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But goodbye.
target: But fare ye well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I must tell you then.
target: I must tell you then.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Believe me, I’m not.
target: Believe me, I am not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How does it go with my magnificent Mark Antony?
target: How goes it with my brave Mark Antony?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Call him!
target: Call!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But be quiet, here comes Thisbe.
target: Here comes Thisbe.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, I’ve been responsible for his upbringing.
target: His breeding, sir, hath been at my charge.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I was told that by one who knows him better than you.
target: I was told that by one that knows him better than you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m still young enough to see without glasses, and I don’t see what you’re talking about.
target: I can see yet without spectacles, and I see no such matter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish you all the best.
target: There lies your way, due west.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good morning, Kate, for I hear that’s what you’re called.
target: Good morrow, Kate—for that’s your name, I hear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Like a young man who wants to amount to something, this morning begins early.
target: This morning, like the spirit of a youth That means to be of note, begins betimes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is the king awake, worthy thane?
target: Is the king stirring, worthy thane?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, then, it’s my body’s doomsday.
target: Why, then All Souls' Day is my body’s doomsday.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll make this wedding happen tomorrow morning.
target: I’ll have this knot knit up tomorrow morning.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s worthless.
target: It is but trash.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d rather be a dog and howl at the moon than be that kind of Roman.
target: I had rather be a dog and bay the moon Than such a Roman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We will watch the execution.
target: We will behold his death.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A deed that will make sick men healthy.
target: A piece of work that will make sick men whole.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The reasons for his death are recorded in the Capitol.
target: The question of his death is enrolled in the Capitol.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye, then.
target: Fare ye well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know your position.
target: I know thy quality.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is healthy talk.
target: These be good humors.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Marry her as you should have married her cousin, and I will let my revenge die.
target: Give her the right you should have given her cousin, And so dies my revenge.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thank you, sir.
target: God save you, sir!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know I may be old, but I’m strong and healthy, because in my youth I never drank nor lived recklessly.
target: Though I look old, yet I am strong and lusty, For in my youth I never did apply Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo The means of weakness and debility.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You killed this king, didn’t you?
target: Didst thou not kill this king?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here comes another Jew.
target: Here comes another of the tribe.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s proceed to the field.
target: Let us to the field.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d rather have a jester to make me happy than experience to make me sad—and to travel for all that trouble, no less!
target: I had rather have a fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad— and to travel for it, too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I swear by this hand and my father’s soul, the whole thing is a disaster.
target: By my hand I swear, and my father’s soul, the work ish ill done.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, sir, it’s all too true, God help us.
target: Ay, sir, it is too true, God help the while.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s running bareheaded, calling for the end of the world, out there on a night like this, when even savage animals ravenous with hunger crawl under cover and hide.
target: This night—wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch, The lion and the belly-pinchèd wolf Keep their fur dry—unbonneted he runs, And bids what will take all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What, from myself?
target: What, from myself?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dear man, calm your rage.
target: Good bawcock, 'bate thy rage.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, please, read it like a sane person.
target: So I do, madonna.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He who is dizzy thinks the world is spinning”—please, tell me what you meant by that.
target: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round”— I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re lucky, my lord, to be able to see the peace and sweetness even in what bad luck has brought you.
target: And this our life, exempt from public haunt, Finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks, Sermons in stones, and good in everything.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He is positively stuffed with honorable virtues.
target: He is no less than a stuffed man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My daughter is still very young.
target: My child is yet a stranger in the world.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’ll grow up to be a proper man.
target: He’ll make a proper man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Getting right to the point, I live near the Capitol.
target: Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can hope your father isn’t your real father.
target: Marry, you may partly hope that your father got you not, that you are not the Jew’s daughter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your wife Octavia, with her self-effacing eyes and self-righteous assumptions, won’t get any praise from patronizing me.
target: Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes And still conclusion, shall acquire no honor Demuring upon me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How old are you?
target: How old art thou?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But why am I telling you this?
target: But what talk I of this?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, even if I had a thousand more pounds than that, for I hear that you are  Me, too.
target: Yea, an ’twere a thousand pound more than ’tis, for I hear as good exclamation on your Worship as of any man in the city, and though I be but a poor man, I am glad to hear it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s true, that’s very true.
target: Nay, that’s true, that’s very true.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You wanted to be king of the island, sir?
target: You’d be king o' th' isle, sirrah?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My cousin’s a fool, and you are too.
target: My cousin’s a fool, and thou art another.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She can stay at her father’s house.
target: Why, at her father’s.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why are you locking her away because of this fiend from hell, Signor Baptista?
target: Why will you mew her up, Signior Baptista, for this fiend of hell And make her bear the penance of her tongue?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Maybe some merchant at the marketplace invited him home for lunch.
target: Perhaps some merchant hath invited him, And from the mart he’s somewhere gone to dinner.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go to her and tell her for me.
target: Go you and tell her of it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t worry about me.
target: Fear me not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll do most of the drinking for you.
target: I’ll drink for you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What, are you trying to make me crazy?
target: What, would you make me mad?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We would profane the other dead souls here if we sang the same requiem for her that we sang for them.
target: We should profane the service of the dead To sing a requiem and such rest to her As to peace-parted souls.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let it end, or let me die so I won’t have to watch any more of it.
target: O, preposterous And frantic outrage, end thy damnèd spleen, Or let me die, to look on death no more.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sure, since beauty’s power can more easily change a good girl into a whore than the power of goodness can change a beautiful girl into a virgin.
target: Ay, truly, for the power of beauty will sooner transform honesty from what it is to a bawd than the force of honesty can translate beauty into his likeness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And this is what you told me he said: that he beat you and pretended his house wasn’t his and I wasn’t his wife.
target: By thee; and this thou didst return from him: That he did buffet thee and, in his blows, Denied my house for his, me for his wife.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Damn him!
target: Beshrew him for ’t!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, madam.
target: Ay, madam.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good gentlemen, look like you’re rested and happy.
target: Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Will you help me?—What an ass and a fool, a gullible no-good idiot!
target: Will you help?—An ass-head, and a coxcomb, and a knave, a thin-faced knave, a gull!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, my lord, and calfskin too.
target: Ay, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord, you know I’m your friend.
target: My lord, you know I love you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His daughters want to kill him.
target: His daughters seek his death.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I remember that very clearly!
target: Oh, that record is lively in my soul!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you think that means?
target: What should that bode?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Set the honorable old man down and let him eat.
target: Set down your venerable burden, And let him feed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I remember very well where I should be, and here I am.
target: I do remember well where I should be, And there I am.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Old age always makes people act funny—even wise people, but fools more than anybody.
target: Infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the better fool.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You won’t be seeing anything.—Hold his chair still, men.—I’m going to put my foot on his eyes.
target: See” ’t shalt thou never.—Fellows, hold the chair.— Upon these eyes of thine I’ll set my foot.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, let’s go see King Edward.
target: Come, go we to the king.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, Petruchio.
target: Ay, that Petruchio came.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I reversed the death sentence.
target: The order was reversed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Quiet, you stupid fool.
target: Peace, you dull fool.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There, where the torch is burning.
target: There, where the torch doth burn.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Though I have far more reason, I don’t have as much energy to curse you.
target: Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse Abides in me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, he told me quite bluntly that he didn’t feel like it.
target: Sir, he answered me in the roundest manner he would not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our friendship in our schooldays, our childhood innocence?
target: All schooldays' friendship, childhood innocence?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: May heaven save us from indecent thoughts!
target: Our worser thoughts heavens mend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And didn’t they place the wreath of victory on my brow and order me to give it to you?
target: And did not they Put on my brows this wreath of victory And bid me give it thee?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good morning, father.
target: Good morrow, Father.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Madam, oh, good Empress!
target: Madam, O good Empress!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your heart’s going to break.
target: For shame, put on your gown.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wouldn’t think much of it even if it were heavier.
target: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve sworn I’ll never sleep with him or talk to him again.
target: I have forsworn his bed and company.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Or like a whale.
target: Or like a whale.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I sent Dromio to you with money for bail, but I don’t think he brought it to you.
target: I sent you money, sir, to be your bail By Dromio, but I think he brought it not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So we need another prologue to tell everyone he’s not a real lion.
target: Therefore another prologue must tell he is not a lion.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We will do the same.
target: We are bound to the like.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, that’s the one.
target: Sailors, my lord, they say.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Farewell, farewell.
target: Farewell, farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s Phoebe-ing me.
target: She Phoebes me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thisbe is the lady Pyramus is in love with.
target: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, I won’t give my medicine away to anyone but the sick.
target: No, I will not cast away my physic but on those that are sick.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your praise has beaten you home.
target: Your praise is come too swiftly home before you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, I’ll grant you that.
target: I grant you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’re two lions born on the same day in the same litter, and I’m the older and more terrible.
target: We are two lions littered in one day, And I the elder and more terrible.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Indeed, before you arrived here, old Siward, with ten thousand soldiers already prepared for battle, was making his way here.
target: Whither indeed, before thy here-approach, Old Siward, with ten thousand warlike men, Already at a point, was setting forth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hey!
target: Holla!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I could say hello to the fifth one as happily as I’ll say goodbye to the first four, I’d be very happy he’s coming.
target: If I could bid the fifth welcome with so good a heart as I can bid the other four farewell, I should be glad of his approach.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good!
target: A match!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good night.
target: Give you good night.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Protect me, my friends.
target: O, yet defend me, friends.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It astounds me that such a weak man could beat the whole world and carry the trophy of victory alone.
target: Ye gods, it doth amaze me A man of such a feeble temper should So get the start of the majestic world And bear the palm alone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I was talking to some Venetians down by the shore, and the fool showed up.
target: I was the other day talking on the sea-bank with certain Venetians, and thither comes the bauble and, by this hand, she falls me thus about my neck— Crying “O dear Cassio!” as it were.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My eyes itch—is that an omen I’ll be crying soon?
target: Mine eyes do itch, Doth that bode weeping?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s what’s driving her crazy.
target: That’s her torment.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: To die for adultery?
target: Die for adultery?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I tell you, this house is as dark as ignorance.
target: I say, this house is as dark as ignorance, though ignorance were as dark as hell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lecherous Cleopatra, may all the charms of love soften those withered lips!
target: But all the charms of love, Salt Cleopatra, soften thy wanned lip!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Were you dreaming, Lucius?
target: Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, Cassius.
target: Yes, Cassius.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s Orlando, who triumphed over both the wrestler and you in the same instant.
target: It is young Orlando, that tripped up the wrestler’s heels and your heart both in an instant.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can I have a word with you?
target: Shall I entreat a word?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve stayed up with you for two nights now, and I haven’t seen any evidence of what you were talking about.
target: I have two nights watched with you but can perceive no truth in your report.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, sir.
target: We do, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where is my page?
target: Where is my page?—Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So, I won’t.
target: No, Caesar shall not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will.
target: Well, officer, arrest him at my suit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: These were sweet omens!
target: Sweet bodements!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are they likely to get dusty?
target: Are they like to take dust, like Mistress Mall’s picture?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Be quiet and depart.
target: Be quiet and depart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You seasoned his food with screams.
target: Thou sayst his meat was sauced with thy upbraidings.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If only you had a clearer memory of who you are!
target: O, that once more you knew but what you are!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish I had a fault like that!
target: Would that fault were mine!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish I were in an alehouse in London!
target: Would I were in an alehouse in London!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So what’s the story, old boy?
target: How now, old lad?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll give you letters of introduction to some friends of mine who will help you.
target: You shall Have letters from me to some friends that will Sweep your way for you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now this joke has turned serious.
target: Now your jest is earnest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: May good fortune come to you, good Petruchio!
target: Now, fair befall thee, good Petruchio!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have no doubt that you love me.
target: That you do love me, I am nothing jealous.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can’t see the future.
target: Go, you wild bedfellow, you cannot soothsay.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bloody, inhuman villain!
target: Bloody, bawdy villain!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Attack the breach in the city wall once more, dear friends, attack it once more—or else let’s close it up with English corpses.
target: Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more, Or close the wall up with our English dead!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You probably killed a lot of his men?
target: Belike you slew great number of his people?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Isn’t there a guard around?
target: No watch?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go and tell them this.
target: Go and tell them so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God bless you.
target: God be wi' you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wait for me there.
target: There attend my coming.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The duke will drink under this tree.—He’s been looking for you all day, you know.
target: Well, I’ll end the song.—Sirs, cover the while; the duke will drink under this tree.—He hath been all this day to look you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But truly, if I were as
target: But truly, for mine own part, if I were as tedious as a king, I could find it in my heart to bestow it all of your worship.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, Charmian!
target: Now, Charmian!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me, Voltemand, what’s the news from the king of Norway?
target: Say, Voltemand, what from our brother Norway?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The gentleman she danced with told her you insulted her.
target: The gentleman that danced with her told her she is much wronged by you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go wherever you want.
target: Now go thy way.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m an honest Puck, and I swear that if we’re lucky enough not to get hissed at, we’ll make it up to you soon.
target: And, as I am an honest Puck,  If we have unearnèd luck  Now to ’scape the serpent’s tongue,  We will make amends ere long.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The king, sir, has bet that in a dozen rounds between you and Laertes, he won’t beat you by more than three hits.
target: The king, sir, hath laid that in a dozen passes between yourself and him, he shall not exceed you three hits.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Draw your sword!
target: Draw, you rascal!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why do you ask?
target: Why ask you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Allow me to continue.—I am a gentleman of Verona, sir, who, hearing of your daughter’s beauty and wit, her friendly disposition and bashful modesty, her uncommon virtues and her mild behavior, have taken the liberty of presenting myself as a guest at your house in the hope of seeing for myself if what I’ve heard is true.
target: Give me leave.— I am a gentleman of Verona, sir, That hearing of her beauty and her wit, Her affability and bashful modesty, Her wondrous qualities and mild behavior, Am bold to show myself a forward guest Within your house, to make mine eye the witness Of that report which I so oft have heard.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, it’s just clothing.
target: Yes, it is apparel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now let me tell you, Casca, I have already convinced some of the noblest Romans to join me in an honorable but dangerous mission.
target: Now know you, Casca, I have moved already Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans To undergo with me an enterprise Of honorable-dangerous consequence.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s where I’m going now, so I’ll leave you here.
target: Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So go on, tell me the news.
target: And therefore, good Grumio, the news.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come with me and let me advise you.
target: Go thou with me, and let me counsel thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, sir!
target: My lord, my lord!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, sir.
target: Ay, sir; there are a crew of wretched souls That stay his cure.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What woman wouldn’t be distressed, being lorded over by a handful of dust?
target: Would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered with a piece of valiant dust?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Raise all the money you can.
target: Make all the money thou canst.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come with me, sir.
target: Come, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Send the necklace to her, or send me with a token that will authorize her to pay me.

target: If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds, Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look at him.
target: Thou art the thing itself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hear a noise inside.

target: Away before me to sweet beds of flowers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish my eyes were
target: Would they were basilisks to strike thee dead.

target: Villain, thou didst deny the gold’s receipt And told’st me of a mistress and a dinner, For which, I hope, thou felt’st I was displeased.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You did it?
target: Did you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll never see it.
target: I’ll never see ’t!

target: Who talks of my nation?

target: Give him tending.

target: Seek him, bid him come hither.

target: Let them affright thee.

target: Why then, the mustard without the beef.

target: And as I say, retire with me to my lodging, from whence I will fitly bring you to hear my lord speak.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ah well, my Kate.
target: Well, come, my Kate.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Virtue turns to vice if it’s misused.
target: Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied, And vice sometime by action dignified.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you can leave your body so easily, then the touch of death is like a lover’s pinch, which hurts but is desired.
target: If thou and nature can so gently part, The stroke of death is as a lover’s pinch, Which hurts, and is desired.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good-bye, noble Agrippa.
target: Adieu, noble Agrippa.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The wide ocean doesn’t prevent them from coming to see her—they travel across it as if it were a little stream.
target: The watery kingdom, whose ambitious head Spits in the face of heaven, is no bar To stop the foreign spirits, but they come As o'er a brook to see fair Portia.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You expect me to cry?
target: You think I’ll weep?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sweet Sir Andrew!
target: Sweet Sir Andrew!

target: Hold, hold, my heart, And you, my sinews, grow not instant old, But bear me stiffly up.

target: You have been factious one against the other.— Wife, love Lord Hastings.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Follow me.
target: Follow me.

target: Do but go after And mark how he continues.

target: Then move not, while my prayer’s effect I take.

target: Why did you laugh then, when I said “man delights not me”?

target: Had I but died an hour before this chance, I had lived a blessèd time, for from this instant There’s nothing serious in mortality.

target: This is the penthouse under which Lorenzo Desired us to make stand.

target: Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile.

target: In troth, I think thou wouldst not.

target: O, how we joy to see your wit restored!

target: No, I do not know you, nor I am not sent to you by my lady, to bid you come speak with her, nor your name is not Master Cesario, nor this is not my nose neither.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: On top of her?
target: lie on her?

target: Why, what effects of passion shows she?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I bet she’s fast asleep.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Just cry out, “Ah me!” Just say “love” and “dove.” Say just one lovely word to my good friend
target: Cry but “Ay me!” Pronounce but “love” and “dove.” Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word, One nickname for her purblind son and heir, Young Abraham Cupid, he that shot so true When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid.— He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: These chatty fellows who can rhyme their way into a lady’s good graces always reason themselves out again.
target: For these fellows of infinite tongue, that can rhyme themselves into ladies' favors, they do always reason themselves out again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If she sends any letters to Richmond, you will be accountable to me for it.
target: If she convey Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I make her angry sometimes by saying that Paris is more handsome than you are.
target: I anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now please go.
target: Pray you, away.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Three times today my horse stumbled and started when he looked in the direction of the Tower, as if he hated to carry me to this slaughterhouse.
target: Three times today my foot-cloth horse did stumble, And started when he looked upon the Tower, As loath to bear me to the slaughterhouse.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t know.
target: I do not know.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You will.
target: And you shall be satisfied.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My uncle is king of Denmark, and the same people who made fun of him while my father was still alive are now rushing to pay twenty, forty, fifty, a hundred ducats apiece for miniature portraits of him.
target: For my uncle is King of Denmark, and those that would make mouths at him while my father lived give twenty, forty, fifty, a hundred ducats apiece for his picture in little.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Her reputation is also her own.
target: She is protectress of her honor too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m going to rest my head on this little slope.
target: Find you out a bed, For I upon this bank will rest my head.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In this house lives a man who despises all that is good in you.
target: Within this roof The enemy of all your graces lives.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Three words, dear Romeo, and then it’s good night for real.
target: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look!
target: Lo thee!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They show their bloody heralds of battle, and something must be done immediately.
target: Their bloody sign of battle is hung out, And something to be done immediately.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Kind gentlemen, I won’t forget the trouble you’ve taken for me whenever I think of this day.
target: Kind gentlemen, your pains Are registered where every day I turn The leaf to read them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is it really possible that you could like her right after meeting her?
target: Is ’t possible that on so little acquaintance you should like her?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord, you’re wrong to berate her like that.
target: You are to blame, my lord, to rate her so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Indeed, I should have asked you before who he was.
target: Indeed, I should have asked thee that before.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Every old man has worries, and worried men never get any sleep, but young men shouldn’t have a care in the world.
target: Care keeps his watch in every old man’s eye, And where care lodges, sleep will never lie.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Invite all my sad captains.
target: Call to me All my sad captains.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Right on cue, here’s the duke himself.
target: In happy time here comes the duke himself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is going even better than I planned.
target: This falls out better than I could devise.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, for three months.
target: Ay, sir, for three months.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then everything must really be finished.
target: Why then, good night indeed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord?
target: My lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Gratiano talks more nonsense than any other man in Venice.
target: Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing, more than any man in all Venice.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t say what you’re thinking, and don’t be too quick to act on what you think.
target: Give thy thoughts no tongue, Nor any unproportioned thought his act.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The  Right.
target: Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Run, run, my lord.
target: Fly, fly, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That was a fine fanfare, boys.
target: Tis well blown, lads.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You look angry.
target: You look angerly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shake off sleep, which looks like death, and look at death itself!
target: Shake off this downy sleep, death’s counterfeit, And look on death itself!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take away the stools, the sideboards, and the plates.
target: Away with the joint-stools, remove the court-cupboard, look to the plate.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What a wonderful time to be alive!
target: How quickly the wrong side may be turned outward!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, your age and status inspire more respect than your weapons do.
target: Good signior, you shall more command with years Than with your weapons.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He looks calmer than he did before.
target: He looks gentler than he did.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s best to rehearse there, because if we do it here in the city, we’ll be bothered by crowds of people and everyone will know the plot of our play.
target: There will we rehearse, for if we meet in the city we shall be dogged with company, and our devices known.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your Grace heard their saccharine words, but didn’t take note of their poisonous intentions.
target: Your Grace attended to their sugared words But looked not on the poison of their hearts.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s obedient—a fine lady.
target: Truly, an obedient lady.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s happening to me, that I’m frightened of every noise?
target: How is ’t with me when every noise appals me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, in and of itself, it is a good life, but given that it’s a shepherd’s life, it’s worthless.
target: Truly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a good life; but in respect that it is a shepherd’s life, it is naught.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good Prince, say something!
target: Sweet Prince, why speak not you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you still so cruel?
target: Still so cruel?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shame on you, warped hag!
target: Thou changèd and self-covered thing, for shame!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t go near Casca.
target: Come not near Casca.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I pray that the mighty gods defend you!
target: The mighty gods defend thee!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d give forty pounds to be safe at home right now.
target: I had rather than forty pound I were at home.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We three couples will celebrate with a sumptuous feast.
target: Three and three, We’ll hold a feast in great solemnity.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The evil that men do is remembered after their deaths, but the good is often buried with them.
target: The evil that men do lives after them; The good is oft interrèd with their bones.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go, coward that you are.
target: Go, coward as thou art.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I won’t keep you very long.
target: I will not hold thee long.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well.
target: Why, so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lay me next to my mistress.
target: Oh, lay me by my mistress' side.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your grandsons will neigh to you like horses.
target: You’ll have your nephews neigh to you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For three months.
target: And for three months.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s a horrible thing to die when you’re not prepared for it, my gracious lord.
target: Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord, When men are unprepared and look not for it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No I don’t, believe me.
target: Not I, believe me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I am at your service.
target: My love is thine to teach.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A victory in battle is twice as victorious when all the soldiers return home safely.
target: A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings home full numbers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve already had a glass of wine tonight, watered down, but look how drunk I am.
target: I have drunk but one cup tonight, and that was craftily qualified too, and behold what innovation it makes here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What is a traitor?
target: What is a traitor?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, madam, he lies beyond my reach.
target: Ay, madam, from the reach of these my hands.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your answer is so strange!
target: How oddly thou repliest!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A pound of human flesh taken isn’t even as valuable as a pound of mutton or beef.
target: A pound of man’s flesh taken from a man Is not so estimable, profitable neither, As flesh of muttons, beefs, or goats.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God help me!
target: Bless us!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen, listen!
target: Hark, hark!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I believe it won’t stop moving and stand upright till Richard wears the wreath of the realm.
target: It is a reeling world indeed, my lord, And I believe will never stand upright Till Richard wear the garland of the realm.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your father!
target: Thy father!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So did I.
target: And so did I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you going to say good things about the man who killed your cousin?
target: Will you speak well of him that killed your cousin?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have you heard of me, most noble Empress?
target: Most noble Empress, you have heard of me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This messenger is wise.
target: The fellow has good judgment.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wouldn’t do it for a nice ring, or fine linen, or pretty gowns or petticoats or hats.
target: Marry, I would not do such a thing for a joint-ring, nor for measures of lawn, nor for gowns, petticoats, nor caps, nor any petty exhibition.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, brighter lights always dim the smaller ones.
target: So doth the greater glory dim the less.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There may be a time for everything, but no man who has gone bald naturally can get his hair back.
target: There’s no time for a man to recover his hair that grows bald by nature.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She takes these signs for warnings and predictions of terrible evils to come, and, on her knee, she begged me to stay home today.
target: And these does she apply for warnings and portents And evils imminent, and on her knee Hath begged that I will stay at home today.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is your job.
target: This is thy office.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get to the point now.
target: Come to what is important in ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who are you?
target: Who are you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In God’s name, who are you?
target: In God’s name, what art thou?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Perhaps a woman’s voice may do some good when some small detail proves to be holding things up.
target: Haply a woman’s voice may do some good, When articles too nicely urged be stood on.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t talk to me, Emilia.
target: Do not talk to me, Emilia.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What did he do when you saw him?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh,  Master, master, look!
target: Master, master, look about you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Remember that Hamlet is young and has a lot more freedom to fool around than you do.
target: For Lord Hamlet, Believe so much in him that he is young, And with a larger tether may he walk Than may be given you.

target: There’s rosemary, that’s for remembrance.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll go and chat with Paris.

target: Get horses for your mistress.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hear some noise.
target: I hear some noise.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, because I saw your niece Olivia treat the count’s messenger better than she’s ever treated me.
target: Marry, I saw your niece do more favors to the Count’s servingman than ever she bestowed upon me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Very well.
target: Very well.

target: It shall lose thee nothing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As for Antony, I’m not interested in his requests.
target: For Antony, I have no ears to his request.

target: Here thought they to have done Some wanton charm upon this man and maid, Whose vows are that no bed-right shall be paid Till Hymen’s torch be lighted—but in vain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Time ambles for both men.
target: These time ambles withal.

target: The spirits that know All mortal consequences have pronounced me thus: “Fear not, Macbeth.

target: And here am I, and wood within this wood, Because I cannot meet my Hermia.

target: Where is she?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hit them!
target: Strike!

target: I’ll ride home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

target: Good my lord, If I have any grace or power to move you His present reconciliation take.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Kent, father, sisters!
target: Kent, father, sisters!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Merciful God!
target: O mercy, God!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, good luck!
target: Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: justice will be rewarded.
target: He that conceals him, death.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh yes, three thousand ducats.
target: Ay, ay, three thousand ducats.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We have consented to all reasonable terms.
target: We have consented to all terms of reason.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Nobody like that should be trusted.
target: Let no such man be trusted.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your voice is loud and commanding, but you look like a working man.
target: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thus far has our straining author pursued the story with his crude, inadequate writing, keeping important people penned up in this little room while he mangled history’s full glory with his uneven telling.
target: Thus far with rough and all-unable pen Our bending author hath pursued the story, In little room confining mighty men, Mangling by starts the full course of their glory.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A nice coincidence, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God alive!

target: Sblood, do you think I am easier to be played on than a pipe?

target: O Scotland, Scotland!

target: All that I have to say is to tell you that the lanthorn is the moon; I, the man in the moon; this thornbush, my thornbush; and this dog, my dog.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And, as the speaker of any prologue should, I ask you to hear our play courteously and to judge it kindly.
target: Turning th' accomplishment of many years Into an hour-glass; for the which supply, Admit me chorus to this history; Who, prologue-like, your humble patience pray Gently to hear, kindly to judge our play.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I cannot blame you now for weeping.
target: I cannot blame thee now to weep, For such an injury would vex a very saint, Much more a shrew of thy impatient humor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lead’s too crass to hold her.
target: It were too gross To rib her cerecloth in the obscure grave.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The answer, my dear, is that they didn’t dare, because the people of Milan loved me too much.
target: Dear, they durst not, So dear the love my people bore me, nor set A mark so bloody on the business, but With colors fairer painted their foul ends.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Delay this marriage for a month, or a week.
target: Delay this marriage for a month, a week.

target: It shall be done.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For my brother Edward’s sake.
target: For Edward, for my brother, for his sake.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As my child, I order you to do so.
target: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Men tend to be at their most irresponsible when they’re away from home.
target: We never valued this poor seat of England And therefore, living hence, did give ourself To barbarous license, as ’tis ever common That men are merriest when they are from home.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: From the time I was seventeen, over sixty years ago, I have lived in this house, but now I will live here no more.
target: From seventeen years till now almost fourscore Here livèd I, but now live here no more.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She stood and spoke.
target: She stood and spake.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dying, sleeping—that’s all dying is—a sleep that ends all the heartache and shocks that life on earth gives us—that’s an achievement to wish for.
target: To die, to sleep— No more—and by a sleep to say we end The heartache and the thousand natural shocks That flesh is heir to—’tis a consummation Devoutly to be wished!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Eyes, look out for the last time!
target: Eyes, look your last.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Call it a match!
target: Tis a match.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The whole town will riot!
target: The town will rise.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For that kind of relief, the patient must heal herself.
target: Therein the patient Must minister to himself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll give him my gray horse Capilet if he forgets the whole thing.
target: Let him let the matter slip, and I’ll give him my horse, gray Capilet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, to think that the same body that once ruled the world could now patch up a wall!
target: Oh, that that earth, which kept the world in awe, Should patch a wall t' expel the winter’s flaw!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But that’s another story.
target: But let that go.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s really taken this prank to heart.
target: His very genius hath taken the infection of the device, man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m not a doddering old fool who brags about the things he did when he was young, and what he would do now if he weren’t so old.
target: I speak not like a dotard nor a fool, As under privilege of age to brag What I have done being young, or what would do Were I not old.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hardly, Kate.
target: Oh, no, good Kate.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you have to say, my dear Nurse?
target: What sayst thou, my dear Nurse?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: On this hill and in despair, with his slave Pindarus.
target: All disconsolate, With Pindarus his bondman on this hill.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They’ve recorded my crimes, and I would rather die than have to retell this shameful story.
target: My villainy they have upon record, which I had rather seal with my death than repeat over to my shame.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And wanted to see you with laces crisscrossed over your legs.” Crisscrossed?
target: And wished to see thee cross-gartered.” Cross-gartered?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you think it would work?
target: May it be done?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Keep him away from me!
target: Let him not come near me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If this is a dream, let me keep on sleeping!
target: If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!

target: How now, Malvolio?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s the matter?
target: What is the matter, ho?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How old are you, friend?
target: How old are you, friend?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, I can’t.
target: Sir, I cannot.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You were sent for.
target: You were sent for, and there is a kind of confession in your looks which your modesties have not craft enough to color.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me go with you to Belmont.
target: I must go with you to Belmont.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And it’s all your fault.
target: The fault’s your own.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My king says this: “Tell Harry of England: though we appeared dead, we were only asleep.
target: Thus says my king: “Say thou to Harry of England, though we seemed dead, we did but sleep.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It was.
target: It was.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He ran to his house, stunned.
target: Fled to his house amazed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s your music, madam, from your house.
target: It is your music, madam, of the house.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Nevertheless, it’s all one—the two rivers are as alike as my fingers are to my fingers, and there are salmon in both.
target: But ’tis all one; ’tis alike as my fingers is to my fingers, and there is salmons in both.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you have enough love for me to be patient when my bad temper, which I inherited from my mother, makes me forget how I should behave?
target: Have not you love enough to bear with me, When that rash humor which my mother gave me Makes me forgetful?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I could really use his advice right now.
target: His counsel now might do me golden service.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re so neat and well put-together that you look like you love yourself more than anyone else.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You must be ready for revenge, too, when you hear me out.
target: So art thou to revenge when thou shalt hear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But wait a minute!
target: But soft!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think few die well who die in battle.
target: I am afeard there are few die well that die in a battle, for how can they charitably dispose of anything, when blood is their argument?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If he wakes up before we kill him, he’ll never stop punishing us.
target: If he awake, From toe to crown he’ll fill our skins with pinches, Make us strange stuff.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here, take the ring.
target: Receive it so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our poor father, Clarence!
target: Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Murder!
target: Murder!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s strange.
target: That’s strange.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: More shouting!
target: Another general shout!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, no, I can’t, really.
target: No, no, forsooth, I dare not for my life.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Robin Starveling, the tailor?
target: Robin Starveling, the tailor?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll leave you now to chatter and gossip like an old woman.
target: I will leave you now to your gossip-like humor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take away this body, and do what I say.
target: Bear hence this body and attend our will.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Those cowardly, gigantic sides of beef have been responsible for many of your family members getting eaten as a condiment on beef.
target: That same cowardly, giantlike ox-beef hath devoured many a gentleman of your house.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She lied to me, and she may lie to you.
target: She has deceived her father, and may thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So I’d like it copied.
target: Ere it be demanded, As like enough it will, I would have it copied.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s the one.
target: That is he.

target: The rest shall keep as they are.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The door’s right here.
target: Here lies your way.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I do not know that you are as good a man as myself.
target: I do not know you so good a man as myself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Caesar’s knave will bring him a message for us.
target: This jack of Caesar’s shall Bear us an errand to him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here comes Antony.
target: Here comes Antony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How beautiful the moonlight’s shining on this bank!

target: She told her, while she kept it 'Twould make her amiable and subdue my father Entirely to her love, but if she lost it Or made gift of it, my father’s eye Should hold her loathèd and his spirits should hunt After new fancies.

target: A play there is, my lord, some ten words long, Which is as brief as I have known a play.

target: She did commend my yellow stockings of late, she did praise my leg being cross-gartered, and in this she manifests herself to my love, and with a kind of injunction, drives me to these habits of her liking.

target: How!

target: You have said, sir.

target: Happiest of all is that her gentle spirit Commits itself to yours to be directed As from her lord, her governor, her king.

target: This fellow I remember Since once he played a farmer’s eldest son.

target: My lord is not my lord, nor should I know him Were he in favor as in humor altered.

target: Here come two noble beasts in, a man and a lion.

target: Sir Toby will be sworn that I am no fox, but he will not pass his word for two pence that you are no fool.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can’t force me any more than Hermia can beg me.
target: Thou canst compel no more than she entreat.

target: Hid’st thou that forehead with a golden crown Where should be branded, if that right were right, The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown And the dire death of my poor sons and brothers?

target: What shall I call thee when thou art a man?

target: This course I fittest choose, For forty ducats is too much to lose.

target: But, sir, forgive me, Since my becomings kill me when they do not Eye well to you.

target: Will you walk, sir?—O Desdemona— My lord?

target: What if it come to thee again?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will confess it to all the world.
target: I will confess it to all the 'orld.

target: We have two hours To furnish us.

target: You are early stirring.

target: I’ll do ’t, but it dislikes me.

target: If this uncouth forest yield anything savage, I will either be food for it or bring it for food to thee.

target: For love I followed him.

target: The best?

target: You’ll let us in, I hope?

target: I am sure you know him well enough.

target: O wonderful son that can so ’stonish a mother!

target: Long love doth so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You are their heir and sit on their throne, and the blood and courage that glorified them run in your veins.
target: You are their heir, you sit upon their throne, The blood and courage that renownèd them Runs in your veins; and my thrice-puissant liege Is in the very May-morn of his youth, Ripe for exploits and mighty enterprises.

target: Come, my lord, and in our flight Tell me how it came this night That I sleeping here was found With these mortals on the ground.

target: If thou pleasest not, I yield thee up my life.

target: I Beyond all limit of what else i' th' world Do love, prize, honor you.

target: I will be bitter with him and passing short.

target: I led them on in this distracted fear And left sweet Pyramus translated there.

target: The English are embattled, you French peers.

target: Bespeak him a fortnight before.—I will have the heart of him if he forfeit, for were he out of Venice I can make what merchandise I will.—Go, go, Tubal, and meet me at our synagogue.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I’m still afraid.
target: But yet I feel I fear.

target: Let specialties be therefore drawn between us, That covenants may be kept on either hand.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Gentlemen, I don’t know what you intend to do, who else you intend to kill, who else you consider corrupt.
target: I know not, gentlemen, what you intend, Who else must be let blood, who else is rank.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will go find him.
target: To him will I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Set down your honorable load, men, if there is ever any honor in being dead.
target: Set down, set down your honorable load, If honor may be shrouded in a hearse, Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament Th' untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, proud Death, what banquet are you preparing that you’ve needed to knock off so many princes at one stroke?
target: O proud death, What feast is toward in thine eternal cell, That thou so many princes at a shot So bloodily hast struck?

target: But now I see our lances are but straws, Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare, That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I wish you weren’t, you poor, frightened soul.
target: O, that thou wert not, poor distressèd soul!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s the matter?
target: What’s the matter?

target: Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice and desire her to rise.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bardolph, be happy.—Nym, rouse your bragging spirits.—Boy, be brave.
target: He’s in Arthur’s bosom, if ever man went to Arthur’s bosom.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh my, what’s the news?
target: Ay me, what news?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m going to cry.
target: I will weep.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Never!
target: O illegitimate construction!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It is best to marry well and die young, better than to be married for a long time.
target: She’s not well married that lives married long, But she’s best married that dies married young.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s full of good intentions.
target: She’s framed as fruitful As the free elements.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So let me sleep next to you.
target: Then by your side no bed room me deny.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll do well.
target: I shall do well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, dainty duck!
target: O dainty duck!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Help me!
target: Oh, help, ho!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Master, I’m all tied up for you.
target: Master, I am here entered in bond for you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who was it that came here?
target: Who was ’t came by?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why?
target: Wherefore?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you a god, an angel, or a devil, that you make my blood turn cold and my hair stand up?
target: Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Her only flaw—and it’s a big one—is that she’s unbearable, a total witch, so much so that I wouldn’t think of marrying her myself, not even if I were in a worse fix than I am, not for a whole goldmine.
target: Her only fault, and that is faults enough, Is that she is intolerable curst, And shrewd and froward, so beyond all measure That, were my state far worser than it is, I would not wed her for a mine of gold.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What?
target: As birds do, Mother.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Many thanks, Signior Gremio.
target: A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, my lord, if you would like.
target: Ay, my lord, an ’t please you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, yes!
target: Ay, ay.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How long has he been there?
target: How long hath he been there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And when some lowlife protests that  Stop, and eat no more.
target: Forbear, and eat no more.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Farewell, everyone.
target: Farewell, everyone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m not sleepy at all.
target: I find not Myself disposed to sleep.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hold the friar too.
target: Stay the friar too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Nobody was hurt in the slightest.
target: Not a hair perished.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Great kings of France and England, I owe you both equal service and loyalty.
target: My duty to you both, on equal love, Great kings of France and England.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Poor Tom’s chilly.
target: Poor Tom’s a-cold.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can have it then, your highness.
target: Thy grace shall have it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Two or three more lords and ladies have been married too.
target: Masters, the duke is coming from the temple, and there is two or three lords and ladies more married.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: To be brief—as the occasion requires—prepare to fight early in the morning, when your future will be decided.
target: In brief, for so the season bids us be, Prepare thy battle early in the morning, And put thy fortune to the arbitrament Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You would have made me treat them like a tyrant.—I’m done, my lord.
target: For thy escape would teach me tyranny, To hang clogs on them.—I have done, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, sir, you are too good at predicting the future.
target: O sir, you are too sure an augurer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re right, Lysander’s admirable too.
target: In himself he is.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I am no tyrant but a Christian king, whose emotions are as tightly controlled as the wretches who languish in our prisons.
target: We are no tyrant, but a Christian king, Unto whose grace our passion is as subject As is our wretches fettered in our prisons.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The four suitors are looking for you so they can say goodbye, madam.
target: The four strangers seek for you, madam, to take their leave.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do not, Phoebe.
target: Do not, Phoebe.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have already.
target: I have already.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You abused me to my face.
target: It was ourself thou didst abuse.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Killing pigs.
target: Killing swine.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Titinius, if you love me, get on your horse and spur him on until he’s brought you to those troops and back again, so that I can find out whether those troops are friends or enemies.
target: Titinius, if thou lovest me, Mount thou my horse, and hide thy spurs in him Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops And here again, that I may rest assured Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You may think that I don’t love you.
target: You may think I love you not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus.
target: And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I don’t answer, perhaps you’ll think I’m accepting the heavy responsibility you foolishly want to impose on me.
target: If not to answer, you might haply think Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty, Which fondly you would here impose on me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you riding far?
target: Is ’t far you ride?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How’s my nephew doing, noble lord of York?
target: How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I shook you and shouted at you, sir.
target: I shaked you, sir, and cried.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It was two o'clock when I left him, and now it’s one.
target: It was two ere I left him, and now the clock strikes one.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you’re happy with what you’ve won And accept this prize as your blissful destiny, Then turn to where your lady is, And claim her with a loving kiss.”
target: If you be well pleased with this And hold your fortune for your bliss, Turn you where your lady is And claim her with a loving kiss.”

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester, follow Fluellen at a close distance.
target: My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester, Follow Fluellen closely at the heels.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll tell you: it’s because of a law as plain as Father Time’s bald head.
target: Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald pate of Father Time himself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let heaven be my witness—I’m putting my mind, my heart, and my hands in Othello’s control.
target: Witness, you ever-burning lights above, You elements that clip us round about, Witness that here Iago doth give up The execution of his wit, hands, heart, To wronged Othello’s service.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The gods forbid!
target: The gods forbid!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, I tell you that we are not.
target: Sir, I say to you we are none.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Fine, thank you.
target: Well, God-'a'-mercy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m as commanding as she is proud, and when two raging fires meet, they end up consuming the very thing that kindled them.
target: For I tell you, father, I am as peremptory as she proud-minded; And where two raging fires meet together, They do consume the thing that feeds their fury.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ll be pricked all over, and it’ll sting like bees.
target: Thou shalt be pinched As thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stinging Than bees that made 'em.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then tell them to treat us well.
target: Then let them use us well, else let them know, The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go to bed, and sleep.
target: Why, go to bed, and sleep.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, how wonderful to see you!
target: O most courageous day!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go.
target: Go.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re my true and honorable wife, as dear to me as the blood that runs through my sad heart.
target: You are my true and honorable wife, As dear to me as are the ruddy drops That visit my sad heart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s as common for us old people to assume we know more than we do as for young people to be too wild and crazy.
target: By heaven, it is as proper to our age To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions As it is common for the younger sort To lack discretion.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’s no bravery in an unfair fight.
target: In a false quarrel there is no true valor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m here, my lord.
target: Here, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, you can go now.
target: Well, get thee gone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re thought to be the most
target: You are thought here to be the most senseless and fit man for the constable of the watch; therefore bear you the lantern.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: At that time you can smash in his skull after seizing his books; or you can bash his skull with a log; or you can stab him in the belly; or cut his windpipe.
target: There thou mayst brain him, Having first seized his books; or with a log Batter his skull; or paunch him with a stake; Or cut his weasand with thy knife.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Antony’s eyes are fiery red from crying.
target: His eyes are red as fire with weeping.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m as crazy as he is, if sad craziness and happy craziness are equivalent.
target: I am as mad as he, If sad and merry madness equal be.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I suggest you lay low until his rage cools a little.
target: I pray you, have a continent forbearance till the speed of his rage goes slower.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who are the people who want to speak with me?
target: Who shall stay you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh God, I wish the two of them were alive and living in Naples, as king and queen!
target: O heavens, that they were living both in Naples, The king and queen there!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Instead of Celia, call me Aliena.
target: But what will you be called?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good night, Lord Brutus.
target: Good night, Lord Brutus.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then my love is humble.
target: My affections Are then most humble.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me one kiss, and I’ll go down.
target: One kiss, and I’ll descend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you hadn’t been their father, your white hair would have inspired in them only compassion.
target: Had you not been their father, these white flakes Did challenge pity of them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This way, we can see how the world moves.
target: Thus we may see,” quoth he, “how the world wags.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have I done something to offend you without knowing it?
target: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Okay, bring on the play.
target: Let them play it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In my travels, great scholars have come up to me, meaning to greet me with well-rehearsed welcoming speeches, and I have seen them tremble and turn pale, and pause inappropriately in the middle of their sentences, and botch their well-rehearsed tones of voice because they’re so nervous, and then break off abruptly at the end, without actually welcoming me.
target: Where I have come, great clerks have purposèd To greet me with premeditated welcomes, Where I have seen them shiver and look pale, Make periods in the midst of sentences, Throttle their practiced accent in their fears, And in conclusion dumbly have broke off, Not paying me a welcome.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, try to act a little more serious, or the people in Belmont will get the wrong impression about me, and your wildness will make me blow my chance with Portia.
target: Pray thee, take pain To allay with some cold drops of modesty Thy skipping spirit, lest through thy wild behavior I be misconst’red in the place I go to, And lose my hopes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The games are done and Caesar is returning.
target: The games are done and Caesar is returning.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did you think I was talking about sex?
target: Do you think I meant country matters?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Because when rich villains need poor villains' services, those poor ones can name the price.
target: For when rich villains have need of poor ones, poor ones may make what price they will.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think I can do that.
target: To do this is within the compass of man’s wit, and therefore I will attempt the doing it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She only appears honorable from the outside.
target: She’s but the sign and semblance of her honor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But it has bay windows that are as transparent as stone walls, and the upper windows facing south-north are as clear as coal.
target: Why, it hath bay windows transparent as barricadoes, and the clerestories toward the south-north are as lustrous as ebony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Edmund and I have talked, and it makes more sense for him to marry me than Goneril.
target: Edmund and I have talked, And more convenient is he for my hand Than for your lady’s.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That way I can conquer my own fear and sleep easy at night.
target: Thou shalt not live, That I may tell pale-hearted fear it lies, And sleep in spite of thunder.
