source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is that what he says?
target: He says so, Tranio?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I guess it doesn’t matter.
target: And yet no matter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why “let it strike”?
target: Why let it strike?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You stay on the left.
target: Keep thou the left.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A ghost, a ghost!
target: A spirit, a spirit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So I recommend you take note of what I’m about to say.
target: Therefore I do advise you, take this note.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Boys, how are you both doing?
target: Good lads, how do you both?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hey, open the door!
target: Ho, open the door.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here comes the man who rescued me, sir.
target: Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll talk about this later.
target: More of this hereafter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, good Demetrius, will you find him for me?
target: Ah, good Demetrius, wilt thou give him me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I won’t tolerate him.
target: You’ll not endure him!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And so, on the wings of imagination and at the speed of thought, our scene flies swiftly on.
target: Thus with imagined wing our swift scene flies In motion of no less celerity Than that of thought.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, go on your way, then.
target: Well, go thy way.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where is that moron of a cook?
target: Where is the rascal cook?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ariel, you’ve done your work exactly as I ordered.
target: Ariel, thy charge Exactly is performed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When he wakes up!
target: He’ll say ’twas done cowardly, when he wakes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, my, it’s my husband.
target: Ay me, it is my husband.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t know, madam.
target: I know not, madam.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And love doesn’t have good judgment either—Cupid, has wings and no eyes, so he’s bound to be reckless and hasty.
target: Nor hath Love’s mind of any judgment taste— Wings and no eyes figure unheedy haste.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thank you, I’m sure.
target: Sure we thank you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But will it be soon?
target: But shall ’t be shortly?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What on earth does that mean?
target: Can anything be made of this?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll write how, under his flag and with his well-paid troops, we have beaten the formerly unvanquished Parthia.
target: I’ll humbly signify what in his name, That magical word of war, we have effected: How with his banners and his well-paid ranks The ne’er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia We have jaded out o’ th’ field.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s incredible—they didn’t say a word.
target: Now, by the holy mother of our Lord, The citizens are mum, say not a word.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, you tanned fieldworkers who are so tired of August’s labors, get out of the dirt and come rejoice with us here.
target: You sunburnt sicklemen of August weary, Come hither from the furrow and be merry.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And you’ve done well on land.
target: And you by land.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Their guilt is finally starting to gnaw at them, like a slow-acting poison.
target: Their great guilt, Like poison given to work a great time after, Now 'gins to bite the spirits.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s time to leave.
target: Tis time to part.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Use your clubs and spears!
target: Clubs, bills, and partisans!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Menas, I’m not going back on shore.
target: Menas, I’ll not on shore.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You are right, it’s for my mistress.
target: You are i' the right, sir, ’tis for my mistress.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wait, madam.
target: Stay, madam.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stay here.
target: Stay here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s midnight.
target: Tis midnight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please do, madam.
target: Good madam, do.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Damn it!
target: And nothing is at a like goodness still.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You know what, my lord?
target: Wot you what, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There must be some resolution.
target: There must be conclusions.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They’ll be married tomorrow, and I’ll invite the duke to the ceremony.
target: They shall be married tomorrow, and I will bid the duke to the nuptial.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ll make me angry.
target: You’ll heat my blood.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hope you’re strong enough to do it.
target: Now let thy friendly hand Put strength enough to ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, Emilia, ask Cassio where he was at dinner tonight.—
target: Prithee, Emilia, Go know of Cassio where he supped tonight.—

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You never heard of the Centaur?
target: You know no Centaur?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is not a maiden, as you say, but an old man—wrinkled, faded, and withered.
target: This is a man—old, wrinkled, faded, withered— And not a maiden, as thou say’st he is.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Never, my lord.
target: Never, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who pronounced this death sentence before a court of law could even convict me?
target: Or who pronounced The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death Before I be convict by course of law?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hey!
target: What, ho!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: While he was still in Rome, he deployed his forces in so many different disguises that all our spies were fooled.
target: While he was yet in Rome His power went out in such distractions as Beguiled all spies.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I do suffer love, because I love you against my will.
target: I do suffer love indeed, for I love thee against my will.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good lord!
target: Blessed pudding!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Young man, your father’s dead.
target: Sirrah, your father’s dead.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, one child is one too many!
target: O, one too much by thee!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s as ugly in his manners as he is in appearance.— I will indeed.
target: He is as disproportioned in his manners As in his shape.— Take with you your companions.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For instance, our husbands
target: Say that they slack their duties

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But soon I’ll see the gods punish you for your lack of respect to your father.
target: But I shall see The wingèd vengeance overtake such children.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have only come in—like the others have—to try to fight him with the strength of my youth.
target: I come but in as others do, to try with him the strength of my youth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, my lord.
target: Ay, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, only time can sort out this mess.
target: O time, thou must untangle this, not I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Be careful, Signior Baptista, lest you be made the dupe in this business.
target: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catched in this business.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If my lips had the power to give life, I would wear them out like this.
target: Had my lips that power, Thus would I wear them out.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s not manly to cry.
target: These foolish drops do something drown my manly spirit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hooray!
target: Hoo!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You just fell the height of ten ship masts, straight down.
target: Ten masts at each make not the altitude Which thou hast perpendicularly fell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It was a huge mistake to let old Gloucester live after we blinded him.
target: It was great ignorance, Gloucester’s eyes being out, To let him live.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Gentle gods in heaven, please let me die.
target: You ever gentle gods, take my breath from me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, dear.
target: Oh, well-a-day, Lady!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is it a habit of his?
target: Is it his use?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go back with her?
target: Return with her?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, she can get used to it.
target: Why, let her except, before excepted.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then she was even more an angel, and you’re an even blacker devil!
target: Oh, the more angel she, And you the blacker devil!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That will never happen.
target: That will never be.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sure, to a cheap host and an even cheaper guest.
target: Ay, to a niggardly host and more sparing guest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, get out of here then!
target: Why, get you gone!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You are very welcome here.
target: You are welcome.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your physical health matters more than your reputation.
target: There is more sense in that than in reputation.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know he wouldn’t be a wolf if the Romans didn’t act like sheep.
target: I know he would not be a wolf But that he sees the Romans are but sheep.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, we’ve missed the beginning; it’s dead and buried.
target: Well, the beginning that is dead and buried.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ingratitude is always hideous, but an ungrateful child is uglier than a sea monster!
target: Ingratitude, thou marble-hearted fiend, More hideous when thou show’st thee in a child Than the sea monster.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re looking for Lord Hamlet.
target: You go to seek the Lord Hamlet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s good advice.
target: Gramercies, Tranio, well dost thou advise.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Am I on earth, in heaven, or in hell?
target: Am I in earth, in heaven, or in hell?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I was bound to him an hour ago, sir, but thankfully he chewed through our ropes.
target: Within this hour I was his bondman sir, But he, I thank him, gnawed in two my cords.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll give the first one, Pompey.
target: That will I, Pompey.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: To hell with you!
target: Fie on thee, wretch.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So goodbye until we meet again.
target: So fare you well till we shall meet again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I refuse to accept that.
target: I cannot be so answer’d.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What is fated to happen must happen.
target: What is decreed must be, and be this so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve practiced Stoicism with as much devotion as you, but I still couldn’t bear this news like you do.
target: I have as much of this in art as you, But yet my nature could not bear it so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s going on, Othello, darling?
target: How now, my dear Othello?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s all there is to say.
target: There is no more to say?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Has he come home yet?
target: Is he come home yet?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He looks like someone with a strange tale to tell.
target: So should he look That seems to speak things strange.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look, sir.
target: Behold, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hope lightning strikes her in the eyes!
target: You nimble lightnings, dart your blinding flames Into her scornful eyes!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Brutus” and “Caesar.” What’s so special about “Caesar”?
target: Brutus and Caesar—what should be in that “Caesar”?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Curse you all, you’re all murderers and traitors!
target: A plague upon you, murderers, traitors all!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s there, aside from this foul weather?
target: Who’s there, besides foul weather?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do I, sir?
target: Have I, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I can tell him that you have submitted to him sweetly, he’ll request your assistance in finding ways in which he can support you.
target: Let me report to him Your sweet dependency, and you shall find A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness Where he for grace is kneeled to.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s the tragedy of our times that lunatics must lead the blind.
target: Tis the time’s plague when madmen lead the blind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d hate to waste my speech on the wrong person, because It’s very well written and I spent a lot of time and energy memorizing it.
target: I would be loath to cast away my speech, for besides that it is excellently well penned, I have taken great pains to con it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The moon has set.
target: The moon is down.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You go and take care of your business (since everybody has some business to take care of, whatever it is worth), and I’ll go and pray.
target: You, as your business and desire shall point you— For every man has business and desire, Such as it is—and for my own poor part, Look you, I’ll go pray.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Cover the sky with a low-hanging fog, as dark as hell, and get these overeager rivals so completely lost in the woods that they can’t run into each other.
target: The starry welkin cover thou anon With drooping fog as black as Acheron, And lead these testy rivals so astray As one come not within another’s way.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll let you know my answer shortly.
target: I will resolve you herein presently.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t know.
target: I know not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But if we have reasons that are strong enough to ignite cowards into action and to make weak women brave—and I think we do—then, countrymen, what else could we possibly need to spur us to action?
target: But if these— As I am sure they do—bear fire enough To kindle cowards and to steel with valor The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen, What need we any spur but our own cause To prick us to redress?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stay with us tonight.
target: Stay with us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go and put on your own armor.
target: Go put on thy defenses.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I love him dearly, and I shall continue to favor him.
target: We love him highly And shall continue our graces towards him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If there’s anyone in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar’s, I say to him that my love for Caesar was no less than his.
target: If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar’s, to him I say that Brutus' love to Caesar was no less than his.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wake up!
target: Awake!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What, is he dead?
target: What, is he dead?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As you all know, overconfidence is man’s greatest enemy.
target: And you all know, security Is mortals' chiefest enemy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I remember a fight, but not why we were fighting.
target: A quarrel, but nothing wherefore.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This terrible storm has smashed the Turks so badly that their plans are ruined.
target: The desperate tempest hath so banged the Turks, That their designment halts.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here comes Ensign Pistol and his wife.
target: Here comes Ancient Pistol and his wife.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Welcome, good Robin.
target: Welcome, good Robin.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If not, I’ll leave you alone and that’ll be the end of my business.
target: If not, your pardon and my return shall be the end of my business.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, Mother Nature, why did you create lions?
target: O wherefore, Nature, didst thou lions frame?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s speaking now, or perhaps he’s whispering, “Where’s my serpent of the Nile?” For that’s his pet name for me.
target: He’s speaking now, Or murmuring “Where’s my serpent of old Nile?” For so he calls me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then if we lose this battle, you’ll be willing to be led in chains through the streets of Rome?
target: Then if we lose this battle You are contented to be led in triumph Thorough the streets of Rome?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And what did he say?
target: And what said he?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Whenever I mention him, praise him more than any man deserves.
target: When I do name him, let it be thy part To praise him more than ever man did merit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If he’s reluctant, I can convince him.
target: If he be so resolved, I can o'ersway him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come, come, you’re making fun of me.
target: You mock me, madam.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dolabella, I will always be in debt to you.
target: Dolabella, I shall remain your debtor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My sweet, so do I.
target: Sweet, so would I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Those are her orders.
target: Tis her command.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, are we turning to men?
target: Why, shall we turn to men?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Fast!
target: Yare, lower, lower!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Signed,    The poorly treated Malvolio.” Did he write this?
target: The madly used Malvolio.”  Did he write this?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I won’t bet on whether or not any of this is real.
target: Whether this be Or be not, I’ll not swear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I surrender all this magic now, when I’ve summoned some heavenly music to cast a spell, as I’m doing now, I’ll break my staff and bury it far underground, and throw my book of magic spells deeper into the sea than any anchor ever sank.
target: But this rough magic I here abjure, and when I have required Some heavenly music, which even now I do, To work mine end upon their senses that This airy charm is for, I’ll break my staff, Bury it certain fathoms in the earth, And deeper than did ever plummet sound I’ll drown my book.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There is nothing in the world that I love as much as you.
target: I do love nothing in the world so well as you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, keep going, old man; don’t stop like that.
target: Nay, forward, old man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And whoever lives to see that day Will walk with his feet.
target: Then comes the time, who lives to see ’t, That going shall be used with feet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s hiding out in Friar Lawrence’s cell.
target: He is hid at Lawrence' cell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen!
target: Hark!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You sent for me, sir?
target: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This may end without anyone getting killed.
target: This shall end without the perdition of souls.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, oh!
target: Alack, alack!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Carry him to my best room—gently, so he doesn’t wake—and hang all my erotic paintings around him.
target: Carry him gently to my fairest chamber And hang it round with all my wanton pictures.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m speaking for the king, but I look like myself.
target: My voice is now the king’s, my looks mine own.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, but these are our friends.
target: Oh, they are our friends.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d give anything to keep them from seeing you here.
target: I would not for the world they saw thee here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s an excellent, sweet woman, and there’s no doubt that she is virtuous.
target: She’s an excellent sweet lady, and, out of all suspicion, she is virtuous.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: children have lost—or no longer have time to learn—skills that should be a credit to our country.
target: And as our vineyards, fallows, meads, and hedges, Defective in their natures, grow to wildness, Even so our houses and ourselves and children Have lost, or do not learn for want of time, The sciences that should become our country, But grow like savages, as soldiers will

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hello, you idiot.
target: Welcome, ass.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t think I blame you.
target: Take to you no hard thoughts.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: One more thing, sir.
target: One word, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go to sleep, and I will wrap my arms around you.
target: Sleep thou, and I will wind thee in my arms.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hope I see him and hear him again soon.
target: Soon may I hear and see him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If that’s all, gentlemen, I see no problem.
target: If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Iago’s a good man.
target: Iago is most honest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s meet as little as we can.
target: Let’s meet as little as we can.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I did, my lord.
target: I did, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We will wait on you, your majesty.
target: We wait upon your Grace.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m begging you, tell me who it is quickly, and speak fast.
target: I prithee, tell me who is it quickly, and speak apace.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, he’s in a place worse than hell.
target: No, he’s in Tartar limbo, worse than hell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord, Hamlet’s going to his mother’s room.
target: My lord, he’s going to his mother’s closet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, absolutely not.
target: No.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please go away, both of you.
target: Away, I do beseech you, both away.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So get ready to cut off the flesh.
target: Therefore prepare thee to cut off the flesh.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The moon looks sad to me.
target: The moon methinks looks with a watery eye.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The king has broken his heart.
target: The king has killed his heart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your death would prevent that.
target: Let the world see His nobleness well acted, which your death Will never let come forth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Should I perjure my soul by disobeying it?
target: Shall I lay perjury upon my soul?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Didn’t you know?
target: Know you not the cause?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What is logical, then, my lord?
target: What follows, then, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you refuse to allow me to do so, your city’s charter and its freedom are endangered.
target: If you deny it, let the danger light Upon your charter and your city’s freedom.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll bet anything you like that nothing will happen, once again.
target: I dare lay any money ’twill be nothing yet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is it lost?
target: Is ’t lost?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Rest easy in the meantime.
target: Good repose the while!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Not bad; you might accomplish something.
target: You might do much.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m a surgeon to old shoes.
target: I meddle with no tradesman’s matters nor women’s matters, but withal I am indeed, sir, a surgeon to old shoes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh God, Benedick will plague him like a disease!
target: O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did he marry me just to starve me?
target: What, did he marry me to famish me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When was the last time you saw her sleepwalking?
target: When was it she last walked?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you pay too much attention to him you’ll make him angry, and that will make his convulsions go on longer.
target: If much you note him, You shall offend him and extend his passion.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There isn’t much time.
target: Time calls upon ’s.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have forgotten your name, but you were well cast in the role and played it convincingly.
target: I have forgot your name, but sure that part Was aptly fitted and naturally performed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, and a brave one, who dares to look at something that would frighten the devil.
target: Ay, and a bold one, that dare look on that Which might appall the devil.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t know you.
target: I know you not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me.
target: Therefore speak.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here’s the indictment of the good Lord Hastings, which has been written out in a clear hand, like any legal document, so it can be read aloud in public outside St. Paul’s Cathedral.
target: This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings, Which in a set hand fairly is engrossed, That it may be today read o'er in Paul’s.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As for myself, it was Greek to me.
target: But, for mine own part, it was Greek to me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, be a man.
target: Come, be a man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But let me try my luck on the boxes.
target: But let me to my fortune and the caskets.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can get the better of religion and a few flimsy vows between a misguided barbarian and a depraved Venetian girl.
target: If sanctimony and a frail vow betwixt an erring barbarian and supersubtle Venetian be not too hard for my wits and all the tribe of hell, thou shalt enjoy her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My Lord of Cambridge and my good Lord of Masham and you, my noble knight, what do you think?
target: My Lord of Cambridge, and my kind Lord of Masham, And you, my gentle knight, give me your thoughts.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, my lord.
target: No, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, I wouldn’t say I was your friend, but I’ve praised you when you deserved ten times more praise than I gave.
target: Sir, I never loved you much, but I ha’ praised ye When you have well deserved ten times as much As I have said you did.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will choose this one and try my chances.
target: Here do I choose, and thrive I as I may!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re forgetting yourself when you back me into a corner.
target: You forget yourself To hedge me in.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ll grant me, you hedgehog?
target: Dost grant me, hedgehog?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, good sir?
target: Why, good sir?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well then, the beef without the mustard.
target: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I wish I was the glove on that hand so that I could touch that cheek.
target: Oh, that I were a glove upon that hand That I might touch that cheek!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I was the only one who refused to give back what I stole.
target: Only myself stood out; For which, if I be lapsèd in this place, I shall pay dear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So beware of my contempt, and keep your promise.
target: Therefore beware my censure, and keep your promise.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, Antony, Antony, Antony!
target: O Antony, Antony, Antony!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Happy that we’re not too happy, lucky in being not too lucky.
target: Happy, in that we are not overhappy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s drink to our general!
target: To the health of our general!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Appear before me now quickly— No talking.
target: Appear and pertly!— No tongue.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My dear madam, why are you in mourning?
target: Good madonna, why mournest thou?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s her skin like?
target: What complexion is she of?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ah-ha!
target: Aha!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, make them joyful!
target: O, make them joyful.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Even good men have bad luck.
target: A good man’s fortune may grow out at heels.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In his greatest need, even they will desert him.
target: Which in his dearest need will fly from him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Suffolk died first, and York, cut to pieces, came to him where he lay in his blood and took him by the face, kissing his gashes.
target: Suffolk first died, and York, all haggled over, Comes to him where in gore he lay insteeped And takes him by the beard, kisses the gashes That bloodily did yawn upon his face.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, what better favor can I do for you than to kill the man who killed you with the same hand that made you die young.
target: O, what more favor can I do to thee, Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain To sunder his that was thine enemy?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll poison you, or beat you with a club, or stab you with a sword.
target: I will deal in poison with thee, or in bastinado, or in steel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Madam, tell me quickly, what day is that?
target: Madam, in happy time, what day is that?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I would like to prove to you that I am.
target: I would fain prove so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tonight in Harfleur we will be your guest; tomorrow we’ll march on.
target: Tonight in Harfleur will we be your guest; Tomorrow for the march are we addressed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m very sorry I was so hard on him.
target: I repent me much That so I harried him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I pray that God ends his life before I die, so I can say, “The dog is dead!”
target: Cancel his bond of life, dear God I pray, That I may live to say, “The dog is dead.”

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Until recently, I was as unimportant to his affairs as the morning dew is to the wide ocean.
target: I was of late as petty to his ends As is the morn-dew on the myrtle leaf To his grand sea.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Curse the day this happened, but it did.
target: Alas the day, it did.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Has my master returned yet?
target: I pray you, is my master yet returned?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Four legs and two voices—a very special monster.
target: Four legs and two voices—a most delicate monster.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I had known this young man was his son, I would have tried harder to convince him not to fight.
target: Had I before known this young man his son, I should have given him tears unto entreaties Ere he should thus have ventured.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If it’s for me, don’t keep it from me.
target: If it be mine, Keep it not from me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s lying through his teeth!
target: He lies to th' heart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’ll recover his sanity there.
target: Tis for the dead, not for the quick.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I gave him no order.
target: I gave him no order.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, the he that will marry this woman.
target: He, sir, that must marry this woman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then teach your cousin to also be willing to close her eyes, my lord.
target: Then, good my lord, teach your cousin to consent winking.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you behave yourself and join us in our circle dance and moonlight celebrations, then you can come with us.
target: If you will patiently dance in our round And see our moonlight revels, go with us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And our drunkenness does detract from our achievements, as great as they are, and lessens our reputations.
target: And indeed it takes From our achievements, though performed at height, The pith and marrow of our attribute.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His eyes started glazing over around eight in the morning.
target: His eyes were set at eight i' the morning.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let lightning spit fire!
target: Spit, fire!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You wouldn’t know enough to be afraid of traps.
target: Thou ’dst never fear the net nor lime, The pitfall nor the gin.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You slander her, you devil.
target: Thou dost belie her, and thou art a devil.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Follow me.
target: Follow me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, will you leave me alone in the dark?
target: O, wilt thou darkling leave me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me, good grandmother, is our father dead?
target: Good grandam, tell us, is our father dead?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What kind of loyalty is this?
target: What a foolish duty call you this?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As I neglected practical matters, being totally dedicated to solitude and to improving my mind with subjects more valuable than most people imagine, I was so shut away from the world that I unwittingly stirred up evil wishes in my disloyal brother.
target: I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated To closeness and the bettering of my mind With that which, but by being so retired, O'erprized all popular rate, in my false brother Awaked an evil nature.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We need a more appropriate place to discuss Cordelia and her father.
target: The question of Cordelia and her father Requires a fitter place.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She says that you should come to her.
target: She bids you come to her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go ahead, Moon.
target: Proceed, Moon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, Cassius, I’ll run far from this country to where no Romans can find me.
target: O Cassius, Far from this country Pindarus shall run, Where never Roman shall take note of him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If we meet again, then we’ll smile indeed.
target: If we do meet again, we’ll smile indeed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord, how are you feeling?
target: How fares my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, pilgrim—they have lips that they’re supposed to pray with.
target: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Twelve years ago, Miranda, twelve years ago your father was the Duke of Milan, a powerful prince.
target: Twelve year since, Miranda, twelve year since, Thy father was the Duke of Milan and A prince of power.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What features?
target: What features?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s fair game to mark a coward.
target: Tis sport to maul a runner.

target: But yet I cannot love him; He might have took his answer long ago.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who are you talking about?
target: What should he be?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ve said it well.
target: Fairly spoke.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: By our Lady, I think that’s true.
target: By 'r lady, I think it be so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Even if I had sworn never to marry, I wouldn’t trust myself to keep that promise if Hero would marry me.
target: I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can any of your neighbors tell, Kate?
target: Can any of your neighbors tell, Kate?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So could I.
target: So could I too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Pompey has a strong navy.
target: Pompey is strong at sea, And it appears he is beloved of those That only have feared Caesar.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s not the right time to play.
target: Tis no time to play now.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think a few members of the court should fetch the young prince from Wales and bring him to London to be crowned our king.
target: Meseemeth good that with some little train Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fet Hither to London, to be crowned our king.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take  Beatrice, have you come because I called for you?
target: Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I called thee?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But  Hello, my lord, how have you been doing lately?
target: Good my lord, How does your honor for this many a day?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You too, Fabian.
target: Come hither, Fabian.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What does Caesar want?
target: Caesar’s will?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve made a risky investment.
target: Twill bring you gain or perish on the seas.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The alcohol that got the servants drunk has made me bold.
target: That which hath made them drunk hath made me bold.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have important business that requires me to remain in disguise a while longer.
target: Some dear cause Will in concealment wrap me up awhile.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Anything that’s mended is only patched up.
target: Anything that’s mended is but patched.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s true, that wasn’t such a nice thing to do.
target: Faith, that was not so well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lorenzo, please take charge of the management of my house until my husband comes back.
target: Lorenzo, I commit into your hands The husbandry and manage of my house Until my lord’s return.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Doors, open up for whoever is knocking!
target: Open, locks, Whoever knocks.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s stay and watch.
target: Let us now stay and see it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Was it mine?
target: Was that mine?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Just ignore him.
target: Take no note of him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh heaven, oh earth, witness what I’m about to say, and reward me if I tell the truth!
target: O heaven, O earth, bear witness to this sound And crown what I profess with kind event

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, that’s the one.
target: That.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wish me luck.
target: Hie to high fortune!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!
target: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And when I told you he was involved the whole time I was trying to get Desdemona, you were like, “Oh, really?” And then you frowned and wrinkled up your forehead as if you were imagining something horrible.
target: And when I told thee he was of my counsel Of my whole course of wooing, thou cried’st “Indeed?” And didst contract and purse thy brow together As if thou then hadst shut up in thy brain Some horrible conceit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll eat at her place.
target: There will we dine.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you wise?
target: Art thou wise?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Portia!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Call him.
target: Call him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s too bad.
target: Tis pity of him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And isn’t your husband an honorable man?
target: Is not your lord honorable without marriage?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I break the door down, slave, you’ll be sorry for this.
target: You’ll cry for this, minion, if I beat the door down.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why do you ask?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re in the charge of an honorable man.

target: There’s part of a power already footed.

target: Heart, once be stronger than thy continent.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lord Hastings, you and he are close.

target: Then be ’t so, my good lord.— How does the king?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What quality is that, my lord?
target: It well appears.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me see.
target: Let me see.

target: I go.

target: O thou dull Moor!

target: My resolution’s placed, and I have nothing Of woman in me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I see.

target: What night-rule now about this haunted grove?

target: And what have I to give you back whose worth May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, young man, don’t make me angry.
target: I beseech thee, youth, Put not another sin upon my head By urging me to fury.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, they’re spirits that I’ve called out of their prisons to perform my whims.
target: Spirits, which by mine art I have from their confines called to enact My present fancies.

target: I thank you; and be blessed for your good comfort.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I might come back soon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As long as it’s honorable, you can be sure that I’ll let you use all my money and do everything I can to help you.
target: And if it stand, as you yourself still do, Within the eye of honor, be assured My purse, my person, my extremest means Lie all unlocked to your occasions.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Isn’t my vest just as clean and fresh as the day I put it on?
target: Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it?

target: Why, do not your courtier’s hands sweat?

target: Was ever man so 'rayed?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here.
target: Ready.

target: Where is our usual manager of mirth?

target: You are there followed by a faithful shepherd.

target: By my troth, ’s not so good, and I warrant your cousin will say so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m old and foolish.
target: I am old and foolish.

target: None that I know will be; much that I fear may chance.

target: You shall not gauge me By what we do tonight.

target: I take this offer then: pay the bond thrice And let the Christian go.

target: Pray you, tread softly, that the blind mole may not hear a foot fall.

target: Do we but find the tyrant’s power tonight, Let us be beaten if we cannot fight.

target: He is not here, so please your lordship, that should sing it.

target: Hang not on my garments.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes.

target: O, my old master.—Who hath bound him here?

target: I’ll make her come, I warrant you, presently.

target: Wilt thou at Ninny’s tomb meet me straightway?

target: Judge me the world if ’tis not gross in sense That thou hast practiced on her with foul charms, Abused her delicate youth with drugs or minerals That weakens motion.

target: Things growing are not ripe until their season.

target: You have obtained it.

target: Make your vaunting true, And it shall please me well.

target: How came her eyes so bright?

target: Were ’t twenty of the greatest tributaries That do acknowledge Caesar, should I find them So saucy with the hand of she here—what’s her name Since she was Cleopatra?

target: Now am I Dromio, and his man, unbound.

target: I was killed i' th' Capitol.

target: Sister, it is not a little I have to say of what most nearly appertains to us both.

target: Romeo must not live.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Not even trivial things were left out.
target: Tis exactly valued, Not petty things admitted.

target: I’ll prove mine honor and mine honesty Against thee presently if thou dar’st stand.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, lead on.
target: Why then, lead on.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lord, Lord, when she was a little baby—Oh, there is one nobleman in the city, a guy named Paris, who would be happy to claim her as his own.
target: when ’twas a little prating thing.—Oh, there is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain lay knife aboard, but she, good soul, had as lief see a toad, a very toad, as see him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish the night were here already!
target: Would the night were come!

target: Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum, Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Everything’s ready.
target: All ready.

target: For my part, I had rather bear with you than bear you.

target: I know him; he wears a lock.

target: To eat us hungerly, and when they are full, They belch us.

target: Go back again and be new beaten home?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How many wonderful creatures there are here!
target: How many goodly creatures are there here!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell him to gather together the greatest army he can muster in a hurry and meet me right away at Salisbury.
target: Bid him levy straight The greatest strength and power that he can make And meet me suddenly at Salisbury.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Reborn.
target: Thou art translated.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Everything’s fine, now, sweetheart.
target: All’s well, sweeting, Come away to bed.— Myself will be your surgeon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Her
target: I warrant her rags and the

target: Fetch forth the stocks!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So now everyone will point at me and say, “Look, there goes the wife of that comedian Petruchio—if he could be bothered to marry the pathetic thing!”
target: Now must the world point at poor Katherine And say, “Lo, there is mad Petruchio’s wife, If it would please him come and marry her!”   Upon my life, Petruchio means but well, Whatever fortune stays him from his word: Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise; Though he be merry, yet withal he’s honest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, heaven help us!
target: Oh, heaven forgive us!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re not supposed to get old until you’re wise.
target: Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst been wise.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And what would you give me for the handkerchief?
target: What will you give me now For the same handkerchief?

target: There’s no offense, my lord.

target: Hush, Thou think’st there is no more such shapes as he, Having seen but him and Caliban.

target: Not Hermia but Helena I love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You didn’t offend us, you offended the king.
target: Offended us you have not, but the king.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If the world were mine, I’d give it all up—everything except Demetrius—to be you.
target: Were the world mine, Demetrius being bated, The rest I’d give to be to you translated.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What, you mean kid actors?
target: What, are they children?

target: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Won’t the ladies be scared of the lion?
target: Will not the ladies be afeard of the lion?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m at your service until death.
target: Yours in the ranks of death.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get out of here, my friend.

target: Why are you drawn?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s busy, can’t you hear him giving orders?
target: Do you not hear him?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s a stupid thing to say.
target: A foolish thought, to say a sorry sight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So how short am I, you painted barber pole?
target: How low am I, thou painted maypole?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, Iras, what do you think?

target: This sight would make him do a desperate turn, Yea, curse his better angel from his side And fall to reprobation.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: After midnight, for two nights running, these two guards, Marcellus and Barnardo, saw a figure that looked very much like your father, in full armor from head to toe.
target: Two nights together had these gentlemen, Marcellus and Barnardo, on their watch, In the dead waste and middle of the night, Been thus encountered: a figure like your father, Armed at point exactly, cap-à-pie, Appears before them and with solemn march Goes slow and stately by them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: At least I don’t have a horse for my mistress—or a saying so beside the point.
target: Yet do I not use my horse for my mistress, or any such proverb so little kin to the purpose.

target: The gray-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night, Checkering the eastern clouds with streaks of light, And fleckled darkness like a drunkard reels From forth day’s path and Titan’s fiery wheels.
