target: If every one knows us, and we know none, 'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack, and be gone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But you still wish the gods had made me poetical?
target: Do you wish then that the gods had made me poetical?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t be upset.
target: Sir, grieve not you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell them to capture me, then sell my bones.
target: Bid them achieve me and then sell my bones.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There!… And over there!… And over there!
target: There could I have him now—and there—and there again—and there.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go get Aliena ready—because, look, here comes my Rosalind.
target: Go you and prepare Aliena, for look you, here comes my Rosalind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Prove you are worthy of your birth, which I do not doubt for a moment.
target: Let us swear That you are worth your breeding, which I doubt not,

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So, goodbye.
target: So, adieu.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, if only we had with us here ten thousand of those men back home in England who aren’t working today.
target: Oh, that we now had here But one ten thousand of those men in England That do no work today.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Just tell me what you want me to do, and however hard it is, you’ll see that I’m eager to do it.
target: Teach it but how, And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn Any hard lesson that may do thee good.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where’s the necklace?
target: Come, where’s the chain?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The world doesn’t make laws to make you rich.
target: The world affords no law to make thee rich.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The man that once sold the skin of a lion while the beast still lived died hunting him.
target: The man that once did sell the lion’s skin While the beast lived was killed with hunting him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The more I hate him, the more he follows me around.
target: The more I hate, the more he follows me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Seyton!
target: Seyton!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And like I am for Rosalind.
target: And I for Rosalind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Greed has been the downfall of many kings.
target: This avarice Sticks deeper, grows with more pernicious root Than summer-seeming lust, and it hath been The sword of our slain kings.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come, mistress Kate, I’ll join you.
target: Come, mistress Kate, I’ll bear you company.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have it ready.
target: I have them ready.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And, Kate, when France is mine and I am yours, then France is yours and you are mine.
target: And, Kate, when France is mine and I am yours, then yours is France and you are mine.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s not my fault he acts like that, Helena.
target: His folly, Helena, is no fault of mine.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Arms, make your last embrace!
target: Arms, take your last embrace.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me be your servant.
target: Let me be your servant.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then I will swear to Kate and you to me, and may our oaths be faithfully kept and prove fortunate.
target: Then shall I swear to Kate, and you to me, And may our oaths well kept and prosp'rous be.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sorry, sir?
target: Sir?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Not one drop sooner.
target: Not a drop before.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So don’t advise me.
target: Therefore give me no counsel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Swear by her foot, so she can stamp out the oath.
target: Swear by her foot, that she may tread out the oath.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll be right next to you.
target: I’ll be at thy elbow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve botched the job, friends.
target: I have done my work ill, friends.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bring him here dead or alive within the next year, or get out off my land.
target: Bring him, dead or living, Within this twelvemonth or turn thou no more To seek a living in our territory.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll give you cramps for saying that—horrible pains in your sides that will keep you from breathing.
target: For this, be sure, tonight thou shalt have cramps, Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, not at all— All right, all right.
target: Nay, then— Well, well, th' event.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your words are idiotic.
target: The text is foolish.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you biting your thumb at us?
target: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If my doing what you told me to makes you happy, then be happy, because I did it.
target: If to have done the thing you gave in charge Beget your happiness, be happy then, For it is done.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look out, here she comes.
target: Look, where she comes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, write down “Borachio.”—And yours?
target: Pray, write down, “Borachio.”—Yours, sirrah?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This box was tested in the fire seven times.
target: The fire seven times tried this, Seven times tried that judgment is, That did never choose amiss.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Awaken the memory of those valiant ancestors and with your own powerful arm make their deeds live again.
target: Awake remembrance of these valiant dead And with your puissant arm renew their feats.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Or maybe, to make it even more lovely, I’ll sing it when the heroine dies.
target: Peradventure, to make it the more gracious, I shall sing it at her death.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll tell you, good Brutus.
target: Therefore, good Brutus, be prepared to hear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It was just moments ago.
target: I have not breathed almost since I did see it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why do you keep repeating that, woman?
target: What needs this iterance, woman?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is that the law?
target: Is that the law?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But where is he?
target: Where is he gone?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t want to have anything to do with you anymore.
target: I’ll no more of you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And how do you like Lord Bassanio’s wife?
target: How dost thou like the Lord Bassanio’s wife?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, my lord, you once said that lazy weeds grow fast.
target: O, my lord, You said that idle weeds are fast in growth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stay!
target: Stay!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re a pustule, a sore, a tumor digesting my bloodline.
target: Thou art a boil, A plague-sore or embossèd carbuncle In my corrupted blood.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That, stirred up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Morton, he’s coming to England to claim the crown.
target: Stirred up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Morton, He makes for England, here to claim the crown.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who do you think you are coming in here armed?
target: And what art thou that dar’st Appear thus to us?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Referee!
target: Judgment?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye.
target: Fare you well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The old king was so overjoyed by this promise that he gave young Fortinbras an annual income of three thousand  I like this news, and when I have time I’ll read this and think about how to reply.
target: Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee And his commission to employ those soldiers, So levied as before, against the Polack, With an entreaty, herein further shown, That it might please you to give quiet pass Through your dominions for this enterprise, On such regards of safety and allowance As therein are set down.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What he just said to me—it’s alright.
target: I’ll assure you, he uttered as prave words at the pridge as you shall see in a summer’s day.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t speak of this again.
target: Speak this no more.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is the day I’m going to get what I wished for when I wished that the person I most trusted would betray me.
target: This is the day wherein I wished to fall By the false faith of him who most I trusted.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m learning every hour how to be subservient.
target: I hourly learn A doctrine of obedience, and would gladly Look him i’ th’ face.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Fill my cup, Lucius, until the wine overflows it.
target: Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It would be a pretty stingy love if it could be counted and calculated.
target: There’s beggary in the love that can be reckoned.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s carry him to the barracks.
target: Let us bear him  To th’ court of guard.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve heard her say that.
target: I have heard her swear ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, I want it, and I’ll get it.
target: Nay, and I will.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Just as if they were perfectly loyal and faithful.
target: How smooth and even they do bear themselves, As if allegiance in their bosoms sat Crownèd with faith and constant loyalty.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Indeed I do, sir, and I’ve come to let you in on a certain problem.
target: Marry, do I, sir, and I came to acquaint you with a matter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Great Mark Antony is a widower now.
target: Great Mark Antony Is now a widower.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Baptista is a noble gentleman—one to whom my father is not completely unknown—and lovely as his daughter is, she is entitled to any number of suitors—myself among them.
target: Baptista is a noble gentleman, To whom my father is not all unknown, And were his daughter fairer than she is, She may more suitors have, and me for one.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Isn’t that what they said?
target: And thane of Cawdor too: went it not so?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tear him to pieces.
target: Tear him to pieces.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I beg the court to deliver the verdict.
target: Most heartily I do beseech the court To give the judgment.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The kind that tells you that the Moor is having sex with your daughter right now.
target: I am one, sir, that comes to tell you your daughter and the Moor are now making the beast with two backs.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So can I.
target: So can I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll bring you there.
target: I will bring you thither.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Such an expression of despair would only prove that I was guilty.
target: By such despair I should accuse myself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let the Egyptians and Phoenicians go swimming.
target: Let th’ Egyptians And the Phoenicians go a-ducking.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How  What, are you jealous, Oberon?—Fairies, let’s get out of here.
target: What, jealous Oberon?—Fairies, skip hence.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, who’s so stupid that he can’t see through this fraud?
target: Who is so gross That cannot see this palpable device?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord, my life is as important to me as yours is to you, and it was never as precious to me as it is now.
target: My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours, And never in my days, I do protest, Was it so precious to me as ’tis now.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is it four o'clock?
target: Is it four o'clock?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can’t trust all the rumors.
target: Report is changeable.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve come to take you to the senate house.
target: I come to fetch you to the senate house.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish I was your bird.
target: I would I were thy bird.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let them last forever.
target: Still live they, and forever let them last.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shall we get started?
target: Come, shall we about it?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Amen, amen.
target: Amen, amen.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have you seen him today?
target: Saw you him today?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you think of this fool, Malvolio?
target: What think you of this fool, Malvolio?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: With all my heart, I’ll join you.
target: With all my heart I’ll gossip at this feast.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is just another one of the hallucinations you always get when you’re afraid.
target: This is the very painting of your fear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your son will have my consent to marry my daughter.
target: Your son shall have my daughter with consent.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I’d rather have met my fiercest enemy in heaven, Horatio, than have lived through that terrible day!
target: Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven Or ever I had seen that day, Horatio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, that’s not it, trust me.
target: Believe me, no.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My generosity to you is as limitless as the sea, and my love is as deep.
target: My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If there are any, speak, for it is he whom I’ve offended.
target: If any, speak—for him have I offended.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I give you a sister whom I love more than a brother ever loved any sister.
target: A sister I bequeath you whom no brother Did ever love so dearly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye, my sweet lord.—Goodbye, my sister.
target: Farewell, sweet lord, and sister.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I won’t be kind to you.
target: I love thee not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Therefore, my old age is like a blustery winter: cold, but kindly.
target: Therefore my age is as a lusty winter, Frosty but kindly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I swear he’s the better dog.
target: Trust me, I take him for the better dog.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well sir, they’ve lied; moreover, they have said things that were not true; secondarily, they are slanderers; sixth and lastly, they have falsely accused a lady; thirdly, they have confirmed things that did not in fact happen; and, in conclusion, they are lying scoundrels.
target: Marry, sir, they have committed false report; moreover, they have spoken untruths; secondarily, they are slanders; sixth and lastly, they have belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified unjust things; and, to conclude, they are lying knaves.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The watchdogs bark.
target: The watchdogs bark.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When you weren’t at home, the Senate sent out three different search parties to find you.
target: When being not at your lodging to be found The Senate hath sent about three several guests To search you out.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: May heaven bless you.
target: The bounty and the benison of heaven To boot and boot.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And if it doesn’t go well, then you can keep her hidden in a nunnery, the best place for someone with her kind of dirtied reputation—away from the public’s eyes, tongues, mind, and insults.
target: And if it sort not well, you may conceal her, As best befits her wounded reputation, In some reclusive and religious life, Out of all eyes, tongues, minds, and injuries.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, then, help me.
target: Well then, sustain me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Make yourself comfortable.
target: Seek thine own ease.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me your blessing.
target: Give me your blessing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish the lightning had burned up all those logs that you’ve been ordered to stack!
target: I would the lightning had Burnt up those logs that you are enjoined to pile!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Isn’t it strange, Canidius, that he could cross the Ionian Sea so quickly from Tarentum and Brundusium and take Toryne?—Have you heard about this, sweet?
target: Is it not strange, Canidius, That from Tarentum and Brundusium He could so quickly cut the Ionian sea And take in Toryne?—You have heard on ’t, sweet?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t dare, sir.
target: I dare not, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thank you.
target: I know he loves me well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wait, good Beatrice.
target: Tarry, good Beatrice.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, please, save it for dinner conversation.
target: No, pray thee, let it serve for table talk.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ill will never prompted anything well said.
target: Ill will never said well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You call this sneering?
target: Call you this railing?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You won’t get any bad cooks from me.
target: You shall have none ill, sir, for I’ll try if they can lick their fingers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Young man, excuse me, how do I get to the Jew’s?
target: Master young gentleman, I pray you, which is the way to Master Jew’s?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It wasn’t the journey itself, uncle, but the troubles we encountered that made it wearisome and dull.
target: No, uncle, but our crosses on the way Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, not me, sir.
target: Not I, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But did I fall or not?
target: But have I fall'n, or no?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s probably some noble gentleman stopping off in mid-journey, thinking to spend the night here.
target: Belike some noble gentleman that means, Traveling some journey, to repose him here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wait until I read the letter.
target: Stay till I have read the letter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Make him think you’re Sir Topas the priest.
target: Make him believe thou art Sir Topas the curate.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’d better shut up!
target: Peace, you were best.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Until then, my noble friend, think about this: I’d rather be a poor villager than call myself a citizen of Rome under the hard conditions that this time is likely to put us through.
target: Till then, my noble friend, chew upon this: Brutus had rather be a villager Than to repute himself a son of Rome Under these hard conditions as this time Is like to lay upon us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll do whatever the king wants.
target: I am constant to my purpose.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Killing men in the dark?
target: Kill men i' th' dark!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For God’s sake, my lord, let’s be sure to be part of the group that meets the prince.
target: My lord, whoever journeys to the prince, For God’s sake let not us two at home.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And how would we go about doing that?
target: How now shall this be compassed?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Or you can pretend to settle your differences until this matter with Pompey is finished.
target: Or, if you borrow one another’s love for the instant, you may, when you hear no more words of Pompey, return it again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, she tears that letter into a thousand small pieces and berates herself for being so forward as to write a letter to a man she knows would mock her.
target: O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, railed at herself that she should be so immodest to write to one that she knew would flout her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My brother is imprisoned because of you, I am disgraced, and the nobility are held in contempt while those who two days ago weren’t worth a dime have suddenly been promoted.
target: Our brother is imprisoned by your means, Myself disgraced, and the nobility Held in contempt, while great promotions Are daily given to ennoble those That scarce some two days since were worth a noble.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is a stranger business than men have ever set foot in before, and it’s not natural either.
target: This is as strange a maze as e'er men trod, And there is in this business more than nature Was ever conduct of.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s a very sad day.
target: Most heavy day!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can only say this about her: if she looked different than she does, she would be ugly, and since she can’t be anything but herself, I don’t like her.
target: Only this commendation I can afford her, that were she other than she is, she were unhandsome, and being no other but as she is, I do not like her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell us about this wrestling.
target: You tell us the manner of the wrestling.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Or walk either.
target: Nor go neither.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Gertrude, he says he’s found out the reason for your son’s insanity.
target: He tells me, my dear Gertrude, he hath found The head and source of all your son’s distemper.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here comes the messenger with your niece.
target: Here he comes with your niece.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I just meant that you should use some holy thistle.
target: I meant plain holy thistle.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But his navy rules the sea.
target: But by sea he is an absolute master.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you know Captain Gower?
target: Know’st thou Gower?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hurry now, get the job done.
target: Go, go, dispatch.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, do you know who I am?
target: Sir, do you know me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, you’re just going to talk about banishment again.
target: Oh, thou wilt speak again of banishment.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And as for what I promised to you, I’m as good as my word.
target: And for that I promised you, I’ll be as good as my word.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, my companions and brothers in exile, hasn’t experience made this simple life sweeter than a life of glittery pomp and circumstance?
target: Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile, Hath not old custom made this life more sweet Than that of painted pomp?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t be afraid, even though you see me with a weapon.
target: Be not afraid, though you do see me weaponed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The Count sent me an excellent pair of perfumed gloves.
target: These gloves the Count sent me, they are an excellent perfume.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s late.
target: His hour is almost past.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish she were in heaven so she could appeal to some power to make this dog Jew change his mind.
target: I would she were in heaven, so she could Entreat some power to change this currish Jew.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh love!
target: O love!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s sleeping in the second chamber?
target: Who lies i' th' second chamber?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please call him and tell him to come back here.
target: I prithee, call him back.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So how’s my nephew Hamlet doing?
target: How fares our cousin Hamlet?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t you have any manners, you savage?
target: You beastly knave, know you no reverence?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If she punishes you, master, she’s sure to punish me.
target: If you went in pain, master, this knave would go sore.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I won’t bother with it.
target: I’ll not meddle with it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Benedick’s heart is like a bell, with his tongue as the clapper: everything his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.
target: He hath a heart as sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I see you like to make big offers, sir.
target: I see, sir, you are liberal in offers.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come with me.
target: Come.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, most bloody sight!
target: O most bloody sight!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Be quick for a while and let the one who lives the longest take everything.
target: Be brisk 0awhile, and the longer liver take all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come this way, my lord.
target: This way, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: From the Earth’s womb, many different sorts of plants and animals come forth, and the Earth provides her children with many excellent forms of nourishment.
target: And from her womb children of divers kind We sucking on her natural bosom find, Many for many virtues excellent, None but for some and yet all different.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d rather be a heretic than a schemer with fancy plots.
target: I had as lief be a Brownist as a politician.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you weren’t a man, then what kind of animal were you when you first told me you wanted to do this?
target: What beast was ’t, then, That made you break this enterprise to me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A soothsayer tells you to beware of March 15th.
target: A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Be at ease.
target: You see how easily she may be surprised.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Maybe you will find a husband without a beard.
target: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stay calm.
target: Be patient.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Okay, to the point.
target: Therefore no more but to the matter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go back, slave, or I’ll knock you one across the head.
target: Back, slave, or I will break thy pate across.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Open your gates.
target: Open your gates.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s true.
target: Tis true.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s yours.—Come, Ariel!
target: She is thine own.— What, Ariel!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Damn those men shouting down there!
target: A plague upon this howling!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Michael Cassio, lieutenant of the Moor Othello, has arrived on shore.
target: Michael Cassio, Lieutenant to the warlike Moor Othello, Is come on shore.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The moon sets at twelve, right?
target: And she goes down at twelve.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But let’s follow it, and then do our dirty work afterward.
target: Let’s follow it, and after do our work.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here.
target: Ready.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will.
target: I will, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, no.
target: O, no!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But still, she’s going to kill you for being gone so long.
target: Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your other daughter Regan will treat you kindly, you’ll see.
target: Shalt see thy other daughter will use thee kindly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Those who have done this deed are honorable.
target: They that have done this deed are honorable.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will, my lady, but a sane person reading this would make it sound crazy.
target: But to read his right wits is to read thus.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But really, are you the one who’s been hanging on the trees those poems that speak so admiringly of Rosalind?
target: But, in good sooth, are you he that hangs the verses on the trees wherein Rosalind is so admired?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, you’re right, her name is Margery.
target: Her name is Margery, indeed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tomorrow is Wednesday.
target: Wednesday is tomorrow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, one of you go ask that man over there if we can buy some food off him.
target: I pray you, one of you question yond man, if he for gold will give us any food.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ugh!
target: Doth his Majesty Incline to it or no?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I swear by the mass, before I close my eyes to go to sleep, I’ll put in some good fighting, or I’ll lie in the ground dead.
target: By the mess, ere theise eyes of mine take themselves to slomber, ay’ll de gud service, or I’ll lig i' th' grund for it, ay, or go to death.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How will that kill this marriage?
target: What life is in that to be the death of this marriage?

target: Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress.

target: I must to the barber’s, monsieur, for methinks I am marvelous hairy about the face.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He will be fooled into thinking he is greater than fate, he will mock death, and he will think he is above wisdom, grace, and fear.
target: He shall spurn fate, scorn death, and bear His hopes 'bove wisdom, grace, and fear.

target: God grant we never may have need of you.

target: If you knew my business, You would entreat me rather go than stay.

target: Marry, now I let go your hand, I am barren.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, dear child?

target: The wall, methinks, being sensible, should curse again.

target: By this kind of chase I should hate him, for my father hated his father dearly.

target: What, in our house?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If he’s in a good mood I’ll mention you again, and do everything I can.
target: If I do find him fit, I’ll move your suit And seek to effect it to my uttermost.

target: The selfsame name, but one of better nature.

target: He did bewray his practice, and received This hurt you see striving to apprehend him.

target: Death is my heir.

target: What’s that to thee?

target: Where be thy brothers?

target: Good shepherd, tell this youth what ’tis to love.

target: No, indeed, my lord.

target: Know’st thou his mind?

target: Stand fast, Titinius.

target: The duke and senators of Venice greet you.

target: Lead, monster; we’ll follow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A friend.
target: A friend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now we can shout, “Congratulations, congratulations, my lord and lady!” My Lord Bassanio, and my dear lady, I wish you all the joy I can wish for.
target: My lord and lady, it is now our time, That have stood by and seen our wishes prosper, To cry, “Good joy, good joy, my lord and lady!” My Lord Bassanio and my gentle lady, I wish you all the joy that you can wish, For I am sure you can wish none from me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m sending you to England on diplomatic business, and Hamlet will go with you.
target: I your commission will forthwith dispatch, And he to England shall along with you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You will also confess, I’m sure, that you love me.
target: So will ye, I am sure, that you love me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: which any peace-lover can do.
target: Wherein the toged consuls can propose As masterly as he.

target: Cheerly, boys.

target: Which she shall purchase with still-lasting war.

target: Good night.

target: Is the king dead, the empire unpossessed?

target: There are no tongues else for ’s turn.

target: Morton is fled to Richmond, And Buckingham, backed with the hardy Welshmen, Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.

target: Edmund, seek him out, wind me into him, I pray you.

target: My lord is dead.

target: Your eyes are lodestars, and your tongue’s sweet air More tunable than lark to shepherd’s ear When wheat is green, when hawthorn buds appear.

target: A sailor’s wife had chestnuts in her lap, And munched, and munched, and munched.

target: Oh, you are men of stones.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Monday, my lord.
target: Monday, my lord.

target: Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord.

target: Let me shun that.

target: Note this before my notes: There’s not a note of mine that’s worth the noting.

target: And there the snake throws her enameled skin, Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in.

target: Tis twenty year till then.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And I came with him.
target: And I with him.

target: I owe you much, and, like a willful youth, That which I owe is lost.

target: No, it is Casca, one incorporate To our attempts.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But you’re too good a friend for me to wish her on you.
target: But thou'rt too much my friend, And I’ll not wish thee to her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m afraid to think how I’ll be criticized for letting my natural affection for my father give way to my loyalty to you.
target: How, my lord, I may be censured, that nature thus gives way to loyalty, something fears me to think of.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What news?
target: What news?

target: Hope I may choose, sir.

target: Answer to that.

target: The man should be put into the lanthorn.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s calling out my name as if I were a bullet murdering her, just like I murdered her relative.
target: As if that name, Shot from the deadly level of a gun, Did murder her, as that name’s cursed hand Murdered her kinsman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll put a leash on this danger that’s now running wild.
target: For we will fetters put upon this fear, Which now goes too free-footed.

target: This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince’s brother, was a villain.

target: And will you, being a man of your breeding, be married under a bush like a beggar?

target: Then he’s a rogue, and a passy-measures pavin.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But no matter—I’ll get back at him soon enough.
target: But that’s all one: omittance is no quittance.

target: Here’s a change indeed!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Before I learn how to love, I’ll learn how to follow orders.
target: Ere I learn love, I’ll practice to obey.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And by all means see if you can get the young man to answer it.
target: And by all means stir on the youth to an answer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s like this: as long as a person tells me the truth, even though it means my death, I will listen as though he praised me.
target: Tis thus: Who tells me true, though in his tale lie death, I hear him as he flattered.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is that possible?
target: Is ’t possible?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, I believe this piece of trash, Bianca, has something to do with all this trouble.—Hang in there, Cassio.—Come here, bring the light.
target: Gentlemen all, I do suspect this trash To be a party in this injury.— Patience awhile, good Cassio.—Come, come, Lend me a light.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But you’re no such man.
target: But you are no such man.

target: If you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap.—Cheerly, good hearts!—Out of our way, I say.

target: As I stood here below, methought his eyes Were two full moons.

target: Love’s not love When it is mingled with regards that stands Aloof from th' entire point.

target: You come to me and you say, “Shylock, we would have moneys.” You say so!— You, that did void your rheum upon my beard And foot me as you spurn a stranger cur Over your threshold!

target: Oh, he’s a lovely gentleman.

target: Tis so strange That, though the truth of it stands off as gross As black and white, my eye will scarcely see it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your authorization is ready.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you say one more word, I’ll punish you, maybe even hate you.

target: Though you have put me into darkness and given your drunken cousin rule over me, yet have I the benefit of my senses as well as your Ladyship.

target: Thy bed, lust-stained, shall with lust’s blood be spotted.

target: There!

target: Well, all is one.

target: Himself.

target: There I have another bad match!—a bankrupt, a prodigal who dare scarce show his head on the Rialto, a beggar that was used to come so smug upon the mart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now I’m scared again.
target: Then comes my fit again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For you, our swords have blunt edges, too dull to harm you, Mark Antony.
target: For your part, To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony.

target: I saw ’t not, thought it not, it harmed not me.

target: Is it possible?

target: Who’s born that day When I forget to send to Antony Shall die a beggar.

target: I can no more.

target: Wherefore speaks he this To her he hates?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re naughty.
target: You are naught, you are naught.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, but not out of fear.
target: Ay, but not frighted me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Only for poor men?
target: Poor men alone?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The Constable of France.
target: The constable of France.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This feather moved because of her breath.
target: This feather stirs.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All right then, legitimate brother Edgar, I have to have your lands.
target: Well then, Legitimate Edgar, I must have your land.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Titinius is lying face-up.
target: Titinius' face is upward.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What have I ever done that he has anything to complain about?
target: How have I been behaved that he might stick The small’st opinion on my least misuse?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Madam, I’ve come here to try to make you like him.
target: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts On his behalf.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, it doesn’t mean anything.
target: Tis neither here nor there.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where’s Antony now?
target: Where is he now?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is he talking nonsense?
target: Does he rave?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You are the best of the cutthroats.
target: Thou art the best o' th' cutthroats: Yet he’s good that did the like for Fleance.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He really is the most skillful, bloodthirsty, and dangerous opponent you can find in Illyria.
target: He is, indeed, sir, the most skillful, bloody, and fatal opposite that you could possibly have found in any part of Illyria.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our imminent separation so occupies our thoughts that even though you stay here, you come with me, and even though I leave here, I stay with you.
target: Our separation so abides and flies That thou, residing here, goes yet with me, And I, hence fleeting, here remain with thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s dead to me.
target: Ay, to me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I would have thought she was invincible against any assault of love.
target: I would have thought her spirit had been invincible against all assaults of affection.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please go on.
target: The rest will comfort, for thy counsel’s sound.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The next bit of good news is that our ship—which we gave up for ruined only three hours ago—is as well-outfitted and seaworthy as it was when we first set sail.
target: The next, our ship— Which, but three glasses since, we gave out split— Is tight and yare and bravely rigged as when We first put out to sea.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come at me in the form of a rugged Russian bear, an armor-plated rhinoceros, or a tiger from Iran.
target: Approach thou like the rugged Russian bear, The armed rhinoceros, or th' Hyrcan tiger; Take any shape but that, and my firm nerves Shall never tremble.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go on, master, and I will follow you—with truth and loyalty to my last breath.
target: Master, go on, and I will follow thee To the last gasp, with truth and loyalty.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If we let crimes like this happen, slaves and heathens will be our rulers.
target: For if such actions may have passage free, Bond-slaves and pagans shall our statesmen be.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s she trying to say?
target: What means this lady?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come talk to me about this.
target: Come to me, that of this I may speak more.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t imagine what’s made him so unlike himself, other than his father’s death.
target: What it should be, More than his father’s death, that thus hath put him So much from th' understanding of himself, I cannot dream of.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I won’t stand for it.
target: I’ll not endure it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I won’t either, sir.
target: Nor I, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sorry, I’m all stuffed.
target: I am stuffed, cousin.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Most noble man, will you die?
target: Noblest of men, woo’t die?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, my good lord.
target: No, my good lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Call out my household servants.
target: Call forth my household servants.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She went from me, who loved her with the dignity and devotion that suits a legitimate marriage, to a wretch whose natural gifts were poor compared to mine.
target: From me, whose love was of that dignity That it went hand in hand even with the vow I made to her in marriage, and to decline Upon a wretch whose natural gifts were poor To those of mine.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Though the last time I saw him it was black from the smoke of war.
target: Yet, when I saw it last, it was besmeared As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I am a spirit, yes, since I have a soul.
target: A spirit I am indeed, But am in that dimension grossly clad Which from the womb I did participate.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My dear Miss Chat-her-up, I look forward to getting to know you better.
target: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Welcome, dear madam.
target: Welcome, dear madam.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: First let me talk with this philosopher here.—
target: First let me talk with this philosopher.—

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good morning to you, friend.
target: Good dawning to thee, friend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then he’s the whining schoolboy, with a book bag and a bright, young face, creeping like a snail unwillingly to school.
target: Then the whining schoolboy with his satchel And shining morning face, creeping like snail Unwillingly to school.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: with the same accessories.
target: Still in this fashion, color, ornament, For him I imitate.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good news, friends.
target: News, friends!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Not true, not true.
target: Not so, not so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: These revelations have overwhelmed her.
target: These things, come thus to light, Smother her spirits up.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Silly babbler, how you talk!
target: Poor prattler, how thou talk’st!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s the truth.
target: Ay me, detested!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Everything’s fine now.
target: Now all is well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, my lord, don’t be friendly with her.
target: Dear my lord, Be not familiar with her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll go hunting again tomorrow, I think.
target: Tomorrow I intend to hunt again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Roderigo’s been killed?
target: Roderigo killed?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hello, do you have any news?
target: How now, what news?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s clear that someone less noble, less loyal, more bloody-minded than Clarence but not a blood relation, deserves as bad an end as my brother, but he goes free.
target: God grant that some, less noble and less loyal, Nearer in bloody thoughts, and not in blood, Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did, And yet go current from suspicion.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hope you go senile soon, sir, so you can become a more foolish fool!
target: God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the better increasing your folly!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did you hear that?
target: Do you mark that, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No doubt the murderous knife was blunt till it was sharpened on your stony heart—you reveled in my lambs' bloody guts.
target: No doubt the murd'rous knife was dull and blunt Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart, To revel in the entrails of my lambs.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But goodbye.
target: But fare you well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll stay in Messina until you’re married, and then I’ll go to Aragon.
target: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and then go I toward Aragon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I thought I had escaped from the Tower and was on a ship to France with my brother Richard, who persuaded me to leave my cabin and walk on deck with him.
target: Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower And was embarked to cross to Burgundy, And in my company my brother Gloucester, Who from my cabin tempted me to walk Upon the hatches.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, he did.
target: Ay, that he did.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, my good lord.
target: Ay, my good lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can tell your Majesty, the duke is a brave man.
target: I can tell your Majesty, the duke is a prave man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who are you, moaning in the hut like that?
target: What art thou that dost grumble there i' th' straw?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye, boy.
target: Fare you well, boy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll get you for that.
target: I will owe thee an answer for that.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I am not made of stone; I am affected by all these kind pleas, though it goes against my conscience and my soul.
target: I am not made of stones, But penetrable to your kind entreaties, Albeit against my conscience and my soul.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This epitaph will hang here forever, Continuing to praise Hero after I die.
target: Hang thou there upon the tomb, Praising her when I am dumb.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t like it.
target: Tut, I like it not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, what did he do?
target: What’s his fault?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is there anyone to give the bride away?
target: Is there none here to give the woman?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You, Roderigo!
target: You, Roderigo!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here he comes.
target: Here he comes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve shut the memory of your beautiful eyes out of my heart.
target: For, of my heart, those charms, thine eyes, are blotted.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I would’ve been a sore king then.
target: I should have been a sore one then.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No one.
target: Nobody.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stand close together, in case someone loyal to Caesar tries to— Don’t talk about standing together.—Publius, cheer up.
target: Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar’s Should chance— Talk not of standing.—Publius, good cheer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh!
target: Oh!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s enough.
target: Thy spirits are most tall.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d like to introduce you to my friend.
target: Give welcome to my friend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d like to sing my song solo.
target: I would sing my song without a burden.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, you scoundrel!
target: O villain!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s lost his comrades and is wandering around looking for them.
target: He hath lost his fellows And strays about to find 'em.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Better men than you have heard me speak my mind, and if you can’t take it, then you’d better plug your ears.
target: Your betters have endured me say my mind, And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If your wife’s not a madwoman, and you tell her how much I deserve this ring, she won’t stay angry at you forever if you give it to me.
target: An if your wife be not a madwoman, And know how well I have deserved the ring, She would not hold out enemy forever For giving it to me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The Emperor is calling for Canidius.
target: The Emperor calls Canidius.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why should I stay— In this vile world?
target: What should I stay— In this wild world?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on.
target: Come.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But it’s dark out, and it could be a trap.
target: Tis heavy night, These may be counterfeits.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Call Claudio and some of my other men.
target: Call Claudio and some other of my men.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We have to get out of here, old man.
target: Away, old man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where are my good fellows?
target: Where are these hearts?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: With a touch of green in it.
target: With an eye of green in ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll fight brutally.
target: I will be treble-sinewed, -hearted, -breathed, And fight maliciously.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The duke went with him to search Bassanio’s ship.
target: The villain Jew with outcries raised the Duke, Who went with him to search Bassanio’s ship.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, he’s been betrayed, and I’ve been ruined.
target: Alas, he is betrayed and I undone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Slay!
target: Slay!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Venice has made Cassio governor here on Cyprus.
target: Sir, there is especial commission come from Venice to depute Cassio in Othello’s place.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: First kiss me, Kate, and then we will.
target: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Didn’t I meet up with your allies?
target: Did I not meet thy friends?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, but who is he?
target: Ay, marry, what is he?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And you, sweet Hero?
target: And you too, gentle Hero?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My sword will talk for me.
target: My voice is in my sword.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take this mad wretch to jail.—Father-in-law Baptista, will you see that he’s available to appear in court?
target: Carry this mad knave to the jail.—Father Baptista, I charge you see that he be forthcoming.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t even have one to throw at a dog.
target: Not one to throw at a dog.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve acted like such a villain!
target: Oh, wretched villain!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What did you say to me?
target: What say you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hope for my brother’s sake that he just wrote it to test my honor.
target: I hope, for my brother’s justification, he wrote this but as an essay or taste of my virtue.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now they’ve turned around and are clearly heading for Cyprus.
target: And now they do re-stem Their backward course, bearing with frank appearance Their purposes toward Cyprus.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She can’t stand to hear about getting a husband.
target: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m tired of it, and you say you’re tired of it too.
target: It wearies me; you say it wearies you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me your arm.
target: Give me thy arm.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: By the god Jupiter above, I swear “No.” By Jupiter’s wife Juno, I swear “Yes.” They wouldn’t dare.
target: By Jupiter, I swear “No.” By Juno, I swear “Ay.”    They durst not do ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I only wish I could load him up with all the praise he deserves!
target: Would I were able to load him with his desert!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I am the duke who loved your father.
target: I am the duke That loved your father.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can justify that better than you can justify sleeping with Portia’s African servant.
target: I shall answer that better to the commonwealth than you can the getting up of the Negro’s belly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is he right?
target: Is that any thing now?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m not in a joking mood.
target: I am not in a sportive humor now.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We used to sit together and sew one flower with our two needles, sewing it on one piece of cloth, sitting on the same cushion, singing one song in the same key, as if our hands, our sides, our voices and our minds were stuck together.
target: We, Hermia, like two artificial gods, Have with our needles created both one flower, Both on one sampler, sitting on one cushion, Both warbling of one song, both in one key, As if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds, Had been incorporate.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sweet Moon, I thank you for your sunny beams.
target: Sweet Moon, I thank thee for thy sunny beams.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye.
target: Farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They’ve turned me into food for worms.
target: They have made worms' meat of me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hope to God I’m wrong about your chances.
target: Pray heaven I be deceived in you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And why are you so pale?
target: Why look you pale?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Not young enough to fall in love with a woman because she sings well, but not old enough to dote on a woman for any reason.
target: Not so young, sir, to love a woman for singing, nor so old to dote on her for anything.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s there?
target: Who’s there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What time is it?
target: What is ’t o'clock?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s not feeling well.
target: She is not well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Was this ambition?
target: Was this ambition?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good-bye.
target: Farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His face will make the heavens so beautiful that the world will fall in love with the night and forget about the garish sun.
target: And when I shall die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine That all the world will be in love with night And pay no worship to the garish sun.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But he’s sleeping.
target: But he sleeps.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do tell.
target: I prithee let me hear it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There never was a monarch better feared and loved than yourself, your Majesty.
target: Never was monarch better feared and loved Than is your Majesty.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My plans take me a roundabout way.
target: My purposes do draw me much about.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’s no ambiguity here.
target: There is no obstruction in this.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, just wait a minute.
target: Nay, I prithee stay a little.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: At least it’s possible in Denmark.
target: At least I’m sure it may be so in Denmark.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have news for you about the Prince’s punishment.
target: I bring thee tidings of the Prince’s doom.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s not talking to me.
target: Tis not to me she speaks.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Refusing to fight him at sea won’t disgrace you.
target: No disgrace Shall fall you for refusing him at sea, Being prepared for land.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye to the soldiers and to the wars that make men great!
target: Farewell the plumèd troops and the big wars That makes ambition virtue!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Remember who liked your yellow stockings—” Your yellow stockings?
target: Remember who commended thy yellow stockings—” Thy yellow stockings?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here’s to your health.
target: Here’s to thy health.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go up there and second his petition.
target: Press near and second him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That our grandmother’s soul could end up inhabiting a bird.
target: That the soul of our grandam might haply inhabit a bird.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is she really that wonderful?
target: Is it so brave a lass?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m glad to see you in such a merry mood.
target: I am glad to see you in this merry vein.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh cousin, cousin, cousin, my sweet little cousin, I wish you knew how deep in love I am.
target: O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thou didst know how many fathom deep I am in love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let tornadoes spew water until the steeples of our churches and the weathervanes are all drowned.
target: You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout Till you have drenched our steeples, drowned the cocks!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll do it.
target: This is open.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is that possible?
target: Is ’t possible?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How many things in life seem good to us because of when they happen!
target: How many things by season seasoned are To their right praise and true perfection!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Cheer up, Antonio!
target: Good cheer, Antonio!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The devil in him is strong!
target: The fiend is strong within him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have done your bidding and fulfilled my promise.
target: I have performed Your pleasure and my promise.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ll wear a mask, and you can make your voice as high as you want to.
target: You shall play it in a mask, and you may speak as small as you will.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’s no power in Venice that can change an established decree.
target: There is no power in Venice Can alter a decree establishèd.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come, sisters, let’s cheer him up and show him our talents.
target: Come, sisters, cheer we up his sprites, And show the best of our delights.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It is that.
target: Tis so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A wise man and a fool.
target: Marry, here’s grace and a codpiece—that’s a wise man and a fool.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You have a daughter named Elizabeth, who is virtuous and beautiful, aristocratic and full of grace.
target: You have a daughter called Elizabeth, Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye.
target: Adieu.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If she feels like coming over here, I’ll give her your message.
target: If she will stir hither, I shall seem to notify unto her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You stole it from her?
target: Hast stolen it from her?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So do all thoughts.
target: So do all thoughts.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is a sleepy tune.
target: This is a sleepy tune.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How are you, Malvolio?
target: How now, Malvolio!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Help!
target: Help, ho!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She took that ring from me.
target: She took the ring of me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: By nine o'clock.
target: By the hour of nine.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you say to a calf’s foot?
target: What say you to a neat’s foot?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It was a rough night.
target: Twas a rough night.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Just one glass.
target: But one cup.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My brave relative!
target: O valiant cousin!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t give it away.
target: No words.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I suspect that I have committed some offence to the city and you have come to reprimand me for not knowing better.
target: I do suspect I have done some offense That seems disgracious in the city’s eye, And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh righteous God, how can I thank you enough that this meat-eating mutt preys on his mother’s children and forces her to join others in their grief!
target: O upright, just, and true-disposing God, How do I thank thee that this carnal cur Preys on the issue of his mother’s body And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you dreaming or awake?
target: What, art thou waking?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look how cheerful my mother is, only two hours after my father died.
target: For, look you, how cheerfully my mother looks, and my father died within these two hours.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sure, and twenty others just like you.
target: Ay, and twenty such.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I would choose to take my penalty.
target: I would have my bond.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And I would die a thousand deaths cheerfully, if it made your life easier.
target: And I, most jocund, apt, and willingly, To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m amazed you got here before me.
target: It gives me wonder great as my content To see you here before me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you hurt, lieutenant?
target: What, are you hurt, lieutenant?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And bring the ship’s captain to the castle.
target: Bring thou the master to the citadel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where are you going?
target: Whither away?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But don’t let me keep you from going, Cassius.
target: Let me not hinder, Cassius, your desires.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord, he asks that you please visit him tomorrow or the next day.
target: He doth entreat your Grace, my noble lord, To visit him tomorrow or next day.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you mean by that?
target: What mean’st thou by that?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s the one: Leonato’s Hero, your Hero, every man’s Hero.
target: Even she: Leonato’s Hero, your Hero, every man’s Hero.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me.
target: Give me answer to it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The sails were dyed purple, and they were perfumed so heavily that they made the air seem dizzy with love.
target: The poop was beaten gold, Purple the sails, and so perfumèd that The winds were lovesick with them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, if you want to help yourself.
target: Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Therefore it’s certain that he wasn’t ambitious.
target: Therefore ’tis certain he was not ambitious.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Taurus!
target: Taurus!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The total due is about three ducats more than I owe this gentleman.
target: Saving your merry humor, here’s the note How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat, The fineness of the gold, and chargeful fashion, Which doth amount to three-odd ducats more Than I stand debted to this gentleman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I did that to him.
target: That I did for him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So with no money, but a little more wisdom, I’m going back to Venice.
target: And so, with no money at all and a little more wit, return again to Venice.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can only repeat what I’ve said before.
target: But saying o'er what I have said before.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re as pale as your nightgown!
target: O ill-starred wench, Pale as thy smock!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He insisted on leaving this ring with me whether I wanted it or not.
target: He left this ring behind him, Would I or not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is a horrible sight.
target: The sight is dismal, And our affairs from England come too late.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So I will, my liege.
target: So I will, my liege, as I live.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Portia, goodbye to you.
target: Portia, adieu.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You should be able to endure this because the world is broad and wide.
target: Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s a good tragedy, very well done.
target: And so it is, truly, and very notably discharged.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, right, good Catesby.
target: O true, good Catesby.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you think of his belief?
target: What thinkest thou of his opinion?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look, you’ve got his wrinkled hands.
target: Here’s his dry hand up and down.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Mr. Fabian, stay with this gentleman until I come back.
target: Signior Fabian, stay you by this gentleman till my return.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord, your promise of the earldom— Richmond!
target: My lord, your promise for the earldom— Richmond!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You all saw that on the Lupercal feast day I offered him a king’s crown three times, and he refused it three times.
target: You all did see that on the Lupercal I thrice presented him a kingly crown, Which he did thrice refuse.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I was just knocking to see if anyone was home.
target: And this cuff was but to knock at your ear and beseech list'ning.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why the hell did you come in between us?
target: Why the devil came you between us?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bring me a bigger one.
target: Come, let me have a bigger.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If he agrees, great.
target: If he will take it, so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, I swear by my life and soul!
target: No, by my life and soul!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll stop by before you go to bed, and tell you what I’ve heard.
target: I’ll call upon you ere you go to bed And tell you what I know.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So let me be brief here.
target: Brief let me be.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think you’re right, sir.
target: I think it well, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, what’s the problem?
target: Why, sir, what’s your conceit in that?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You thought you were being funny, but you said the truth.
target: You have spoken truer than you purposed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He is in love with Hero.
target: He is enamored on Hero.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re not going anywhere.
target: You shall not go.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Cobweb.
target: Cobweb.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s ruining my rituals of true love?
target: What cursèd foot wanders this way tonight To cross my obsequies and true love’s rite?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The night has been chaotic.
target: The night has been unruly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As for his thoughts, I wish he’d think about nothing at all rather than think about me all the time.
target: For his thoughts, Would they were blanks, rather than fill’d with me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.
target: My cousin means Signor Benedick of Padua.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, he comes to be married  Lady, do you come here to be married to this count?
target: Lady, you come hither to be married to this count?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I explained how you were deceived, how you were thwarted, the things that were used against you, who was working against you, and a lot of other things that would convince even a half-wit or a crazy person to say, “Banquo did it!” You explained it all.
target: This I made good to you In our last conference, passed in probation with you, How you were borne in hand, how crossed, the instruments, Who wrought with them, and all things else that might To half a soul and to a notion crazed Say, “Thus did Banquo.”      You made it known to us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Know the glove!
target: Know the glove!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And, in fact, I think they’re meeting together right now.
target: And the hour, I think, is come To give him hearing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go tell your generals to hurry their preparations.
target: Pray you, hasten Your generals after.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s too bad their beauty fades right when it reaches perfection!
target: Alas, that they are so, To die even when they to perfection grow!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come along, though.
target: But come thy ways.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hurry, hurry, close the curtain quick.
target: Draw the curtain straight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I did it myself.
target: I myself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Indeed I did, my lord.
target: That did I, my lord, and was accounted a good actor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How could I forget, my lord!
target: Remember it, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A good reputation is the most valuable thing we have—men and women alike.
target: Good name in man and woman, dear my lord, Is the immediate jewel of their souls.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Antony, it’s time to stop your wild hedonism.
target: Antony, Leave thy lascivious wassails.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve got you now, pagan.
target: Now, infidel, I have you on the hip.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have you heard about anything unusual happening in the city?
target: Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then it looks like Macbeth will become king.
target: Then ’tis most like The sovereignty will fall upon Macbeth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come with me, boy.
target: Come, boy, with me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take it off and throw it on the ground.
target: Off with that bauble, throw it underfoot.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You can’t trust anyone who abuses her own father, her flesh and blood.
target: That nature, which contemns its origin Cannot be bordered certain in itself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What a poor instrument, that can do such a noble deed!
target: What poor an instrument May do a noble deed!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Control yourself, my precious Queen, and concede that my love is true.
target: My precious Queen, forbear, And give true evidence to his love which stands An honorable trial.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is he dead?
target: Is he dead?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: May Egypt drown in the Nile and all good creatures turn into poisonous snakes.
target: Melt Egypt into Nile, and kindly creatures Turn all to serpents.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I couldn’t stay behind after you left.
target: I could not stay behind you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m the ghost of your father, doomed for a certain period of time to walk the earth at night, while during the day I’m trapped in the fires of purgatory until I’ve done penance for my past sins.
target: I am thy father’s spirit, Doomed for a certain term to walk the night And for the day confined to fast in fires, Till the foul crimes done in my days of nature Are burnt and purged away.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All I’m asking for is to have that little human boy as part of my crew.
target: I do but beg a little changeling boy, To be my henchman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m involved in your rivalry.
target: I have an interest in your hearts' proceeding.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye.
