source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s true, my good boy.—Come on, take us to that hut.
target: True, my good boy.—Come, bring us to this hovel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s safe, Antony.
target: Safe, Antony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thanks, Guildenstern and worthy Rosencrantz.
target: Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And at the base of Pompey’s statue, with his cloak covering his face, which was dripping with blood the whole time, great Caesar fell.
target: Then burst his mighty heart, And, in his mantle muffling up his face, Even at the base of Pompey’s statue, Which all the while ran blood, great Caesar fell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When I left him, he was less than nine miles from here.
target: He was not three leagues off when I left him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What, faithful to being mean and nasty?
target: What, to perverseness?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I didn’t say free, madam.
target: Free, madam, no.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here comes Lorenzo.
target: Here comes Lorenzo.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s that trumpet?
target: What trumpet’s that?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My spells are working well, my spirits are obeying me, and everything is right on schedule.
target: My charms crack not, my spirits obey, and time Goes upright with his carriage.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: To race after your departing ships, leaving his navy to watch, was a shame as great as the resulting loss.
target: Twas a shame no less Than was his loss, to course your flying flags And leave his navy gazing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God bless you, my friend, and your music too.
target: Save thee, friend, and thy music.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen!
target: Hark!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What must be will be.
target: What must be shall be.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I’ll get you a candle and paper and ink.
target: I will fetch you light, and paper, and ink.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His legs aren’t great, but they’re alright.
target: His leg is but so-so—and yet ’tis well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All the perfumes of Arabia couldn’t make my little hand smell better.
target: All the perfumes of Arabia will not sweeten this little hand.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me, please: how many boys and girls will I have?
target: Prithee, how many boys and wenches must I have?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The warships have sent a dozen messages tonight, one after the other, and many of the senators have been awakened and are at the Duke’s already.
target: The galleys Have sent a dozen sequent messengers This very night at one another’s heels, And many of the consuls, raised and met, Are at the Duke’s already.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can he even get angry?
target: Can he be angry?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know they’re in Rome together, hoping for Antony to return.
target: I know they are in Rome together Looking for Antony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What did you say?
target: What is it thou didst say?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t remember.
target: I cannot tell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But let me hear the letter from your friend.
target: But let me hear the letter of your friend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lovell, go as fast as you can to Doctor Shaw.
target: Go, Lovell, with all speed to Doctor Shaw.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Beware of March 15th.
target: Beware the ides of March.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who are you?
target: What are you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hope you think I’m faithful to you.
target: I hope my noble lord esteems me honest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s be sacrificers but not butchers, Caius.
target: Let us be sacrificers but not butchers, Caius.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, well, I don’t care.
target: By my heel, I care not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I swear I’m not the person I’m playing.
target: And yet, by the very fangs of malice I swear, I am not that I play.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will go straight to visit him.
target: And thither will I straight to visit him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s the bet?
target: What’s the wager?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord?
target: My lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ll never see me again, whether or not he’s dead.
target: See me no more, whether he be dead or no.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please hear what Goneril is saying.
target: Give ear, sir, to my sister.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I swear to God it’s true, sir.
target: As I do live, my honored lord, ’tis true.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shame on you, you slanderer!
target: Oh, fie upon thee, slanderer!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s my master who’s not getting the reward he deserves, not me.
target: My master, not myself, lacks recompense.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We argued about which was best, and now we won’t get either one.
target: In debating which was best, we shall part with neither.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, sir— Don’t think I’m flattering you.
target: O my dear lord—   Nay, do not think I flatter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The duke will be here tonight?
target: The duke be here tonight?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So all hail, Macbeth and Banquo!
target: So all hail, Macbeth and Banquo!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, is it possible that a person could fall in love so suddenly?
target: I pray, sir, tell me, is it possible That love should of a sudden take such hold?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Picture the linen sails driven by the invisible and subtle wind as they pull the vast hulls through the wrinkled sea, breasting the high waves.
target: Behold the threaden sails, Borne with th' invisible and creeping wind, Draw the huge bottoms through the furrowed sea, Breasting the lofty surge.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s this, my lord?
target: How now, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll be getting my own figures together in the meantime.
target: Till which encounter It is my business too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sa, sa, sa, sa.
target: Then there’s life in ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve spelled it out for you clearly.
target: Be certain, nothing truer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You are my love, my love, I think.
target: My love thou art, my love, I think.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And everything will be alright, I promise you, wife.
target: Tush, I will stir about, And all things shall be well, I warrant thee, wife.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Farewell, good Strato.
target: Farewell, good Strato.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Signior Benedick!
target: Signor Benedick!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, fashion is fashion.
target: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come here, sir.
target: Come hither, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That way Antony will feel like he’s fighting his own men.
target: Go charge Agrippa Plant those that have revolted in the vant, That Antony may seem to spend his fury Upon himself.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I just speak directly.
target: I only speak right on.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Three months from twelve months of the year.
target: Three months from twelve, then.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And I wouldn’t ask for any dowry except for her to play another trick like this one.
target: And ask no other dowry with her but such another jest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They burn for revenge.
target: Revenges burn in them, for their dear causes Would to the bleeding and the grim alarm Excite the mortified man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So be quiet.
target: Therefore speak softly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Therefore, the fact that you’re awake this early tells me you’ve been upset with some anxiety.
target: Therefore thy earliness doth me assure Thou art uproused by some distemperature.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where’s your conscience now?
target: Where’s thy conscience now?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You and your fellow spirits did your last assignment well, and now I need your help again.
target: Thou and thy meaner fellows your last service Did worthily perform, and I must use you In such another trick.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, if you struggle with me— Just half an hour!
target: Nay, if you strive— But half an hour!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Unfaithful, my lord?
target: To whom, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I give you my obedience and my humble service, madam.
target: My duty, madam, and most humble service.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Love will give me strength, and strength will help me accomplish this plan.
target: Love give me strength, and strength shall help afford.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, the glory of war has faded.
target: Oh, withered is the garland of the war.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, sir, be quiet.
target: Alas, sir, be patient.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, leave that labor to great Hercules—it’s worse than the previous twelve put together.
target: Yea, leave that labor to great Hercules, And let it be more than Alcides' twelve.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, corporal, stop!
target: Pray thee, corporal, stay.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I wish you’d never been born!
target: O thou weed, Who art so lovely fair and smell’st so sweet That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst ne'er been born!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go find him, please, and bring him to my tent.
target: Pray thee, go seek him, and bring him to my tent.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me a kiss.
target: Give me a kiss.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shall I let them exhibit me to the shouting mobs of Rome?
target: Shall they hoist me up And show me to the shouting varletry Of censuring Rome?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thank you, sir.
target: Good my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here comes Sir Toby, limping.
target: Here comes Sir Toby halting.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will, my lord.
target: I will, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They sing when they die.
target: And die in music.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Meanwhile, let’s go to bed and dream about this.
target: For this night, to bed, and dream on the event.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m critical by nature.
target: Come on, assay.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll do what you want us to, my lord.
target: We shall, my lord, Perform what you command us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord, what are you talking about?
target: What means your lordship?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll wait over here.
target: I will walk by.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God will protect me.
target: Give me faith, say I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There is a crab-apple here.
target: There is, there is.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, the second time around, since, as they say, old people become children again.
target: Happily he’s the second time come to them, for they say an old man is twice a child.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I heard that Julius Caesar got fat from all the feasting there.
target: I have heard that Julius Caesar Grew fat with feasting there.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh well, God’s in charge, and some people have to go to heaven, while other people have to go to hell.
target: Well, heaven’s above all, and there be souls must be saved, and there be souls must not be saved.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, fifteen days of March have gone by.
target: Sir, March is wasted fifteen days.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wretched boy, you hung out with him here, and you’re going to go to heaven with him.
target: Thou, wretched boy, that didst consort him here Shalt with him hence.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I didn’t take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me.” That’s like saying, “Any thing I do for you is as easy as saying ‘thank you.’” If this doesn’t move me to take pity on her, I’m a horrible person.
target: I took no more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me.” That’s as much as to say, “Any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks.” If I do not take pity of her, I am a villain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, I am.
target: Ay, I do.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have made your daughter mine by marriage while false impressions blinded your eyes.
target: Here’s Lucentio, right son to the right Vincentio, That have by marriage made thy daughter mine While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now the only person I love, and believe in, and want to look at, is Helena.
target: And all the faith, the virtue of my heart, The object and the pleasure of mine eye, Is only Helena.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re too bitter.
target: I prithee, hear me speak.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll take it over to the pile.
target: I’ll carry it to the pile.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It is well done, and appropriate for a princess who has descended from so many royal kings.
target: It is well done and fitting for a princess Descended of so many royal kings.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh ho, is that what you’re getting at?
target: Oh ho, are you there with me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Watch his reaction.
target: Observe his construction of it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look, here’s where Cassius’s dagger pierced it.
target: Look, in this place ran Cassius' dagger through.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Right on cue.
target: In happy time.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How are things going now?
target: How goes the world, sir, now?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I didn’t give her any ring.
target: I left no ring with her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What, that’s all?
target: What, no more?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve seen her do it.
target: And yet she’ll kneel and pray, I have seen her do ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When she landed at the port, Antony sent an invitation for her to come to supper.
target: Upon her landing, Antony sent to her, Invited her to supper.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I won’t beg the gods to punish you, or caution you to fear their judgment.
target: I do not bid the thunder-bearer shoot, Nor tell tales of thee to high-judging Jove.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s very handsome.
target: A very handsome man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye, old friend.
target: Farewell, sweet playfellow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Isn’t this Stephano, my drunken butler?
target: Is not this Stephano, my drunken butler?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My girlfriend has beautiful white hands, and great warriors aren’t  Ha, ha!
target: My lady has a white hand, and the Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I bet he slipped away and went home to bed.
target: He is wise, And, on my life, hath stol'n him home to bed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When an evil thing has been lost, no one cries.
target: No evil lost is wailed when it is gone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This one, and I will give her to you.
target: This same is she, and I do give you her.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She can’t hurt you, Helena.
target: She shall not harm thee, Helena.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you who are so wise can’t help, please be kind enough to call my solution wise.
target: If in thy wisdom thou canst give no help, Do thou but call my resolution wise, And with this knife I’ll help it presently.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s our destiny, like death.
target: Tis destiny unshunnable, like death.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You foolish madman, listen to me for a moment.
target: Thou fond mad man, hear me a little speak.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’ll come right away.
target: And so he goes to heaven.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shouldn’t I say, “Does a dog have money?
target: Should I not say, “Hath a dog money?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Follow them straight to the cottage.
target: Not to be endured.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We must preserve our goodwill toward each other and not break into factions again.
target: The broken rancor of your high-swoll'n hates, But lately splintered, knit, and joined together, Must gently be preserved, cherished, and kept.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, get ready.
target: Come, prepare.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Twenty crowns?
target: Twenty crowns?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me the death sentence and end all my troubles.
target: Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall, And by the doom of death end woes and all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, I hope you stay in that frame of mind or some poor man will end up with his face all scratched up.
target: God keep your Ladyship still in that mind, so some gentle- man or other shall ’scape a predestinate scratched face.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then I’ll see you again?
target: Well, then I shall see thee again?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I swear, old fools become like babies again.
target: Now by my life, Old fools are babes again and must be used With checks as flatteries, when they are seen abused.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We are men, my lord.
target: We are men, my liege.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me to tear up this contract.
target: Bid me tear the bond.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s the only worthy man in Italy, aside from my dear Claudio.
target: He is the only man of Italy, Always excepted my dear Claudio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is the door.
target: This is the door.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, please, tell us, sir.
target: Good my lord, tell it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come, come, I know what you’re referring to, Richard.
target: Come, come, we know your meaning, brother Gloucester.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You attract me to you, you cruel magnet!
target: You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can see what’s in broad daylight.
target: I can see a church by daylight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You seem all right now.
target: Why, but you are now well enough.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As I remember, this should be the house.
target: As I remember, this should be the house.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Me too.
target: I' faith, or I either?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Call my knights together.
target: Call my train together.— Degenerate bastard, I’ll not trouble thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, tell me—which of my bad qualities did you fall in love with first?
target: And I pray thee now tell me, for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in love with me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Always give him his way.
target: In each thing give him way.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I find an opportunity, I will give him a piece of my mind.
target: If I find a hole in his coat, I will tell him my mind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, sir.
target: Sir, no.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Was my father a traitor, Mother?
target: Was my father a traitor, Mother?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We need a calendar!
target: A calendar, a calendar!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Farewell.
target: Farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you blushing?
target: Change you color?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now that I think about it, Maria was the one who first told me you were insane.
target: And now I do bethink me, it was she First told me thou wast mad, then camest in smiling, And in such forms which here were presupposed Upon thee in the letter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Either we go after Pompey or he’ll come after us.
target: Of us must Pompey presently be sought, Or else he seeks out us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What dangers are you trying to lead me into, Cassius, that you want me to look inside myself for something that’s not there?
target: Into what dangers would you lead me, Cassius, That you would have me seek into myself For that which is not in me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Great God of heaven, say amen to all this!
target: Great God of heaven, say amen to all!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Fulvia?
target: Fulvia?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you wish.
target: So please you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m surprised I didn’t bite back.
target: I marvel why I answered not again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For the favor of sleeping in her bed.
target: For the best turn i’ th’ bed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look out, I’m on my way up.
target: Now, gods, stand up for bastards!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This chatter is no cure for my toothache.
target: Yet is this no charm for the toothache.—Old Signior, walk aside with me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How strange that they all got so sleepy!
target: What a strange drowsiness possesses them!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She says all the right things, but the dumbest brothel-keeper would tell the same story.
target: She says enough, yet she’s a simple bawd That cannot say as much.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me, how did you get in here?
target: By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s in there?
target: Who talks within there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is your master awake?
target: Is thy master stirring?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But in the meantime, just assume that I’m paranoid—as I’m pretty sure I am—and keep thinking she’s innocent, please.
target: In the meantime, Let me be thought too busy in my fears— As worthy cause I have to fear I am— And hold her free, I do beseech your honor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Her heart is carrying a heavy weight.
target: The heart is sorely charged.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What part of her body is Ireland?
target: In what part of her body stands Ireland?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, Isis, that’s impossible.
target: O Isis, ’tis impossible.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Besides, he brings his fate with him.
target: Besides, he brings his destiny with him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, my king, be quiet.
target: Prithee, my king, be quiet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Some of those lines had more feet than the  That’s not a problem: the feet can bear Sure, but these feet were
target: Ay, but the feet were lame and could not bear themselves without the verse, and therefore stood lamely in the verse.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you mean by “carriages”?
target: What call you the carriages?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A crown was offered to him, and he pushed it away with the back of his hand, like this—and then the people started shouting.
target: Why, there was a crown offered him; and, being offered him, he put it by with the back of his hand, thus; and then the people fell a-shouting.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You have offered me the lands of Sicily and Sardinia.
target: You have made me offer Of Sicily, Sardinia.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It was my magic that saved you when I arrived on the island and heard you, making the pine tree open and let you out.
target: It was mine art, When I arrived and heard thee, that made gape The pine and let thee out.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, help!
target: Oh, help!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You said those exact things to me back in the marketplace.
target: Villain, thou liest; for even her very words Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Farewell till then.
target: Farewell till then.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have a good morning.
target: Give you good morrow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All right, go ahead, keep up your little game, pretend to be sympathetic, but then nudge each other and wink and make faces at me when I turn my back.
target: Persever, counterfeit sad looks, Make mouths upon me when I turn my back, Wink each at other, hold the sweet jest up— This sport, well carried, shall be chronicled.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Freedom!
target: Freedom!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish I were, so I could deprive you of both day and life.
target: I would I were, to be revenged on thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now you sound like a man.
target: This tune goes manly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It just appeared before them and marched past them with slow dignity three times, a staff’s distance from their amazed eyes, while they turned, quaking with fear and too shocked to speak.
target: Thrice he walked By their oppressed and fear-surprisèd eyes Within his truncheon’s length, whilst they, distilled Almost to jelly with the act of fear, Stand dumb and speak not to him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s the matter, dear?
target: What’s the matter, dear?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hey!
target: Sola!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The rooster has already crowed twice.
target: The early village cock Hath twice done salutation to the morn.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s not lost, but what if it were?
target: It is not lost, but what and if it were?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It really is good to see you.
target: By my troth, well met.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Set it down awhile.
target: Set it by a while.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Heaven help him!
target: Now heaven help him!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look and see.
target: Behold and see.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh God!
target: O God!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I beg your pardon, sirs.—Please tell me your name, sir?
target: I cry your worships' mercy, heartily.—I beseech your worship’s name.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you mean, do I think so?
target: Think so, Iago?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I just beg death to wait awhile, until I place the last of our many thousands of kisses on your lips.
target: Only I here importune death awhile, until Of many thousand kisses the poor last I lay upon thy lips.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You scoundrel!
target: You slave, you cur!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, start thinking about marriage now.
target: Well, think of marriage now.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now go!
target: Away!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m not a traitor, unfair lady.
target: Unmerciful lady as you are, I’m none.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d never heard such raucous music, such pleasant thunder.
target: I never heard So musical a discord, such sweet thunder.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Madam!
target: Madam!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, taking you away from your new marriage would be like showing a child a new coat and then not letting him wear it.
target: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to wear it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You will always be welcome to me.
target: Best of comfort, And ever welcome to us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here are my keys.—But why should I go?
target: There are my keys.—But wherefore should I go?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You should know, my loving lord, I’ve heard that the marquess Dorset has fled to Brittany, to the earl of Richmond.
target: Know, my long lord, The marquess Dorset, as I hear, is fled To Richmond, in the parts where he abides.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir Toby, madam, your relative.
target: Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Someone who was always near you.
target: One ever near thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I thought he was just toying with you and meant to ruin your reputation.
target: I feared he did but trifle And meant to wreck thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You would be committing a wicked sin by chiding other people for sinning, because you yourself have been a terrible sinner, as carnal in your appetites as lust itself, and all the swollen pustules of sin that you acquired in your freedom you now want to burst and shoot back into the world at large.
target: Most mischievous foul sin in chiding sin, For thou thyself hast been a libertine, As sensual as the brutish sting itself, And all th' embossèd sores and headed evils That thou with license of free foot hast caught Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Welcome, my lord.
target: Welcome, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take that, and that!
target: Hold, take thou that and that.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’s another.
target: He sings at grave- making.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hey!
target: Ha!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The wound can’t be that bad.
target: The hurt cannot be much.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me my sword.
target: Give me my sword.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I remember a jumble of impressions, but nothing distinctly.
target: I remember a mass of things, but nothing distinctly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The man hasn’t done anything wrong.
target: The man is innocent.

target: It should seem then that Dobbin’s tail grows backward.

target: Tush, Gremio.

target: Stop that, ’twill fly with the smoke out at the chimney.

target: Let’s see once more this saying graved in gold, “Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.” Why, that’s the lady.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t know what you’ve done to upset him, but someone has challenged you to a duel.
target: Of what nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know not, but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as the hunter, attends thee at the orchard end.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All I ever did was tell him how hurtful and bad it was.
target: Still did I tell him it was vile and bad.

target: Lend thy hand And pluck my magic garment from me.

target: Censure me in your wisdom, and awake your senses that you may the better judge.

target: Well then, I know thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good Enobarbus, you would be doing a very good thing if you advised your captain to speak calmly and quietly.
target: Good Enobarbus, ’tis a worthy deed, And shall become you well, to entreat your captain To soft and gentle speech.

target: I’ll have grounds More relative than this.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m finished, then.
target: I have done.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He was a wreck, almost past hope.
target: A wreck past hope he was.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Neighbors, hello.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When you have said your lines, go hide in that bush.—Everyone else, go there too when you’re not onstage.
target: When you have spoken your speech, enter into that brake.—And so everyone according to his cue.

target: Draw the curtains—so, so, so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, a plague has been prevented, thank God!
target: O plague right well prevented!

target: Thou but rememberest me of mine own conception.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Along the way, I’ll find an opportunity to separate him from the queen’s proud relatives, as step one in the plan we’ve discussed.
target: For by the way I’ll sort occasion, As index to the story we late talked of, To part the queen’s proud kindred from the prince.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sure, I hate her, but I wouldn’t hurt her.
target: Although I hate her, I’ll not harm her so.

target: Farewell, thou woeful welcomer of glory.

target: It fell upon a little western flower, Before milk-white, now purple with love’s wound.

target: God help thee, shallow man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Margaret, run into the sitting room.
target: Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor.

target: Then how can it be said I am alone When all the world is here to look on me?

target: I am the very man— I’ll see that straight.

target: Give me that boy and I will go with thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Love can make worthless things beautiful.
target: Things base and vile, holding no quantity, Love can transpose to form and dignity.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Even my hair revolts.
target: My very hairs do mutiny, for the white Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them For fear and doting.

target: What serious contemplation are you in?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: At five o'clock he’s going to pay me for it.
target: At five o'clock I shall receive the money for the same.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And have I ever seemed less than modest or appropriate to you?
target: And seemed I ever otherwise to you?

target: Now must your conscience my acquaintance seal, And you must put me in your heart for friend, Sith you have heard, and with a knowing ear, That he which hath your noble father slain Pursued my life.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But do this: find your brother, wherever he is.
target: But look to it: Find out thy brother, wheresoe'er he is.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You evil thief, where have you hidden my daughter?
target: O thou foul thief, where hast thou stowed my daughter?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The sun itself has never seen anyone as beautiful since the world began.
target: The all-seeing sun Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.

target: We will hence forthwith To feast and sport us at thy father’s house.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll always be loyal to you, sir.

target: Nine or ten times I had thought t' have yerked him here under the ribs.

target: Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.

target: O, pardon me for bringing these ill news, Since you did leave it for my office, sir.

target: I would have made it short, for I was come to the whole depth of my tale, and meant, indeed, to occupy the argument no longer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Farewell.
target: Farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now from head to foot I’m as firm as marble.
target: Now from head to foot I am marble-constant.

target: I’ll do the service of a younger man In all your business and necessities.

target: How art thou out of breath when thou hast breath To say to me that thou art out of breath?

target: My name is Edgar, and thy father’s son.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, lords, don’t let slip any opportunity that might be advantageous for our expedition.

target: Why, to keep one’s eyes of either side ’s nose, that what a man cannot smell out, he may spy into.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, no, boy.

target: Such was the very armour he had on When he the ambitious Norway combated.

target: If the cat will after kind, So, be sure, will Rosalind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The duke’s trumpets.
target: I never got him.— Hark, the duke’s trumpets.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: crowned by the golden sun, observed his heroic son and smiled to see him mangle the work of nature, French youth whose fathers and God had nurtured for twenty years, since they were babies.
target: Up in the air, crowned with the golden sun, Saw his heroical seed and smiled to see him Mangle the work of nature and deface The patterns that by God and by French fathers Had twenty years been made.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your husband lies dead there, and Paris too.
target: Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead, And Paris too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Prepare yourselves.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How can you square things with me?
target: How canst thou make me satisfaction?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: have lost, and the indignity we have endured, for which he is too insignificant to sufficiently pay us back.
target: Bid him therefore consider of his ransom, which must proportion the losses we have borne, the subjects we have lost, the disgrace we have digested, which, in weight to reanswer, his pettiness would bow under.

target: There lies the man, slain by young Romeo, That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Really, I’m afraid you are.
target: Trust me, I fear it has.

target: Bless you, fair dame!

target: Also King Lewis the Tenth, Who was sole heir to the usurper Capet, Could not keep quiet in his conscience, Wearing the crown of France, till satisfied That fair Queen Isabel, his grandmother, Was lineal of the Lady Ermengare, Daughter to Charles the foresaid duke of Lorraine, By the which marriage the line of Charles the Great Was reunited to the crown of France.

target: Now my charms are all o'erthrown, And what strength I have’s mine own, Which is most faint.

target: I am his brother, and I love him well.

target: God will revenge it.

target: Then saw you not his face?

target: We’ll send Mark Antony to the senate house, And he shall say you are not well today.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What?
target: How?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll be ready when the time comes.
target: We will greet the time.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you have poison for me, I’ll drink it.
target: If you have poison for me, I will drink it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, not you again.
target: Yet again?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come with me, please.
target: Nay, come, I prithee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our advance will so dazzle the enemy that England will cower in fear and surrender.
target: Then let the trumpets sound The tucket sonance and the note to mount, For our approach shall so much dare the field That England shall couch down in fear and yield.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shall Kate be my wife?
target: Shall Kate be my wife?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It was tossed into the window of my room.
target: I found it thrown in at the casement of my closet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Signior Angelo, please excuse us.
target: Good Signior Angelo, you must excuse us all; My wife is shrewish when I keep not hours.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I’m running ahead of myself.
target: But yet I run before my horse to market.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re thinking something.
target: Thou dost mean something.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If that’s true, then don’t be tongue-tied.
target: If so, then be not tongue-tied.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good night.
target: Good night.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you crazy?
target: What, have you lost your wits?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The king has been informed of all their plans, but they have no idea.
target: The king hath note of all that they intend, By interception which they dream not of.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Run as if your life depended on it.
target: Haste thee for thy life.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve heard that’s not the most nourishing food.
target: And that’s but unwholesome food, they say.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m sure he will stay under control.
target: I doubt not of his temperance.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye, nymph.
target: Fare thee well, nymph.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How goes the battle?
target: How appears the fight?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who said that?
target: Who are they?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s see.
target: Let’s see.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now I’ll go see my priest, to ask for his help and tell him about my good luck.
target: Hence will I to my ghostly friar’s close cell, His help to crave and my dear hap to tell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: To put it plainly, I’m afraid I’m not quite sane.
target: And to deal plainly I fear I am not in my perfect mind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, you must see them as your father sees them.
target: Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you think of his neighbor, the Scottish lord?
target: What think you of the Scottish lord, his neighbor?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Rise, princes, and, with a spirit of honor more sharply edged than your swords, rush to the battlefield: Charles Delabreth, High Constable of France; you dukes of Orléans, Bourbon, Berri, Alençon, Brabant, Bar, and Burgundy; Jaques Chatillon, Rambures, Vaudemont, Beaumont, Grandpré, Roussi, and Fauconberg, Foix, Lestrale, Bouciqualt, and Charolois.
target: Up, princes, and, with spirit of honor edged More sharper than your swords, hie to the field: Charles Delabreth, High Constable of France; You dukes of Orléans, Bourbon, and of Berri, Alençon, Brabant, Bar, and Burgundy; Jacques Chatillon, Rambures, Vaudemont, Beaumont, Grandpré, Roussi, and Faulconbridge, Foix, Lestrale, Bouciqualt, and Charolois; High dukes, great princes, barons, lords, and knights, For your great seats now quit you of great shames.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Kill!
target: Kill!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t sleep so close to me.
target: Do not lie so near.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Enough, gentlemen.
target: Content you, gentlemen.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have a good night!
target: Rest you happy!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Seek!
target: Seek!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I am still so faithful, my lord.
target: Still so constant, lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How did you sleep, my lord?
target: How have you slept, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Caesar, I never believed in omens, but now they frighten me.
target: Caesar, I never stood on ceremonies, Yet now they fright me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Will you come with me?
target: Will you go with me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dead.
target: Dead.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I love you all the more for not liking it.
target: I love thee well in that thou lik’st it not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m too young to remember anything like it.
target: My young remembrance cannot parallel A fellow to it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You look like you have something more to say.
target: You look as you had something more to say.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What is it?
target: The matter?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, what a sad sight!
target: O piteous spectacle!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I wish we could unmask scoundrels like that, and give a whip to every good man to beat them senseless with!
target: O heavens, that such companions thou’dst unfold, And put in every honest hand a whip To lash the rascals naked through the world Even from the east to th' west!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is what happens when you act rashly.
target: This is the fruits of rashness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have you told her our decision?
target: Have you delivered to her our decree?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I just know I’m not one.
target: I am sure I am none such.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good girl, give it to me.
target: A good wench, give it me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I am friends with you all and love you all, on one condition—that you prove to me that Caesar was dangerous.
target: Friends am I with you all and love you all Upon this hope: that you shall give me reasons Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, Fool?
target: Why, Fool?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Instead, lend it to me as your enemy.
target: But lend it rather to thine enemy, Who, if he break, thou mayst with better face Exact the penalty.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s all the same.
target: Tis all one.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Even innocents cannot always escape disaster.
target: Some innocents ’scape not the thunderbolt.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I can’t do it myself, I’ll find someone who can.
target: And if I cannot, I’ll find those that shall.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord, here is the entrance.
target: Good my lord, enter here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In prison we’ll outlast hordes of rulers that will come and go as their fortunes change.
target: And we’ll wear out In a walled prison packs and sects of great ones That ebb and flow by the moon.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, unfortunately.
target: A most unhappy one.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Will you be having dinner with her tonight?
target: Will you sup there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Down with the Capulets!
target: Down with the Capulets!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Madam, please be patient.
target: Good madam, stay a while.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me lick your shoe.
target: Let me lick thy shoe.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then we can let this ambitious tyrant continue unchallenged until each of us is killed at his whim.
target: So let high-sighted tyranny range on Till each man drop by lottery.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What, my dear lord?
target: What, my gracious lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: to wage war.
target: Of what your reverence shall incite us to.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My God, this is unbelievably strange.
target: O day and night, but this is wondrous strange!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s standing ready outside the door.
target: He is ready at the door.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is how they do it, sir: they measure the depth of the Nile, according to certain marks made on the walls of the Pyramid.
target: Thus do they, sir: they take the flow o’ th’ Nile By certain scales i’ th’ Pyramid.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The life”?
target: The life”?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve decided on a plan that doesn’t require your assistance.
target: I have myself resolved upon a course Which has no need of you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, chest, obey me!
target: O, cleave, my sides!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Two of both kinds makes four.
target: Two of both kinds make up four.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Groan?
target: Groan!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll go with you.
target: I’ll go along, no such sight to be shown, But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If the Turkish fleet isn’t protected in some harbor, their men must all be drowned.
target: If that the Turkish fleet Be not ensheltered and embayed, they are drowned.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are your tears wet?
target: Be your tears wet?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dear God, thank you!
target: Jove, I thank thee!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re afraid of the boar but you go around without your spear?
target: Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So the lion disappeared.
target: And so the lion vanished.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Quiet there!
target: Peace there!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Women are like roses: the moment their beauty is in full bloom, it’s about to decay.
target: For women are as roses, whose fair flower Being once displayed, doth fall that very hour.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye, goodbye.
target: Farewell, farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Run after that obnoxious messenger, the duke’s servant.
target: Run after that same peevish messenger, The county’s man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, and I’ll keep crying a while longer.
target: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, ceremony, only show me your value!
target: O ceremony, show me but thy worth!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m locked up in a prison and deprived of food.
target: Not mad, but bound more than a madman is, Shut up in prison, kept without my food, Whipped and tormented and—Good e'en, good fellow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, put your sword away, my little soldier.
target: Come, my young soldier, put up your iron.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I feel sorry for you.
target: I pity you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Contagious infection of humanity, give me a chance to condemn you for the evils I know you’ve committed.
target: Vouchsafe, defused infection of a man, Of these known evils but to give me leave By circumstance to curse thy cursèd self.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then why did you travel so quietly?
target: Why have you stol’n upon us thus?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now I’ll get Cassio to do something in front of all these drunkards that will offend everyone on the island.
target: Now ’mongst this flock of drunkards Am I to put our Cassio in some action That may offend the isle.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re not paying attention to me.
target: Thou dost not mark me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, then it isn’t one to you, since nothing is really good or bad in itself—it’s all what a person thinks about it.
target: Why, then, ’tis none to you, for there is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What kind of crude jerk are you?
target: What profane wretch art thou?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve never known any woman or seen a woman’s face—except my own in the mirror.
target: I do not know One of my sex, no woman’s face remember— Save, from my glass, mine own.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Though science can explain them away, disasters still come after eclipses.
target: Though the wisdom of nature can reason it thus and thus, yet nature finds itself scourged by the sequent effects.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you like pictures?
target: Dost thou love pictures?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She has royal blood.
target: She is a royal princess.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve been practicing fencing constantly since he went off to France.
target: Since he went into France, I have been in continual practice.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That was when I was young and inexperienced and didn’t know what passion was.
target: My salad days, When I was green in judgment, cold in blood, To say as I said then.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: From Silvius, sir.
target: From Silvius, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take me inside some house, Benvolio, or I’ll pass out.
target: Help me into some house, Benvolio, Or I shall faint.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, good fool.
target: Ay, good fool.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll answer for you.
target: I will say for you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lord, the queen wants to speak with you right away.
target: My lord, the queen would speak with you, and presently.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Has homely old age taken the alluring beauty from my poor cheeks?
target: Hath homely age th' alluring beauty took From my poor cheek?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Farewell to both of you, dear teachers.
target: Farewell, sweet masters both.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But insincere men, like horses who are too lively at the start of a race, make a big show of their spirit.
target: But hollow men, like horses hot at hand, Make gallant show and promise of their mettle.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Not so fast.
target: Not so hot.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My father—I think I see my father.
target: My father—methinks I see my father.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s the news?
target: What news?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Madam.
target: Madam.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, please, I’m begging you, don’t mention him again.
target: O, by your leave, I pray you, I bade you never speak again of him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Be kind now and tell me some excellent fortune.
target: Good now, some excellent fortune!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There is no life, but my love is dead!
target: Not life, but love in death.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lay her in the ground, and let violets bloom from her lovely and pure flesh!
target: Lay her i' th' earth, And from her fair and unpolluted flesh May violets spring!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He is the son and heir of old Tiberio.
target: The son and heir of old Tiberio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But what danger we’ll put ourselves in, two young, innocent women traveling so far!
target: Alas, what danger will it be to us, Maids as we are, to travel forth so far?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please avoid doing that.
target: Pray you, avoid it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I rescued that ungrateful boy next to you from drowning.
target: That most ingrateful boy there by your side From the rude sea’s enraged and foamy mouth Did I redeem.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: By Jesus, I am your Majesty’s countryman, and I don’t care who knows it.
target: By Jeshu, I am your Majesty’s countryman, I care not who know it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I overlooked your request, but I did not deny it.
target: To lend me arms and aid when I required them, The which you both denied.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Gravestones have been known to move, and trees to speak, to bring guilty men to justice.
target: Stones have been known to move, and trees to speak.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If that is not granted, he reduces his requests and asks only that he be allowed to live as a private man in Athens.
target: Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee, and Requires to live in Egypt; which not granted, He lessens his requests, and to thee sues To let him breathe between the heavens and earth A private man in Athens.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A reason?
target: Wherefore?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now I am no more than a woman, ruled by the same lowly passion as the maid who milks and does the humblest chores.
target: No more but e’en a woman, and commanded By such poor passion as the maid that milks And does the meanest chares.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s look in his pockets.
target: Let’s see these pockets.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s a good fellow, I can tell you that much.
target: He’s a good fellow, I can tell you that.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen, sad friends, though the gods may rebuke me, this news would make kings cry.
target: Look you, sad friends, The gods rebuke me, but it is tidings To wash the eyes of kings.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But since this has happened, you should fix it for your own good.
target: But since it is as it is, mend it for your own good.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good night, lieutenant.
target: Good night, lieutenant, I must to the watch.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Indeed, the French can bet twenty French crowns to one that they’ll beat us, they have such an army.
target: Indeed, the French may lay twenty French crowns to one they will beat us, for they bear them on their shoulders.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll do it, if you help me out.
target: I will do this, if you can bring it to any opportunity.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, not tonight.
target: No, not tonight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is the jester I have met so many times in the forest.
target: This is the motley-minded gentleman that I have so often met in the forest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is it good or bad?
target: Is ’t good or bad?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Prince Dauphin, you’ll stay with me in Rouen.
target: Prince Dauphin, you shall stay with us in Rouen.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s my brave lord!
target: That’s my brave lord!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: May God in heaven bless you.
target: Now God in heaven bless thee!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, it’s the Moor.
target: Signior, it is the Moor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Soldier, you must come to the king.
target: Soldier, you must come to the king.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Or any of you?
target: Or any of your faction?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s coming here?
target: Who comes here?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What a horrible slut!
target: O most unhappy strumpet!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Send for the Count.
target: Send for the county.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll help you through this business.
target: I do serve you in this business.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Farewell.
target: Farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you want from me?
target: What wouldst thou with us?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your face is mine, and you have slandered it.
target: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slandered it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can suck sadness out of a song the way a weasel sucks eggs.
target: I can suck melancholy out of a song as a weasel sucks eggs.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I want to be this Duke’s servant.
target: I’ll serve this duke.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There is a man who loves you better than your husband could.
target: He lives that loves thee better than he could.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hate your logic as much as I hate an empty drinking cup.
target: I hate it as an unfilled can.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Fury, Fury!—Get over there, Tyrant, there.
target: Fury, Fury!—There, Tyrant, there.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ll remain a prisoner until we bring your crimes to the Venetian government.—Okay, take him away.
target: You shall close prisoner rest Till that the nature of your fault be known To the Venetian state.—Come, bring him away.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did the brothers-in-law leave?
target: What, are the brothers parted?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think she’s the most wonderful woman I’ve ever laid eyes on.
target: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I looked on.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Cleopatra, our conquest won’t include either the things you kept back or the ones you listed.
target: Cleopatra, Not what you have reserved nor what acknowledged Put we i’ th’ roll of conquest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Some people say that the earth shook as if it had a fever.
target: Some say the Earth Was feverous and did shake.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He would never have spoken to me like this.
target: He would not have spoke such a word.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My husband lost his life to get the crown, and my sons' fortunes have been tossed up and down, leaving me to rejoice over their victories and weep over their losses.
target: My husband lost his life to get the crown, And often up and down my sons were tossed For me to joy, and weep, their gain and loss.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ll soon be meeting Lorenzo at supper; he’ll be a guest of your new master.
target: And Launcelot, soon at supper shalt thou see Lorenzo, who is thy new master’s guest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, he ate with this woman at the Porcupine.
target: Sir, he dined with her there, at the Porpentine.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your guardian angel is noble, courageous, significant, and unmatched when Caesar’s not around.
target: Thy dæmon—that thy spirit which keeps thee—is Noble, courageous, high, unmatchable Where Caesar’s is not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You will be exhibited in Rome along with me, like Egyptian puppets.
target: Thou an Egyptian puppet shalt be shown In Rome, as well as I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m a poor man who’s been humbled by many misfortunes.
target: A most poor man made tame to fortune’s blows, Who by the art of known and feeling sorrows Am pregnant to good pity.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Draw your sword, scoundrel, or I’ll slice your thighs like flank steak.
target: Draw, you rogue, or I’ll so carbonado your shanks.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But now I’ll grit my teeth and kill anyone who tries to stop me.
target: For when mine hours Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives Of me for jests; but now I’ll set my teeth And send to darkness all that stop me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is it that early in the day?
target: Is the day so young?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She creeps along.
target: She creeps.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your grief should not be equal to his worth, because then your sorrow would never end.
target: Your cause of sorrow Must not be measured by his worth, for then It hath no end.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You want me to copy the embroidery pattern?
target: I must take out the work?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m sure the duke will never allow this contract to be enforced.
target: I am sure the duke Will never grant this forfeiture to hold.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Has Banquo left the court?
target: Is Banquo gone from court?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: With all my heart, I give you that thing which, if you didn’t already have it, I’d try with all my heart to keep from you.
target: I here do give thee that with all my heart Which, but thou hast already, with all my heart I would keep from thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There has never been a widow who suffered such loss as me.
target: Was never widow had so dear a loss.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In this world, I’m only taking up space.
target: Only in the world I fill up a place which may be better supplied when I have made it empty.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Pardon us, dear father.
target: Pardon, dear father.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That counts for everything.
target: Ay, when the special thing is well obtained, That is, her love, for that is all in all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Leave him alone.
target: Let him alone.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hear a voice more piercing than the music of these trumpets calling “Caesar!” Speak.
target: I hear a tongue, shriller than all the music, Cry “Caesar!”—Speak.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take it away.
target: Away with it!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And her sister’s dead too, poisoned by your wife.
target: And her sister By her is poisoned.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And so, good Capulet—which is a name I love like my own name—you should be satisfied with what I say.
target: And so, good Capulet—which name I tender As dearly as my own—be satisfied.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go.
target: Go after.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you down in the dumps?
target: In your dumps?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know my nails are stronger than my eyes; I’ll scratch them out.
target: For I am sure mine nails Are stronger than mine eyes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Was it you that was always plotting to kill him?
target: Was ’t you that did so oft contrive to kill him?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look: Benedick is so pale—are you sick, or angry?
target: As I am an honest man, he looks pale.—Art thou sick, or angry?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then, rejecting my request, you kill
target: You kill me to deny it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, good judge!
target: O noble judge!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d rather die in a ditch in Egypt, and make it my gentle grave.
target: Rather a ditch in Egypt Be gentle grave unto me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here is the count of the slaughtered French.
target: Here is the number of the slaughtered French.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If true lovers are always thwarted, then it must be a rule of fate.
target: If then true lovers have been ever crossed, It stands as an edict in destiny.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We would not want to die in the company of a man who fears to die with us.
target: We would not die in that man’s company That fears his fellowship to die with us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I admit I’m only a woman, but I’m still a woman from a noble family—I’m Cato’s daughter.
target: I grant I am a woman, but withal A woman well-reputed, Cato’s daughter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Make room!
target: Room, ho!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me go.
target: Let me go.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll let you.
target: You shall have leave.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So stop hoping and wondering what I mean.
target: Therefore be out of hope, of question, of doubt.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What, the necklace?
target: What, the chain?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Master, should I watch the door?
target: Master, shall I be porter at the gate?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I said something, she’d mock me so mercilessly that I’d probably disintegrate into air.
target: If I should speak, She would mock me into air.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why are you knocking so hard?
target: Who knocks so hard?
