source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I recognize the handwriting.
target: I know the hand.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I beg your pardon, sir— What did that guy say?
target: So please you— What says the fellow there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Nurse!
target: Nurse!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I come to ask you out of charity to let us wander over this bloody field to record the numbers of our dead and bury them, separating our nobles from the common men, for many of our princes—alas!—lie drowned and soaked in the blood of mercenary soldiers.
target: I come to thee for charitable license, That we may wander o'er this bloody field To book our dead and then to bury them; To sort our nobles from our common men, For many of our princes—woe the while!— Lie drowned and soaked in mercenary blood.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, don’t fight by sea, noble Emperor!
target: O noble Emperor, do not fight by sea!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you say, Signior Gremio?
target: How say you, Signior Gremio?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How is your majesty doing?
target: How fares your majesty?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t have anywhere to go, so I don’t need to see.
target: I have no way, and therefore want no eyes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, you would beg, if you were in my position.
target: Ay, you would beg, Were you in my distress.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How can you stand there shamelessly talking about me and Hippolyta, when you know that I know about your love for Theseus?
target: How canst thou thus for shame, Titania, Knowing I know thy love to Theseus?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: With all my heart, Phoebe.
target: Phoebe, with all my heart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Rulers abuse their power when they separate it from compassion.
target: Th' abuse of greatness is when it disjoins Remorse from power.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why are you looking for me?
target: Why seek’st thou me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hope to God Othello’s all right.
target: Pray heavens he be, For I have served him, and the man commands Like a full soldier.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s better here than outside.
target: Here is better than the open air.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ouch, what a comeback!
target: What a blow was there given!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What friend?
target: What friend?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s that calling so loud?
target: Who calls so loud?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me wipe it off first.
target: Let me wipe it first.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You call yourself my wife, yet you don’t call me “husband”?
target: Are you my wife and will not call me “husband”?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Out here everybody can see us.
target: Here all eyes gaze on us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go to the church: take the priest, the clerk, and some reasonably honest witnesses.
target: To th' church take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient honest witnesses.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: First, he sends his regards.
target: First, he commends him to your noble self.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But what’s the upshot of her admiration?
target: But is there no sequel at the heels of this mother’s admiration?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My heart is thirsty for that noble promise.
target: My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re taking it more seriously than I meant it.
target: You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She shall be buried next to her Antony.
target: She shall be buried by her Antony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And if they don’t find charity there, they find it someplace else.
target: If not, elsewhere they meet with charity.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If she were so moral, she would never have fallen in love with the Moor in the first place.
target: If she had been blessed, she would never have loved the Moor.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then I’ll know exactly what she is, just as I know what I am.
target: No, let me know, And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Gentlemen, on to the bridal dinner.
target: Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There was no Signior Montanto in our army.
target: There was none such in the army of any sort.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m very sorry you’re not feeling well.
target: I am very sorry that you are not well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tie him up like a thief and bring him here to me.
target: Pinion him like a thief, bring him before us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Or rather, do what you feel like doing.
target: Or rather, do thy pleasure.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I didn’t survive a shipwreck so I could be scared of your four legs now.
target: I have not ’scaped drowning to be afeard now of your four legs.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Antipholus, you hear how the man pleads with me.
target: You hear how he importunes me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sad, my lady!
target: Sad, lady!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The interest rate will be— Well, Shylock?
target: The rate— Well, Shylock, shall we be beholding to you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s this song?
target: What is this same?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s very hot.
target: It is very hot.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s true.
target: Good, i' faith.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you have permission to go out and take confession today?
target: Have you got leave to go to shrift today?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My noble lord— What is it, Iago?
target: My noble lord— What dost thou say, Iago?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Poor imitation queen, why do you align yourself with this humpbacked spider when he’s got you trapped in his deadly web?
target: Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune, Why strew’st thou sugar on that bottled spider, Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You are my guests.
target: I am your host.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, master, tell me.
target: I pray you, master, tell me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I told you not to hang around my house.
target: I have charged thee not to haunt about my doors.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Read it.
target: Read thou this challenge.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, no more questions.
target: Here cease more questions.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: To hell with your sword.
target: Come, no matter vor your foins.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good Macbeth, we’re ready when you are.
target: Worthy Macbeth, we stay upon your leisure.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lucillius and Titinius, order the commanders to have the men camp for the night.
target: Lucillius and Titinius, bid the commanders Prepare to lodge their companies tonight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have more than you show, Speak less than you know, Lend less than you owe.
target: Have more than thou showest, Speak less than thou knowest, Lend less than thou owest, Ride more than thou goest, Learn more than thou trowest, Set less than thou throwest, Leave thy drink and thy whore And keep in-a-door, And thou shalt have more Than two tens to a score.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So take your last breath.
target: Therefore exhale.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here comes better news.
target: Here comes newer comfort.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’ll happen soon enough.
target: That shall be by and by.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But not for long; Charles will take care of everything.
target: But it shall not be so long; this wrestler shall clear all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Regarding the Dauphin, you can speak to me.
target: For the Dauphin, I stand here for him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take these too.
target: And this.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hello, brother Edmund.
target: How now, brother Edmund?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, though he had no part in the killing, will benefit from his death—receiving a share in the commonwealth, as you all will.
target: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, though he had no hand in his death, shall receive the benefit of his dying—a place in the commonwealth—as which of you shall not?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then your other senses must be getting worse because of the trauma of blindness.
target: Why then, your other senses grow imperfect By your eyes' anguish.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What are they doing in the north when they should be in the west serving their king?
target: What do they in the north When they should serve their sovereign in the west?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you like, we’ll stand by and wait to do whatever you need.
target: So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sometimes snakes wrap around me, hissing at me with their forked tongues till I go crazy.
target: Sometime am I All wound with adders who with cloven tongues Do hiss me into madness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll tear her to pieces!
target: I’ll tear her all to pieces!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bring him my head.
target: Bear him my head.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: About as long as it would take someone to count slowly to a hundred.
target: While one with moderate haste might tell a hundred.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They are.
target: They are.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A man old Frederick, your father, loves.
target: One that old Frederick, your father, loves.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll be able to see better from that pine tree over there.
target: Where yond pine does stand I shall discover all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is that you, Iago?
target: Iago?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Eros, my young friend, your captain is now just like that cloud.
target: My good knave Eros, now thy captain is Even such a body.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My good man Norfolk, hurry to your post.
target: Good Norfolk, hie thee to thy charge.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Away!
target: Hence.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goneril, you aren’t worth the dust the wind blows in your face.
target: O Goneril, You are not worth the dust which the rude wind Blows in your face.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve got nothing to do with you.
target: I have nothing to do with thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Horatio says we’re imagining it, and won’t let himself believe anything about this horrible thing that we’ve seen twice now.
target: Horatio says ’tis but our fantasy And will not let belief take hold of him Touching this dreaded sight twice seen of us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What good does heaven have in store that can do me any good now?
target: What good is covered with the face of heaven, To be discovered, that can do me good?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dreams are a sign of ambition, since ambition is nothing more than the shadow of a dream.
target: Which dreams indeed are ambition, for the very substance of the ambitious is merely the shadow of a dream.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Shall I be your slave?
target: Shall I play my freedom at tray-trip, and become thy bondslave?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know that my hour has come.
target: I know my hour is come.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll meet again at nine in the morning.
target: At nine i' th' morning here we’ll meet again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My soul is full of sorrow.
target: My soul is full of sorrow.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Perform the speech just as I taught you, musically and smoothly.
target: Speak the speech, I pray you, as I pronounced it to you, trippingly on the tongue.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m doing so.
target: Why, so I do.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Pain, yes indeed.
target: Dolor comes to him, indeed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then how will we see their own natural tears?
target: How shall we then behold their natural tears?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s the play called?
target: What do you call the play?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If he’s not around, bring his brother Oliver to me.
target: If he be absent, bring his brother to me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Cassio’s a good friend of mine—My lord, I can see you’re upset.
target: Cassio’s my worthy friend— My lord, I see you’re moved.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This place is full of trouble, torments, and amazements.
target: All torment, trouble, wonder, and amazement Inhabits here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Could the lead one contain it?
target: Is ’t like that lead contains her?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But if you have the stomach for it, you’ll have all the help from me you need.
target: But if you have a stomach, to ’t, i' God’s name: You shall have me assisting you in all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I could take back my crown by force—What outrageous ingratitude!
target: To take ’t again perforce— Monster ingratitude!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I thank your Highness.
target: Thanks to your Highness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is there a scale here to weigh the flesh?
target: Are there balance here to weigh The flesh?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Of all places, I don’t like the
target: I do not like the Tower, of any place.— Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Plain and simple loyalty doesn’t make anyone act phony.
target: There are no tricks in plain and simple faith.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And when I’ve sneaked up on my sons-in-law, then I’ll kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!
target: And when I have stol'n upon these sons-in-law, Then, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please give me a little credit!
target: Prithee bear some charity to my wit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s over here.
target: Tis here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s too overwhelmed with shame.
target: A sovereign shame so elbows him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What, here in the middle of the street?
target: What, in the midst of the street?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your master and his servant are here.
target: Thy master and his man are here, And that is false thou dost report to us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell the army to flee.
target: Bid them all fly, For when I am revenged upon my charm, I have done all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I mean please go into the house, sir.
target: I mean, to go, sir, to enter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Everything we’ve heard is bad.
target: All that is spoke is marred.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We won’t go today—or any day until it’s clear that it shall be whatever time I say it is.
target: I will not go today, and ere I do It shall be what o'clock I say it is.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’re trying to be reasonable while you’re so upset, and we understand that you’re old, and… But Goneril knows what she’s doing.
target: For those that mingle reason with your passion Must be content to think you old, and so— But she knows what she does.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The duke is temperamental.
target: The duke is humorous.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, no, he’s surely not in hell.
target: I hoped there was no need to trouble himself with any such thoughts yet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I would be glad to forget about it, but it weighs on my memory like sins linger in guilty minds.
target: I would forget it fain, But oh, it presses to my memory, Like damnèd guilty deeds to sinners' minds.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Poison, I see, has been the cause of his death.
target: Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end.— O churl, drunk all, and left no friendly drop To help me after?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But since you come from him, you’re saturated with his healing spirit.
target: Yet, coming from him, that great med’cine hath With his tinct gilded thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He can’t possibly be such a monster— And I’m sure he isn’t.
target: He cannot be such a monster— Nor is not, sure.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you forgive my mistake, I swear I’ll never break an oath with you again.
target: Pardon this fault, and by my soul I swear I never more will break an oath with thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll leave you, lady.
target: I’ll leave you, lady.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please hire Cassio again.
target: Pray you, let Cassio be received again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I brought you here from Venice.
target: I have brought you from Venice.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I certainly do have him, but I wouldn’t advise you to touch him.
target: Truly, I have him, but I would not be the party that should desire you to touch him, for his biting is immortal.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I’ll stop rebuking you.
target: But I’ll not chide thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And you say he’s not jealous?
target: Is not this man jealous?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t do this.
target: I may not leave it so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then surrender, coward, and we’ll put you in a freakshow, just like they do with deformed animals.
target: Then yield thee, coward, And live to be the show and gaze o' th' time.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re like the poor cat in the old story.
target: Wouldst thou have that Which thou esteem’st the ornament of life, And live a coward in thine own esteem, Letting “I dare not” wait upon “I would, ” Like the poor cat i' th' adage?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I swear, sir, you did not eat at home.
target: Sir, sooth to say, you did not dine at home.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here she comes, the brilliant fool-catcher.
target: Here comes my noble gull-catcher.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I chose her for my wife when I thought I had no father to ask advice of.
target: I chose her when I could not ask my father For his advice, nor thought I had one.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: While the armed hand fights in foreign lands, the wise head defends itself at home.
target: While that the armèd hand doth fight abroad, Th' advisèd head defends itself at home.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Be gone!
target: Avaunt!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Caesar?
target: Caesar?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I gave my lover a ring and made him swear never to lose it or give it away.
target: I gave my love a ring and made him swear Never to part with it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Caesar, I have news about Menecrates and Menas, notorious pirates who prowl the sea in a variety of ships.
target: Caesar, I bring thee word Menecrates and Menas, famous pirates, Make the sea serve them, which they ear and wound With keels of every kind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What Tranio did, he did at my command.
target: What Tranio did, myself enforced him to.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you serious?
target: Speak’st thou in sober meanings?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Richard, the duke of Gloucester, is very dangerous, and the queen’s sons and brothers are haughty and proud—it would be better for this ailing country if they were subjects, not rulers.
target: O, full of danger is the duke of Gloucester, And the queen’s sons and brothers haught and proud, And were they to be ruled, and not to rule, This sickly land might solace as before.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m off to visit my friends in Padua—particularly my best friend Hortensio.
target: Verona, for a while I take my leave, To see my friends in Padua, but of all My best belovèd and approvèd friend, Hortensio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is the single man lucky, then?
target: Is the single man therefore blessed?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What country is this, friends?
target: What country, friends, is this?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll shut up now.
target: Here’s our chief guest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll speak to him now.
target: I’ll board him presently.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Since she belongs to me, I can do what I want with her—as the law says: I can either make her marry Demetrius—or have her killed.
target: As she is mine, I may dispose of her— Which shall be either to this gentleman Or to her death—according to our law Immediately provided in that case.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is there anything offensive in it?
target: Is there no offense in ’t?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You, Nick Bottom, have been cast as Pyramus.
target: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It doesn’t matter.
target: All’s one.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why,
target: Why,

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, it’s true.
target: Tis true.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t think I’m in love with him just because I’m asking about him.
target: Think not I love him, though I ask for him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My body waits here, but the rest of me is gone.
target: I am gone, though I am here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Did you hit your head?
target: Have you not hurt your head?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When Duke Frederick heard that great, worthy men were coming to this forest every day, he raised a large army to invade this land and fight his brother.
target: Duke Frederick, hearing how that every day Men of great worth resorted to this forest, Addressed a mighty power, which were on foot In his own conduct, purposely to take His brother here and put him to the sword.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And servants of the Danish king.
target: And liegemen to the Dane.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who’s the one who’s going out the door right now?
target: What’s he that now is going out of door?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How do you mean, “conspired”?
target: How intend you, “practiced”?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Trinculo, if you interrupt him any more, I swear I’ll knock some teeth out of your head.
target: Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in ’s tale, by this hand, I will supplant some of your teeth.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll cry my tears for Romeo’s banishment when their tears are dry.
target: Mine shall be spent When theirs are dry, for Romeo’s banishment.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s going on?
target: How now!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Angry enough to run away.
target: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, he’s the Prince’s fool, and a very dull fool at that.
target: Why, he is the Prince’s jester, a very dull fool, only his gift is in devising impossible slanders.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, just look over there.
target: Prithee, see there!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let the envoy from Antony come in.
target: Let him appear that’s come from Antony.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bow to him, fairies, and curtsy to him.
target: Nod to him, elves, and do him courtesies.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let me choose now.
target: At our synagogue, Tubal.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I had to hurry to my love, beautiful Helena, who lights up the night better than all those fiery stars.
target: Lysander’s love, that would not let him bide, Fair Helena, who more engilds the night Than all yon fiery oes and eyes of light.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The only thing that I’ve been entrusted with was getting you from the market and bringing you to your house, the Phoenix, for lunch.
target: My charge was but to fetch you from the mart Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God defend and guard us innocents against them!
target: God and our innocence defend and guard us!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Not with any sauce they could provide for them.
target: With no sauce that can be devised to it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I can’t sleep quietly in the Tower.
target: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell her you heard us, and that she should sneak into the arbor where the crisscrossing branches overhead keep the honeysuckles out of the sun.
target: Say that thou overheardst us, And bid her steal into the pleachèd bower Where honeysuckles ripened by the sun Forbid the sun to enter, like favorites Made proud by princes, that advance their pride Against that power that bred it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Neither good nor bad.
target: Neither good nor bad.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Leonato, am I standing here?
target: Leonato, stand I here?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You gave us the slip, sir, the slip.
target: The slip, sir, the slip.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But please, tell me the worst thing that could happen to me if I refuse to marry Demetrius.
target: I know not by what power I am made bold Nor how it may concern my modesty In such a presence here to plead my thoughts, But I beseech your grace that I may know The worst that may befall me in this case, If I refuse to wed Demetrius.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where have you sent the king?
target: Where hast thou sent the king?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The person who suffers alone suffers the most.
target: Who alone suffers, suffers most i' th' mind, Leaving free things and happy shows behind.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t snap at me.
target: Do not you chide.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come, I’ll place you among the sisterhood of holy nuns.
target: Come, I’ll dispose of thee Among a sisterhood of holy nuns.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And how did you get in here?
target: And how cam’st thou hither?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Ride to Salisbury.
target: Post to Salisbury.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He looks humbler than he used to.
target: His eyes are humbler than they used to be.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You were a cold crumb on dead Julius Caesar’s plate when I met you.
target: I found you as a morsel cold upon Dead Caesar’s trencher.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In my imagination, Horatio.
target: In my mind’s eye, Horatio.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Royal Egypt, Empress!
target: Royal Egypt, Empress!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t be scared.
target: Be not afeard.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go then, slave.
target: So, slave, hence!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I think that’s strange.
target: That methinks is strange.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Prove that the men you call your fathers did truly conceive you.
target: Now attest That those whom you called fathers did beget you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, don’t.
target: No, forbear.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hurry, go!
target: Go hence with diligence.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Until now, no one could say that only one man mattered in all of vast Rome.
target: When could they say till now, that talked of Rome, That her wide walks encompassed but one man?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dear Duke, please listen to what I have to say.
target: Most gracious Duke, To my unfolding lend your prosperous ear And let me find a charter in your voice, T' assist my simpleness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you have the flower?
target: Hast thou the flower there?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Thank God I’m not a woman and afflicted with all the giddiness that troubles that entire sex.
target: I have heard him read many lectures against it, and I thank God I am not a woman, to be touched with so many giddy offenses as he hath generally taxed their whole sex withal.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s good, if he’ll really do it.
target: So said, so done, is well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, yes, we could, sir.
target: Oh yes, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re busted.
target: Or wilt thou hunt?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If I were your average fool, or if I made my feelings for you worthless by making the same promises of friendship to everybody, or if you’d seen me first flattering men, hugging them tightly, and later slandering them behind their backs, or if you hear that I drunkenly declare friendship at banquets with all the rabble, only then, of course, go ahead and assume I’m dangerous.
target: Were I a common laugher, or did use To stale with ordinary oaths my love To every new protester, if you know That I do fawn on men and hug them hard And, after, scandal them, or if you know That I profess myself in banqueting To all the rout, then hold me dangerous.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s true, lieutenant.
target: It’s true, good lieutenant.

target: Within this hour it will be dinnertime.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t wake her.
target: Wake her not.

target: A most manly wit, Margaret, it will not hurt a woman.

target: A king, a king!

target: It eats and sleeps and hath such senses As we have, such.

target: What is it ye would see?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes.

target: I’ll make you amends next, to give you nothing for something.

target: Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wear All your true followers out.

target: And did you leave him in this contemplation?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, let me remember what happened to Hastings and hurry to
target: O, let me think on Hastings and be gone To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m going to let him live.
target: Thy father hath his life.

target: Tomorrow, soldier, By sea and land I’ll fight.

target: If our sport had gone forward, we had all been made men.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You lie.
target: You lie.

target: There is a fat friend at your master’s house That kitchened me for you today at dinner.

target: Now, herald, are the dead numbered?

target: Stand!

target: The man i' th' moon!

target: The sun was not so true unto the day As he to me.

target: thee aloud “England is thine, Ireland is thine, France is thine, and Harry Plantagenet is thine,” who, though I speak it before his face, if he be not fellow with the best king, thou shalt find the best king of good fellows.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: One of them was a man named Pinch: a hungry, narrow-faced villain; a skeleton; a fraud; a raggedy magician and fortune-teller; a needy, hollow-eyed, emaciated wretch; a walking corpse.
target: Along with them They brought one Pinch, a hungry, lean-faced villain, A mere anatomy, a mountebank, A threadbare juggler, and a fortune-teller, A needy, hollow-eyed, sharp-looking wretch, A living dead man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ve been waiting a long time for this day.
target: Now is the day we long have lookèd for.

target: I speak but in the figures and comparisons of it.

target: Nay, had I power, I should Pour the sweet milk of concord into hell, Uproar the universal peace, confound All unity on earth.

target: Death, in guerdon of her wrongs, Gives her fame which never dies.

target: After her, after her.
